PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.

That the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative 'Advisory Council'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of any legislation regarding Plant Variety Rights.
1. We believe it would transfer control, the key aspect of agriculture in this country, to overseas interests not responsible to the Australian Government.
2. We believe it would restrict the growing and trading of many seeds.
3. We believe it would cause a decline in the genetic diversity of crops making them more subject to destruction by pests and diseases.
4. We believe thorough investigation of the effect of similar legislation overseas and a full public debate is required before any decision is made.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on Plant Variety Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF UNITED STATES B52 AIRCRAFT THROUGH AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the agreement dated 11 March 1981 between the governments of the United States of America and Australia on the staging of United States Air Force B52 aircraft through Australia should be renegotiated-

(a) to include a new article reading 'No aircraft carrying nuclear weapons shall use any facility in Australia or based in Australia without the prior agreement in writing of the Australian Government';

(b) to secure amendment of Article (VII) of the agreement to require approval by the Australian Government of developments affecting the staging operations, rather than consultations on such developments; and
(c) to review Article (II) to secure the location of the B52 aircraft and their support aircraft away from Darwin to a location well removed from major population centres of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, as a States House, expresses its grave concern-
(a) that the South Australian Liberal Premier, Mr Tonkin, has stated he intends to transfer money from the Loan Account to compensate for the shortfall in the Revenue Account;

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Chaney, though I am not sure in what capacity. Has the Minister been given the task of supervising the Government's publicity committee as reported in Monday's Age? Does this function involve determining how public money can be spent on improving the electoral standing of the Fraser Government? Does the Minister see any conflict arising when he and the committee approve an allocation of public funds to market research by advertising firms which are retained by the Liberal or National Country parties in the performance of their functions as political parties? If so, how does he reconcile these decisions with the sentiments he expressed when reading a statement or a speech on behalf of the Prime Minister at a Liberal Party gathering in Adelaide on 5 December last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any duties that I have are not related to matters of the electoral standing of the Government but rather the need to ensure that accurate information is available to the Australian people. This is something which sometimes governments find hard to do. I would have thought that, on any comparison of the expenditure of the present Government with the expenditure of the previous Labor Government on matters such as the employment of journalists and people who are there to ensure that information is available to the public, this Government is extremely modest in the amount of public funds that it devotes to that purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government Information Unit has a very small number of journalists here in Canberra-I think it has two with a third to be appointed. It has also one journalist in each State capital. In fact, the Commonwealth Government would have one of the smallest and most modest information services of any comparable government. I suggest that if Senator Button is seriously worried about the amounts of money which might be expended in making information available to the public, he examine the position in New South Wales with its Labor Government and do a comparison between the resources devoted to this area by that Government and by this Government and let me know the results of his inquiries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Chaney, arising from his answer, whether he now justifies the Government's action by referring to things which a Whitlam Government did but which he condemned as wrong.

—Mr President, I suggest that the honourable senator who leads the Opposition go and find whatever statements he apparently recalls that I made about any subject during the time of the Whitlam Government.

—Well, I am afraid, Mr President, that general statement does not really tell the Senate anything. The fact is that the Government has an obligation to ensure that the programs which it is administering are known to the Australian public and it will carry out that obligation in accordance with the proper principles of government expenditure in this area.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to the proposed introduction of cable television. While I agree that this will be a valuable asset to the community, I seek an assurance from the Minister that adequate controls will be built into the system to prevent it from being used to exploit pornography and thus ensure that there will not be any further erosion of the social and moral fabric of our society.

—The honourable senator asks a question relating to the introduction of cable television in Australia. I think that decision is a fair way off. Approximately 60 submissions already have been received by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for its inquiry into cable television, but it is anticipated that a further 80 submissions are yet to be lodged. So I imagine it will be some considerable time before those submissions are lodged, examined and assessed. The closing date for these submissions was about one week ago. The honourable senator seeks an assurance that, when cable television is introduced, it will contain appropriate safeguards against the unrestricted showing of pornographic material. I think that the honourable senator has raised an important matter and I will undertake to refer it to my colleague, the Minister for Communications.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Department of Social Security makes available to various organisations subsidies under the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, but refuses to disclose details of such subsidies? Is it a fact that the Department takes no interest in the services made available to people from these subsidies and, in particular, to the eligibility criteria used by such organisations? If this is so, how can members of this Parliament, or anyone else, make a judgment about the public accountability of these organisations in the use of these public funds provided by this Parliament?

—All the funds administered in the subsidy programs of my Department are, of course, appropriated by this Department and are subject to public examination both in the Parliament and in the committees of this Senate. I have no information that suggests that the Department is refusing to provide information about subsidies paid under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act. I certainly will inquire into the matter which has been raised by Senator Grimes and see whether any difficulty exists about it. It would not be true to say that the Department takes no interest in the people who are beneficiaries of these programs. It is a fact that, in our subsidy programs generally, we are providing moneys to organisations which have the responsibility of providing services to the handicapped-the very purpose for which they were formed. My Department does, however, become involved from time to time in providing assistance and consultants to organisations which may be having difficulties. It does not directly provide the services. If Senator Grimes believes that there are areas of neglect of the interests of the beneficiaries by organisations which receive subsidy funding from the Commonwealth, I suggest that he draw those matters to my attention and I will see what action needs to be taken and can be taken.
—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health tell the chamber why at present there is such financial chaos within the hospital system in Tasmania?

—I do not know exactly the state of hospitals in Tasmania, but I am advised that instructions have gone out that the hospitals have to truncate or limit some of their activities, certainly in hiring. It is quite clear to honourable senators that the Commonwealth presently shares 50 per cent of the net operating cost of each State's public hospitals and that each State is responsible for meeting the other 50 per cent of the cost. If, in fact, Tasmania has decided its hospital system is in disarray, I think it must look to its record of management of its economy to find the answer. That is where the answer rests. I imagine that there has been a record of mismanagement if, in fact, the hospitals in Tasmania are in that situation.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy but which may be of relevance also to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, concerns the long range effects on Royal Australian Navy personnel who served in the vicinity of the Monte Bello atomic trials. Are there any records of a higher than normal rate of terminal illness of naval personnel, or ex-naval personnel, who served in HMAS Karanji, on the staff of the naval officer in charge in Western Australia, or in HMAS Boom Depot, Fremantle, at the time of the Monte Bello atomic trials? What ships were employed in monitoring the radiation levels at the Monte Bello Islands in the three years following the tests in question? Is there a record of any unusual illness among ships' company, in particular among the monitoring team? Also, what equipment was returned by HMAS Karanji to HMAS Boom Depot after the Monte Bello Islands trials? Was it checked for radiation and how was it ultimately disposed of? Finally, how many days did HMAS Karanji spend in the vicinity of the Monte Bello Islands during the time of the tests?

—As honourable senators will know, at this moment my Department is conducting a very intensive investigation specifically into the Maralinga tests and any effects of radiation upon those who served there during the 1950s and 1960s when nuclear explosions occurred. That investigation can readily encompass those who served in areas where atomic tests took place, including the Monte Belle Islands. I repeat my exhortation of the public that any person who has any information relating to adverse effects of nuclear testing in Australia or off-shore Australia or any person who believes that an acquaintance may have suffered such effects should come forward. We are anxious to contact every person who may have been involved. We are searching the records that exist. Records do exist, of course, but people have moved, gone abroad or died. Specifically, I am making a general appeal in terms of the substance and meaning of Senator Mulvihill's question. Although I am not aware of the details of the particular Royal Australian Navy officers and personnel or of the particular vessel or vessels involved, I will seek those details and let Senator Mulvihill have them. Let me make it perfectly clear that my Government, my Department and I want every person who has any information that could help in a thorough investigation of the effects of the nuclear explosions in the 1950s and 1960s to contact my Department or me.
—Wouldn't they be in violation of the Crimes Act?

—We will make sure that they have protection. The question of violation of the official secrecy provisions does not occur with regard to the confidential information they may give to our officers. We will make sure that no threat of violation occurs there. We want to obtain every piece of information that exists today. That would apply to the Monte Bello Islands as well. If Senator Mulvihill has such information, I would be grateful if he were to let me have it.

—I have a supplementary question, which is prompted by Senator Gietzelt's interjection. In the middle of my set of questions I referred to the disposal of some equipment. I wondered-fairly or unfairly-whether we are encountering some difficulty with the Royal Australian Navy about divulging information relating to the setting aside or storing of some of this equipment.

—I know of no such difficulty. Only recently I wanted to reassure myself of that problem in relation to Maralinga. Therefore I sought out the confidential scientific information that was available, read it and studied it. I then went to Maralinga and inspected the various sites. On the basis of the information in the documents and on the assumption that that material existed in the pits concerned, I was able to satisfy myself that very considerable steps had been taken to dispose of waste materials that might be radioactive. I was able to satisfy myself that the safeguards of pits, sealed concrete caps, fences and Federal police patrols were all there. My recollection-I would need to check it-is that I have similar information as to the Monte Bello Islands. I have not been there. It is, in fact, upon my list of places to visit in the near future. I will check. It may well be that because of secrecy all I can do is to say that I have inspected the site and am able to give assurances. Let us pursue the questions asked to see what we can say.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. What is the Federal Government's position concerning the proposed makarrata or Aboriginal treaty? What action has been taken in regard to the proposed treaty? Can the Minister advise what representations, if any, have been made to the States regarding the treaty? If approaches have been made, were they made by the Federal Government or some other authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Makarrata is an Aboriginal word meaning, in general terms, a resumption of normal relationships at the end of a period of disagreement. The word is being used in relation to a move to develop an understanding between Aboriginal people and other Australians. I will answer the last part of the question first. The discussions to develop a makarrata will involve both the Commonwealth Government, which will deal with national Aboriginal bodies, and also State governments which will deal with those areas which relate to their own activities. The meeting last week between State and Commonwealth Ministers responsible for Aboriginal affairs was attended by representatives of the National Aboriginal Conference who asked the States whether they would open up discussions on the question of a makarrata. So, the direct approach has come from the elected representatives of the Aboriginal people to the States regarding the makarrata. I must say to the honourable senator that I do not use the word treaty for reasons which have to do with the precise legal meaning of the word. The approach came from Aboriginal people and was taken up by most of the States and the Northern Territory. At this stage no State has indicated that it will not discuss the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government proposes, with the help of the National Aboriginal Conference, to pursue the concept of a makarrata and also to provide assistance to the NAC to research and develop the proposal. In doing so, the Government is prepared to acknowledge prior occupation of Australia by Aboriginals. We are not prepared to act unilaterally in those areas where the States have an interest. I have indicated to the NAC in a number of particular matters that the Government cannot negotiate a treaty which implies an internationally recognised agreement between two nations. I have indicated to the NAC that the Government cannot agree to any fixed financial commitment into the future. I have also indicated to the NAC that the Government cannot support the proposal for reserved seats in the Parliament for Aboriginals. I have also indicated in response to a particular recommendation from the NAC, that the Government does not believe that a system where Aboriginal employment is subject to a rigidly fixed formula is appropriate. Nevertheless, the Government has indicated a position from which it will negotiate. The Aboriginal representatives have now opened up the matter further with the State governments. It is up to them to take the next step.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. As it now appears certain that a large number of countries will boycott the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Brisbane if the South African Springbok rugby tour to New Zealand goes ahead, what action does the Government intend to take on this matter? Is it possible that the invitation for New Zealand to attend the Commonwealth Games may be withdrawn in order to save the Games?

—The question raises some quite sensitive and hypothetical issues. In view of the particular sensitivities and efforts of a large number of people to seek an equitable agreement on this matter I think it proper that I refer the question to my colleague for a detailed answer.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Have there, as yet, been any discussions or proposals involving some or all of the States for a rebate system of power charging as an incentive to the installation of solar or other supplementary alternatives to the present power supply? If not, can this be proposed at either a Premiers Conference or at State energy Minister level? Does the cost and availability of existing power in Australia justify such an action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of a system of rebates on electricity charges to provide an incentive for the installation of solar energy units essentially involves the pricing policies of State electricity authorities and, as such, falls outside the Commonwealth's responsibilities, as Senator Archer would acknowledge. The situation faced by each electricity authority would no doubt determine the economics of such a proposal. Without being aware of the relevant costs and other matters, it is difficult to say what the economics would be. However, such a proposal would be likely to be less attractive in Australia with its coal-fired electricity generation than it might be in countries in which such schemes have been introduced-for example, in some parts of the United States of America-and which rely on oil-fired electricity generation to a large extent.

ANSWER.PARA: There are signs that, even without special concessions, many people are finding it economically attractive to install solar units, especially for hot water systems. For example, in Western Australia some 22 per cent of new home owners chose a solar water heater in 1979. In excess of 80,000 solar units are now installed in dwellings in Australia.

No discussions have been held between the Commonwealth and the States on a system of power charging rebates for having solar systems installed. As the matter is primarily one for the States, it would be appropriate for any discussion to be initiated by a State, but this discussion could occur between Commonwealth and State Ministers and at meetings of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council. Nevertheless, I will bring the honourable senator's question to the notice of my State colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate is prompted by Senator Bjelke-Petersen's appearance in the Senate. When will the Government honour election promises given by Mrs Bjelke-Petersen last year as leader of the Queensland National Party Senate team to introduce 20 per cent flat rate taxation with a $10,000 tax free threshold?

—The Government will honour all its election promises and other promises made in the name of the Government. The Government has not made any such promise as that referred to by Senator Walsh. Indeed, the Prime Minister has indicated that a flat rate tax would not be a part of Government policy.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer, I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether, the next time the junior coalition partner tries to gull the electorate with false promises, the Government will come clean and tell the truth before the election is held instead of four months afterwards, as it did on this occasion.
—Order! Does the Minister wish to answer that question?

—I am quite sure that that question is out of order. However, all people who have any honesty of memory will know that before the election the Government Leader made it very clear where the Government stood on the policies of taxation. The policies of taxation which the Government proposes to implement have been made clear to the people of Australia at all times.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to reports that at the inaugural meeting of the Saudi-Australian Joint Commission, the question was raised with the Minister for Trade and Resources as to whether Australia's voting patterns in the United Nations in relation to Israel might be modified or in some way affected in the future. I refer to the reply of the Minister for Trade and Resources that there was a growing awareness and even-handed policy being applied by Australia and that he looked forward to having discussions in an attempt to do what could be done to solve this painful problem. Does this indicate that the Australian Government is considering some shift in emphasis or change in its policy in relation to Israel, particularly in relation to issues which arise at the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the statement made by the Minister for Trade and Resources. I will need to refer the matter raised by Senator Martin to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his response.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the statement of the Prime Minister made last week contrasting the Federal reduction in the number of public servants with a large increase that had taken place in State and local government employment. Is it the intention of the Fraser Government to force State governments to reduce the size of their public services and to curtail community services by cutting the allocation of Federal funds to the States at the forthcoming Premiers Conference? Does the Minister acknowledge that the Prime Minister's attitude makes a mockery of his so-called co-operative federalism policy which was a feature of his 1977 election campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is any mockery, it is a mockery of the wrong claim by members of the Australian Labor Party that the States have been short of funds. The figures indicate that whereas the Commonwealth Government, over the last five years, has reduced its Public Service numbers by approximately 10,000-do not hold me to that figure; that is in indicative figures-State Public Service numbers have increased by 100,000. A little calculation will show that to do that they would need approximately an extra $2,000m a year just to maintain that kind of growth. So the first dolly that goes over is that argument that the States have been short of funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is this: There will be a Premiers Conference, I think, within the next month. At that conference, there will be discussion about any new arrangements that there may be with regard to income tax sharing or other matters. I am not able to forecast what will arise from that conference. All I can say is that the test of federalism has been that, in the course of the five or six years that it has run, the States have been able to increase their services and to reduce taxation. Quite clearly, the States have had an abundance of funds during that time.

What the Prime Minister has said is this: It is clearly in the interest of the welfare and the living standards of all Australians that we should keep inflation down, and certainly below that of our trading partners. Since the States and local government handle and spend some 52 per cent of all public funds, they have as much responsibility towards the proper control of finance as has the Commonwealth. If indeed the Commonwealth, under its economic policies, is operating restraint, so should the States if we are to maintain the position that we have been restored to in terms of inflation and of our trading partners in the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that in April 1976 the Government promised that it would substantially increase allocations to the States? Further, is it not a fact that it is the Whitlam formula which the Premiers now want to continue, which has been one of the reasons by which State finances have been healthy and which this Government now proposes to reduce?

—I do not know the significance of April 1976, but the fact is that the policy which now appertains regarding federalism-that is, the policy by which the States get 39.87 per cent of all personal income tax and local government gets 2 per cent of personal income tax-was stated quite clearly throughout the time that the Government was in Opposition and in the early days of its return as the Government, and was implemented. Mr President, what happens for the future is a matter for negotiation between the Commonwealth and the States concerned.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology noticed the depressing frequency with which 24-hour weather forecasts bear no relation to what actually happens? For instance, in Canberra yesterday there was supposed to be developing rain. There was no developing rain and in fact it was a hot fine day. Whilst accepting that weather forecasters can usually tell us what the weather is and perhaps make a useful two-hour route forecast for an aircraft, I should like to ask the Minister: How much does the Commonwealth Bureau of Meteorology cost each year? Is there any statistical evidence that expensive and sophisticated aids such as satellite photographs have significantly improved the accuracy of 24-hour and longer forecasts? If so, how great has been the improvement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be even more depressing if we were able to forecast the weather too accurately. A major point of discussion and complaint which we have all the time about the weather would be removed. The cost of operating the Bureau of Meteorology in 1979-80 was $40m. That covers forecasting, warning and consultative services provided for aviation, defence, shipping and the general community. The main technological aids available to assist weather forecasting are satellite data, computers, radar and communications facilities. Any evaluation of the accuracy of weather forecasting is largely subjective, as I am sure Senator Hamer will agree.

ANSWER.PARA: The indications are that the various aids mentioned by Senator Hamer have resulted in the following: Little improvement in forecasts beyond two days; approximately a 10 per cent improvement in 24-hour forecasts in the last 10 years-we are getting somewhere-but significant improvements in shorter term forecasts. I add as a general point that since satellites have been available there has been a 170 per cent increase in the number of tropical cyclones detected in northern Australia and adjacent oceans and an hourly location system of cyclones is now available everywhere off Australia because of radar and satellites.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General, and in asking it I intend no reflection on the present Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation who, I note, intends to retire from that position in the near future. In view of allegations that a previous head of the British intelligence organisation MI5, Sir Roger Hollis, was for 30 years a member of the Soviet organisation KGB, and indeed the reported decision of the British Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, to undertake an inquiry into that matter, does the Attorney-General see any implications in this situation for the current law covering ASIO which gives virtually unfettered power and influence to any future Director-General? Does the Government intend to bring in amending legislation to require greater accountability to the Attorney-General and to this Parliament and so reduce the chances of a mole infiltrating this position?

—I do not propose to make any comment on matters concerning the operations of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation which may be implied in the Hollis matter. I notice that that is speculative in the British Press and that the Prime Minister of Britain has sought information about it. As far as the legislative framework and accountability of ASIO are concerned, the answer to Senator Mason's question is no. As we all know, ASIO was the subject of a very extensive inquiry by Mr Justice Hope, who reported very fully on the matter and made a large number of recommendations.
—We have never seen it.

—Honourable senators have seen major portions of that report which were made public. His recommendations in relation to the administration of the organisation have been acted upon. His recommendations in relation to legislation were the subject of major legislative changes in the ASIO Act which was extensively debated in this Parliament two years ago. The Government sees no reason to make any further changes in relation to the Act at present.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, by saying that I well recognise the Minister's interest in decentralisation. I refer to a statement in today's Press which indicates that Australia's first silicon wafer fabrication plant is to be built in Canberra at a cost of some $100m and may eventually employ, I believe, about 2,000 people. Is the Minister aware that for many reasons this is exactly the type of industry that should be located in Tasmania? As an electronic engineer I recognise that the growing of silicon chips requires pure air. Surely the air in Tasmania is purer than that in Canberra. I think that is proved by the fact that one of the world's air monitoring stations was established in the north-west of Tasmania because of the air purity there. Is the Minister further aware that the silicon chip industry is suitable for Tasmania because of the ease of air freighting the small but very valuable chips and that it is an industry which employs many people without huge demands for energy-a fact which conservationists would appreciate? I ask: Why was Canberra chosen? Was the Tasmanian Government asked whether it could offer a suitable site for the plant? Does the establishment of this plant mean that, as well as making Canberra the bureaucratic centre of Australia, there will be an attempt to make it the small industry centre and particularly the electronic centre of the country as well? Finally, will the Government re-examine the decision to establish this plant and any others like it in Canberra?

—The choice of Canberra as a potential site for the National Semiconductor company silicon wafer plant was made by the company itself. That was its choice. I make it clear that what the Government has announced is that an agreement for a feasibility study should be made to ensure that all aspects of the feasibility of this undertaking will be capable of fulfilment. There is no doubt in the world that if Australia can get a silicon wafer plant which would be of very high technology-technology that is rapidly changing and increasing-this will be of significance to Australia. I repeat that a feasibility study is being undertaken. Of course, I am aware that those kinds of industries would be ideal for Tasmania. Indeed, one would want not the derision of the Opposition but a constructive approach to seeking such industries and attracting them to Tasmania. I think it can be said without whimsy that Tasmania does have purer air than most parts of the community. Equally, it is possible for such an industry which produces small, lightweight commodities to operate from Tasmania because air freight costs would be very small. The answer is that Canberra was selected as the centre by the National Semiconductor company itself. That must be, I take it, the free choice of commerce and industry. It was nothing to do with bureaucracy as such. I think all honourable senators and the people of Canberra would like to see Canberra develop not entirely as a public service community but as a community of mixed occupations.
—I would like to see the same for Tasmania.
—I did not hear Senator Rae's interjection, but I am sure he would like to see a Canberra not entirely operated by quasi-autonomous national government organisations.
—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether it is a fact that the $16m profit reportedly made by the Bell group in its supposed bid for Elders will be tax free? If this is so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information on the matter raised by Senator Robertson. I will refer the matter to the Treasurer and seek information for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I draw the Minister's attention to an article appearing in the February 1981 edition of the Victorian National Trust Newsletter relating to a meeting recently held in the Seychelles at which delegates from 15 major Indian Ocean states approved a proposal to set up an Indian Ocean Alliance for Conservation by making the Indian Ocean a whale sanctuary. I ask whether the Minister agrees with the comments of the Seychelles President, Mr F. A. Rene, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: The whaling issue could be used to forge an alliance with the other Indian Ocean coastal States and that these States could build a regional conservation policy that could set an example of common sense to the rest of the world.

Will the Minister inform the Senate, firstly, whether Australia was represented at the meeting in the Seychelles, secondly, whether we indicated our support for the proposal and thirdly, what action will be taken by the member nations to ensure that the alliance operates effectively?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is considerable opportunity for, and advantage to, Australia to develop regional conservation policies in co-operation with neighbouring countries to protect common resources such as whales. Representatives of the following governments attended the Seychelles meeting: Bangladesh, the Republique Federale Islamique Des Comores, the Republique De Djibouti, India, the Islam Republic of Iran, Iraq, Mauritius, Oman, Pakistan, Kenya, the Republic of the Maldives, the Republic of Seychelles, Sri Lanka, Tanzania and the Peoples Democratic Republic of Yemen. The Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Professor J. D. Ovington, as Australian Commissioner to the International Whaling Commission, was invited to attend the meeting as an observer and to speak to participants about the IWC and the functions and responsibilities of member nations. Other observers as well as Professor Ovington were present. These were from the Republic of Seychelles, the United Nations Environment Program, the Indian Ocean Cetacean Survey and the California Academy of Sciences. Australia has supported the establishment of the Indian Ocean whale sanctuary. The Australian position with regard to the Indian Ocean alliance for conservation will be considered once a more definitive proposal is developed. It is understood that the Seychelles Government will be pursuing with Indian Ocean coastal nations how best to establish and implement the proposed Indian Ocean alliance for conservation.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Is the Minister aware that drought conditions still continue in a very serious way in New South Wales as well as, no doubt, in other parts of Australia thus causing severe hardship to farmers, particularly those on small holdings, and adding to the great unemployment problems existing in country towns? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent annual report of the New South Wales Rural Assistance Board which states that notwithstanding the permanent basis on which the Rural Adjustment Scheme is constructed, the steadily diminishing Commonwealth contribution to its funding is seen by some observers as an indication that the Commonwealth Government recognises no ongoing commitment to assist in the rural adjustment process and that 6,000 farms in the wheat-sheep zone of New South Wales plus 8,000 in the high rainfall zone will become non-viable by 1986 because of lack of Commonwealth interest in the matter? Will the Minister ask his ministerial colleagues to study the report of the New South Wales Rural Assistance Board and earnestly request the Government to make sufficient finance available for rural reconstruction purposes, especially at this time of severe drought and unemployment in rural areas?

—I suppose it is generally true that drought conditions, along with low prices, tend to focus attention in the rural community on the need for things such as rural reconstruction. I have little doubt that the bad conditions which apply throughout much of rural New South Wales are directing increased attention in the area referred to by the honourable senator. I can assure him that both I and the Government are aware of the drought conditions and the severe hardship that they have brought in many areas. The honourable senator would be aware that those drought conditions unhappily are not peculiar to New South Wales. In my State of Western Australia, some areas have now had drought for five years. I am not familiar with the report to which the honourable senator has referred. I will arrange to see a copy and to refer it to my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry, and seek a detailed reply to the matter which has been raised by the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer to what is known as the off airport duty free industry. At present, Australians can purchase their duty free goods weeks or even months before departure. However, over recent months we have seen a concerted effort by Qantas stewards to disrupt this practice. I ask the Minister: Firstly, can he assure the Australian people that the present system will continue so that the Government can be seen to back an industry based on the 'Buy Australian' theme. Secondly, will the Government consider expanding its present system to allow travelling Australians to purchase duty free goods within seven days of their arrival back in Australia, which would offer a better service, local guarantees, contribute to employment and, of course, save Australians the problem of taking overseas goods which they want back in Australia.

—I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs that the Government is not contemplating any action to eliminate the Australian off airport duty free operators at present. Following representations made on behalf of the international airlines operating in Australia, an interdepartmental committee examined the question of providing the facilities for arriving passengers to purchase the goods to which Senator Thomas has referred. The Committee's report will be considered shortly. I am told that that will take some time. That consideration will take into account the views of the Australian Duty Free Operators Association as well as the retail industry.

I ask: Did Sir Roger Hollis, who for 10 years was Director-General of British MI5, visit Australia in 1948? Was it in accordance with Sir Roger Hollis's advice that a number of trade union officials, including myself, were refused a right of entry to Woomera Rocket Range in 1948? —I am not in a position to know what a previous government, the then Chifley Government, did in 1948. I take the question quite seriously and apolitically, if I may. I will seek out what were the reasons and what information can be given. I am well aware that the honourable senator was denied access to Woomera.
—Because he was anti-Soviet.
—May I say this: I understood--
—Because I was anti-Soviet.
—Let me make this perfectly clear. I understand that that was on the decision of the Prime Minister.
—No, Sir Roger Hollis.

—I do not want my remarks misunderstood, and this may be said as a gratuitous matter: I came into this Parliament with a background knowledge that the honourable senator had been refused access to Woomera. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister gained a better regard for me during his term in this Parliament because he too has become anti-Soviet?

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to an article in the Australian on Monday, 23 March, headed 'Death and Disease Strike the Servicemen who took part in Australia's Atom Tests', 'The Tragic Story of Col Bird'. The story points out how shameful has been the treatment of those members of the armed forces and of the Commonwealth police who were exposed to radiation as a result of their work during the British atomic tests in Australia in the 1950s. I ask the Minister: Did he say, as was reported in the article, that he had been assured by the British authorities that all Australian personnel had been properly decontaminated? Has the Minister followed up this British assurance with any checking of Australian Service and police personnel records? If not, will he check on these records? Further, did the Minister accept the British assurances complacently? Will he now assure the Senate that he is in full possession of all relevant facts on which to base such complacency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never made any complacent statements on this matter. I have read that article. I read it with deep interest and sympathy for the persons concerned. My Department had prior contact with the two persons named in the article and we have received information about them. It is true that I have said that I had been assured that various precautions had been taken, but I have also said that those matters occurred 20 or 30 years ago when knowledge of the handling of radioactivity may have been more imperfect. As Senator O'Byrne will know, servicemen also have a habit of not always sticking to the regulations. Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not being complacent about the matter. I am seeking to do a number of things. Basically I am seeking to find out the circumstances of every person who served in those areas and to identify whether such persons have had a health problem and whether that health problem could have been a result of radiation. If there is some pattern between the radioactivity of nuclear testing of the 1950s and 1960s and the morbidity and mortality of our people, we want to know about it as to both the generality and the particularity of the individual or member of his family who will need help.

ANSWER.PARA: I have made widely a number of statements inviting people to come forward. As far as I know, about 2,000 civilians and servicemen were at Maralinga, Emu Plains and the area generally over a period of 10 years or more. About 160 people have come forward. This is a small but significant sample. We have sought from them information on the existence of their friends and associates. I have talked about the Service network, which, I think, the honourable senator will understand. We are combing through the records for two reasons: Firstly, to find out what happened at every specific place so that when a claim is made we will know the circumstances and, secondly, to try if we can, even from very old records, to track down individuals who do not come forward. Senator O'Byrne will understand that after 25 years it is unlikely that the records will hold the key to the situation. So it is better to invite people to come forward and track from them while we are going through the very tedious process of searching through old records, some of which, I think, are in England.

We have also invited the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association to give us its lists of people who have come forward to it. The Association would be a rallying point. I believe that the Association is inviting its members to give us the names and addresses of people who were involved. Whenever I get the opportunity publicly I will make an appeal for people to come forward. I thank the honourable senator for this opportunity. The only way we will know is by getting the largest possible sample of information that we can from those 2,000 people, some of whom will be dead and some of whom will be overseas, and checking whether the mortality and morbidity is atypical of the population and, if so, whether it could relate to radioactivity. As we proceed we must keep in mind that we are not just after some scientific information; it is important only if it relates to individuals and their sufferings. I would welcome any information that anyone brought to me. My door is open to any honourable senators who have such information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister a supplementary question. In view of the fact that any after effects of the contamination from the atomic tests could not really be classified as war caused disabilities or incapacity, will the Minister make provision for any of the people who consider themselves to be victims of this period to have access to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for the processing of their claims, as has any other ex-serviceman?

—My understanding is that there is a compensation provision which applies to both civilians and ex-servicemen. Indeed, my instructions to my departmental officers when they are interviewing people is not only to find out about people's general health and welfare but also to tell them that if they have a claim they should follow the specific procedures laid down. The specific procedures are being advised as widely as possible. If anybody has a claim which does not fit those procedures we will try to find some way in which to fit them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Walters asked me a question concerning hospital financing in Tasmania. I have a little extra information for the honourable senator. The Commonwealth approved Budget for hospital funding in Tasmania for 1980-81 was $83,149,000, of which the Commonwealth's share of 50 per cent was $41,575,000. This is an increase of 10.6 per cent on last year's funding. Unfortunately, Tasmania has continued to expand its hospital services outside the Commonwealth's guidelines for hospital funding. The Commonwealth's funding formula includes a factor for expected increases in the cost of goods and services as well as wages and salaries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth naturally requests the States to adhere to the broad escalation factors utilised in calculating the amount of public hospital funding in the ensuing year. However, if States can document and substantiate price increases in excess of the provisional escalation factors and demonstrate that efforts have been made to minimise or offset the rises, consideration can be given to the provision of additional funds under the cost-sharing arrangements. Examples of this have been the cost of fuel oil and the adjustments for wage and salary increases within wage indexation guidelines. These are made as a matter of course. At the recent Health Ministers conference in Perth the Minister for Health advised all States and the Northern Territory that the Commonwealth is prepared to consider and respond to as best it can any special difficulties that they may be experiencing. The Minister feels that if variations from a State's approved Budget are required they would best be considered at the next meeting of the standing committee of officers established to consider and review public hospital funding. The next series of meetings is scheduled to take place in April.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will be aware that in recent days considerable media attention has been given to matters related to problems suffered by Vietnam veterans. On Sunday last I issued a statement which had three aims. The first was to allay unnecessary anxieties which may have been generated by the rather sensational nature of the media coverage of these matters. The second aim was to indicate that there is a growing feeling that the problems of Vietnam veterans may have a much broader aspect than the narrow focus on whether or not there is a causal link with certain defoliants. SPEECH.PARA: My third aim was to repeat the offer I made on behalf of the Government earlier this year that any veteran who felt that he was suffering from problems which required urgent attention could avail himself of the full facilities of the repatriation treatment system.
