DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The inadequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance proposed to the Senate by the Australian Labor Party is designed to create some public interest in what we consider to be the inadequacies of our present electoral laws as they relate to political campaigning and political advertising. It is not to be construed as expressing any strong views about the recent case involving the High Court of Australia and certain candidates in the 1980 Federal election; rather, it is to analyse the deficiencies that we believe exist in the present Commonwealth Electoral Act. The purpose, after all, of any electoral system is to bring about a result whereby the party which polls 50 per cent or more of the votes should win the election. Of course, an analysis shows that if that system had been operating in the post-War years, the Australian Labor Party would have won the elections in 1954, 1961 and 1969 in addition to the two elections in 1972 and 1974.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the present electoral system is loaded. It is unfair, inequitable and undemocratic. Yet on the occasions when attempts have been made to remedy these matters in the Parliament, the conservative parties have failed to take any legislative steps to make political campaigning more equitable and democratic. The issue that we want to discuss today drags into the daylight all the hypocrisy, cynicism and outright duplicity of the Liberal and National Country parties. I can remember in 1975, for example, when we were debating an electoral Bill that had passed the House of Representatives, Senator Withers interjecting: 'It is fair to us; just awful to you'. Then he just chuckled. Of course the obstructionist attitude of the Senate placed that Bill aside. What cynicism did that represent? It only highlighted the same attitude that was found in the debate in the House of Representatives. For example, we can recall Mr Killen, then the shadow Minister for Defence, piously calling for the establishment of a joint committee to consider the matters after his party had already stated publicly that it was going to reject the Electoral Act. He called for the establishment of a joint committee. Similarly, in this place Senator Guilfoyle called for the establishment of a joint committee to consider the current Senate debate. Nearly six years later we can surely ask: Why did not the Fraser Government set up such a joint committee to consider electoral matters, electoral deficiencies and electoral expenditure?

We all recognise that there are such deficiencies in the Electoral Act. We can ask the question: Why does not the current Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, set up a joint committee to overhaul the electoral system instead of carrying on as he has been behind doors in secrecy sitting on a report prepared by his predecessor in the Australian Electoral Office? Why the secrecy? Is it because that report highlights these deficiencies and is critical of the Government's attitude to the matter? I challenge the Government-indeed I have asked two questions on this subject of Mr Newman-to make that report available. The issues of electoral reform are substantial and important. They are not unique to Australia. They are being raised in many other countries. Other democratic countries are taking steps when confronted with similar problems on matters of the electoral sytem, electoral expenditure, public accountability and electoral justice. Canada is currently carrying out such an examination. It is looking at different approaches and solutions. In some cases such conditions have already made the appropriate changes to the legislation. But what attitude has been adopted after reports in Australia have been investigated? The reports are kept under double wraps.

The Opposition believes-as indeed most of the other democratic countries and democratic parties believe-that there should be a limit to electoral funding and expenditure and that there should be a public disclosure of sources of funding. Surely a government that has nothing to hide should not be afraid to accept these basic principles. Surely they are basic principles for the maintenance of a functioning democracy. Surely it has to be accepted that the way in which election campaigns are financed is fundamental to the whole way in which the electoral process should operate. If parties do not have equal access to resources and adequate access to funds, the system is clearly lop-sided. In this country it is clear that the conservative parties have unlimited access and unlimited funds and resources. We should recall the question asked of the Government by Senator Button today. Despite the advantages the Government parties have in the political climate of Australia, this Government uses taxpayers' money to establish a communication unit, and extra units, in order to popularise and publicise its day to day policies. Of course, that gives it an edge on every other political party. Therefore it is able to exercise excessive influence in the moulding of public opinion and in the functioning of the whole parliamentary process.

The conservative parties also have the added advantage of greater access to the media. In fact, the media comprise one of the institutions that prop up this Government, its philosophy and its ideology. One has only to refer to the role that has been played in the media by the Murdoch Press. It is primarily because of that position in our society that this Government is able to win majority support. Those who want to put up a different political philosophy, a different policy and an alternative suffer as a result of the substantial use of resources by the conservative parties. The Opposition party is at a disadvantage. How much more at a disadvantage in this whole political process are the smaller parties in our society? What a travesty it is that in our society we have several processes and structures by which some relief is offered to our community-the Trade Practices Act, for example, is designed to protect consumers from the misuse of power in the market place itself and in respect of the media a Press council is designed to provide relief from the excesses that occur from time to time in the dissemination of information and so on-yet absolutely no relief is provided in our present Electoral Act so far as elections are concerned.

What has been the Government's response to the problems of electoral expenditure and campaigns? It set up a committee to try to establish a means of examining this problem. But the guidelines of that committee are so restrictive, so narrow, that in fact it has actually very little purpose at all when the question of public expenditure or funding or electoral expenditure has been raised from time to time. The terms of reference of the current inquiry being carried out are hopelessly loaded and restrictive. I would like to draw attention to just how restrictive the terms of reference are. In the first place, they exclude the question of disclosure of donations to candidates and parties. The Australian Labor Party is firmly of the view that giving money to a party to assist it in its pursuit of its public office responsibilities is an involvement in the electoral process. No privacy should be attached to this involvement. The electorate has a right to know who is providing funds for parties and candidates seeking their votes. The same principles apply to parties and candidates spending funds, whether public or private and whatever the source. We all recall how in the last session of Parliament, before the 1980 general election, this Government brought in legislation which even abolished the restriction on the limit of $1,000 per candidate for election expenses which previously existed in the Act, thereby removing completely any limitation in regard to the funding processes for elections. Arguments that such disclosures endanger the secret ballot system are specious and are rejected. An individual is certainly entitled to his or her privacy up to and until the moment he or she engages in public behaviour, but giving funds to a party or a candidate is a public act and, accordingly, no privacy should be attached to that act.

Although no firm statistics are available on this matter, most funding of election campaigns obviously comes from private corporations. When we consider that the conservative parties spend about three or four times that which is spent by the Labor Party and probably some 50 or 60 times that which is spent by the Australian Democrats, we can see that there is a need for some examination of this issue. The employees of those companies that give such substantial donations to the conservative parties or, indeed, the shareholders of those companies, are rarely consulted, if ever, about these donations and neither are the consumers who, after all, make up the profit given to conservative parties in the form of higher prices.

Anyone who knows anything about politics in this country would know that the conservative parties are the most corrupt of all political parties, corrupt in the sense that there is no disclosure of funds and no indication of how they are able to raise such large sums of money. Obviously these funds are from sources that are associated with them in commercial enterprises and in commercial arrangements. We have only to look at the end result to know that funds flow into the conservative parties in greater volume than they flow into any of the other political parties in our country. Nobody knows about the deals, the subsidies or slush funds which clearly find their way to the conservative parties for election purposes. Even the conservatives in Queensland have raised criticism about the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation and the means by which that enterprise has an advantage over the other conservative party. I do not suggest that individual members of the conservative parties are corrupt, but I do suggest that the conservative parties are corrupt insofar as they receive funds form unnamed sources and are not prepared, as the 1975 debates show and as the inquiry which is now proceeding shows, to have public disclosure of donations. Everyone knows that big spenders can win because they are the big spenders. Everyone knows that it is the Liberal Party and the National Country Party which are the big spenders in the whole political process. We are currently spending $100 for every man, woman and child in this country on commodity production exposure and sales in the market place. That shows, of course, how valuable it is to have a process of advertising. Therefore, those who have more money to spend on advertising obviously enjoy advantages.

Those of us who are involved in the political processes are aware that the very avaricious sections of our economy, such as the multinationals and the big mining sectors, have been and are involved in funding the conservative parties. We do not have to look at the situation in many countries to appreciate that the big corporations and the big business sectors have been involved in political scandals. In Italy, Japan and many other countries funds have actually flowed into political coffers as a result of commercial deals involving the government parties in power in those countries. We would be foolish unto ourselves if we did not realise that this is happening in our own country. For example, I know, but I cannot prove it because the arrangements that are made between corporations and parties are secret, that for years and years the Shell Oil Co financed the political activities of the Australian Democratic Labor Party. What we have is a democracy for the rich and the powerful, a democracy which assists those who have the hegemonic position in our society. We have an electoral system which is incredibly valuable to outside influence. That, for all we know, could extend even to foreign intelligence agencies and to centres of financial power. Basically, we need guidelines. We need to establish a process in our electoral laws that gives us the same sort of relief, the same sort of processes which would equalise and democratise the whole principle of electioneering in our country, if indeed we found the need to do it, as the Trade Practices Act.

I remind the Senate that if this Government were really concerned about this problem it would have applied itself to the major amendments which the Australian Labor Party formulated in 1975. Such formulations were passed by the House of Representatives following a debate in which all of these matters were adequately canvassed. They contained all the considerations which I have suggested need to be examined in the Parliament. It was the obstinacy, the dogmatism, the ruthless use of numbers and the authoritarianism of the Government parties, which then held a majority in this place, which prevented the implementation of the 1975 legislation. These amendments were aimed solely at eliminating some of the injustices and the inequalities of the present system, but after five years of the Fraser Government the need for reform is even more important and even more necessary than it was in those days. The reforms will have to be seen as radical and necessary.

The Electoral Act as interpreted allows those who control enormous financial resources to manipulate election campaigns at their pleasure while the ordinary person struggles to participate in the electoral processes at an unequal level. There is no equality in the system, either in the disclosure of the source of donations, the restraints on campaign spending, the control of the media and the structure of our electoral system, or in the power exercised by the upper houses of the various parliaments. The Government is already operating and has continued to operate on a system which favours it. The Government has taken the extraordinary step, in addition to the inequities to which I have referred, of establishing yet another unit to sell itself more successfully to the Australian people.

The way in which we could overcome the infamous situation which this High Court decision has brought home to us would be to set up the mechanics for an independent control of the administration of a new and reformed Electoral Act and system-the establishment, for example, of an electoral commission which should be permanent, independent, public and acceptable to all parties involved in the parliamentary process. It could be responsible within the guidelines of the Parliament for the regular redistribution of electorates. It could be responsible for overseeing all aspects of the Electoral Act, including those parts dealing with misleading advertising. It could be responsible for monitoring donations to political parties and electoral expenditure. The other speakers in this debate will deal with those matters in much more detail.

I well recall, for example, what happened at the booths for which I had some responsibility in the 1980 election. Big signs were placed in those booths which stated that a vote for Labor was a vote for higher taxes whereas in that election the Australian Labor Party was in fact specifically advocating a reduction in petrol prices and a reduction in taxation. Nowhere in any of the election propaganda or of statements of parliamentary candidates or of our leader was it ever suggested that there would be any increase in taxation. Those matters will be dealt with by other speakers. Here we are concerned about the way in which misleading advertising has an effect upon an election during the campaign and not subsequent to it.

It would be necessary, because of the potential dissension involved, for such an electoral commission that I have recommended to consist of members acceptable to the Parliament. Although by no means it should be legalistic in outlook, it would need to have expertise in law. For example, such a commission could probably include an eminent legal person from the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office-maybe the Commonwealth Ombudsman himself-representatives of the Government and of the Opposition and the Commonwealth Chief Electoral Officer operating under a more broadly defined, popular and democratic electoral Act. In any case, its members would need to be acceptable to all parties and be of high standing in the community if their decisions were to be mandatory.

We believe that the current Electoral Act is inefficient, deficient, discriminatory, undemocratic and biased. To the extent that we will have opportunities to debate those matters in this place in the next two or three years, we will be setting out to have established by the Senate an electoral committee to examine the weaknesses of our existing system and to make to the Parliament recommendations that would have the effect of putting into legislation the way in which elections should be conducted. Such a system would enable the party receiving the majority of votes to hold a majority in both houses of Parliament. We will be setting out to create equity in respect of public expenditure. We will be setting out to bring about a more equitable electoral system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating a matter of public importance, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The inadequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising.

I was disappointed that Senator Gietzelt in his rather rapid cover of the subject did not specifically sheet home, prove or make good his assertions on a whole range of matters. Australia is one of the handful of 20 or so countries which can claim to be democracies. Our democratic system is a fair one. It is fairer, for example, than the system in the United Kingdom. Under that system many members are elected by a minority of votes, and I consider it to be a grossly inferior system. Of course, in this country no one can gain election to a single member constituency for the House of Representatives unless he or she achieves 50 per cent of the votes cast in that election. If we look at global votes it is quite possible to determine that one party may have marginally more or less votes than the party which won the election. But if we count the number of members who represent single member electorates we can see that our system is fair and that it is well administered. We have an electoral office which is non-corrupt. We have officers who are dedicated, who do their jobs and who administer the Act fairly and without fear or favour.

I believe the things that Senator Gietzelt asserted are very serious things, and it is up to him to try to prove them and to sheet them home. I am looking forward to the contributions which numerous honourable senators will make to this debate. If there are some kinds of problems in relation to the Act or its administration, I hope that they will bring them out. We know that at present an examination of the Electoral Act is in progress. The Minister responsible announced on 4 December last year that an examination was to be made. Therefore, this is quite an appropriate time for those who have substantial matters they wish to bring to the attention of the Government to put them before the Senate. But when they do so, I think they have to do so in a calm and measured way and not in the rather florid and extravagant way we have just heard of putting matters which are non-testable, the truth of which cannot be proven or disproven and which really are ideological statements-polemics, shall we say-and not really of much help.

However, a number of subjects were referred to by Senator Gietzelt and I would like to respond to a couple of them because I think they need some kind of airing in public. He referred to election advertising. If it is his wish, some of my colleagues who will take part in this debate will give him chapter and verse, word for word, from the election advertising from his side-what was said publicly by some of his colleagues, including Senator Walsh-in relation to some of the matters which became contentious at election time. We will bring out this material because it is very clear that what comes out in public debate is the stuff of politics. What goes on in this Parliament is a continuous review and evaluation operation. Election advertising material is not like a bar of soap. If we want to advertise soap we have to adhere to certain testable qualities about the product under certain Acts, including the trade practices legislation.

But in the Parliament we have a unique system whereby day by day the ideas which make up the stuff of politics are examined, tested, questioned, assessed and evaluated. Every day we have Question Time. We have matters of public importance. We have adjournment debates. Every issue and every proposition that comes up can be tested here publicly. We have the Fourth Estate which exists to report, to evaluate and to interpret what is said and to indicate what it sees as the weaknesses and strengths of different people's cases. In the end people put together all the material they get from the Parliament, from public debate and from the media quite separately from the question of advertising, and they make their judgments.

Of course, the sour grapes of Senator Gietzelt result from the fact that they do not decide in favour of his side of politics. It must be understood that at the centre of his concern and his disquiet is the fact that his side is not winning. It is true that his side recommended a number of changes to the Electoral Act in 1975. I remember the Act introduced by the Honourable Fred Daly. It proposed, inter alia, not to count electors for the purpose of drawing up electoral boundaries. He was going to count population. He was going to count children.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he did not.

—He was going to count population. He would have altered the electoral system in many ways. However one goes about changing the Act, and however the Labor Party went about changing the Act, it is a matter requiring the closest examination and the most careful scrutiny. I look forward with great interest to what Senator Chipp has to say because, as I said, a review of the Electoral Act is in progress now and I would like to hear all kinds of inputs that people have relating to this Act and its operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of misleading election advertising was referred to briefly, and I think Senator Gietzelt was correct when he said that there was no intention on his part to reactivate or to open up again the recent High Court ruling. But it is worth putting down that the Court, when it made its judgment on 18 March, affirmed the long standing advice to the Attorney-General's Department on the subject. The actions really were not necessary. I think honourable senators should remember that the Attorney-General's Department's most recent advice was in relation to a complaint from Senator Chipp about a National Country Party advertisement dated 15 October 1980. At that time the Attorney-General's Department included earlier advisings by Sir Robert Garran dated 1919 and by Sir George Knowles dated October 1934. On 5 September 1980 I incorporated those advisings in Hansard. They set out the position as it applied. They set out advisings which have been upheld by the High Court.

The honourable senator might wish to argue that the law is inadequate. But the law has been applied on this occasion, as it has been applied before, and it is in accord with all the advisings that have been available to us on this matter. We tried to make known to the honourable senator what the situation was to avoid what would be costly and pointless challenges. People talk about changing the law in relation to some of these matters. It is very difficult to know whether they would increase the situation in equity. It is very difficult to know whether they would create an efficient system or whether the proposed changes which have been suggested would be workable. Considerable practical difficulties could arise if certain changes were made along the lines suggested, for example, by the Australian Democrats. It is a fact that many of the issues which may arise during election campaigns in relation to political speeches or political advertising may be issues not really suitable for testing in the courts.

Suppose we want to argue about the provision of housing in Australia. The argument becomes very difficult unless we can agree upon the definition of what is a house, what is a flat or what is a home unit. For the purpose of the argument, we might assume a certain amount of housing provision but someone might challenge our figures. It would be very difficult to argue in a court that one person was wrong and another person right or to argue the extent of the provision in one year or another. Some of these things are very difficult to test.

Senator Gietzelt raised the matter of public disclosure of donations to candidates in political parties. It is necessary again to advise the Senate, and to make clear to the Australian public, that this is another matter at present being investigated. The examination is being carried out by an eminent Australian, Sir Clarrie Harders, former head of the Attorney-General's Department. He is now carrying out an inquiry into public disclosure of electoral expenditure. I must advise the Senate that there are a number of arguments which can be made in a general way against requiring the public disclosure of political contributions. I thought it rather disingenuous of Senator Gietzelt to fulminate against the contributions to political parties and omit mention of the funding basis of the Australian Labor Party from the trade union movement often by way of compulsory levies which people cannot avoid if they wish to continue carrying out their occupation. These people find it very difficult to avoid contributing to a political party which may not be the party of their choice.

I will state some of the arguments that could be made against public disclosure of such political donations. First of all, the disclosure of donations to political parties denies people the right to support privately the party of their choice. This amounts in effect, to a violation of the secrecy of the ballot. Many people wish to make their donations privately-for example, small people who just wish to give money. Donors, if forced to disclose donations, may face-let us not put too fine a point on it-retaliation, threats or harassment because of their campaign gifts. For example, there may be trade union intimidation of companies making donations to the Liberal or National Country parties. There could be harassment of contributors to minor parties or parties which want to promote unpopular causes-for example, the Marihuana Party. People who support that party may not wish to declare publicly that they are so doing because they fear retaliation or harassment.

I think that at least there is a respectable argument that we should acknowledge the problem and acknowledge the rights of donors in this matter. The disclosure of the names of donors to political parties might lead to a substantial decline in the voluntary contributions to campaign funds, not only from individuals or organisations fearing harassment, but also from donors simply wishing to remain anonymous. There are many people in many areas of public life who remain anonymous in respect of the donations they make. Disclosure might also inhibit donors who wish to support an individual candidate and not necessarily a political party that person is standing for. There are occasions when people who are not members of a political party and who would not join a political party will support a candidate who has merit or who they like for some other reason. The other reason that I think should be raised as one in favour of not publicly disclosing donations is that it would be extremely difficult to enforce prohibitions against anonymous contributions. I am not really aware of the administrative arrangements which might be brought in to effect such a procedure.

There are other reasons which would make me unwilling to endorse public disclosure of campaign funding. Again I will come back to a point I have made all the way through my speech. An inquiry on this subject is in progress at present. People who want to make a reasoned and careful case and have something to say on this subject should get in touch with the person conducting this inquiry, a person of the highest integrity, Sir Clarrie Harders O.B.E. Their thoughts on the matter will be valuable. The other matter referred to by Senator Gietzelt concerns public funding of election campaigns. Senator Gietzelt raised this as one of the things which his party favours. I will not go into the matter at any great length but simply point out to the honourable senator that a joint committee of the New South Wales Parliament is at present conducting an inquiry into public funding of election campaigns. That inquiry is incomplete. The terms of reference have been drawn in such a way that the inquiry will not determine whether such funding is a good idea but will simply make recommendations on the introduction of a system to allow public funding. This is a situation we are watching with some interest but we have to offset that because there are other committees looking into the question of public funding.

For example, there is the Piggott committee report from Tasmania. That committee was established by the Tasmanian Government in October 1979 to inquire into the Tasmanian Electoral Act, particularly the electoral expense provisions. The report was tabled in the Tasmanian Parliament in March last year. The Piggott report expressed no support at this stage for public funding of electoral campaigns. That State report left open the determination of the threshold matter. In New South Wales we are talking about merely the determination of the subject of matters. The threshold matter for the proposition that there should be public funding of election campaigns elicited no support in Tasmania. Of course, this matter of the terms of reference is difficult and I acknowledge, in relation to the matter I raised earlier, that Sir Clarrie Harders has limited terms of reference in relation to the reporting of expenditure. I note that an honourable senator attempted to interject on this point earlier.

I come back to what I was saying before: This Parliament is a means of evaluating what goes on both in the electoral atmosphere and in relation to the policy promises of individual political parties. To listen to the Opposition, one would think that the only element of an election campaign and the only basis on which people decided how to vote was the political advertising, the way that advertising is funded and the way the financial support of parties is derived. It would be thought from what we heard from the Opposition that the Australian people would believe anything they were told. It could be believed, listening to Opposition senators, that the performance of political parties in the Parliament, the performance of candidates on the hustings and at meetings, the presentation of policies through the public media and the philosophical approaches, reputations and standing of party leaders had nothing whatsoever to do with the way people vote.

Well, their performances do have something to do with the way people vote and it is because they have something to do with the way people vote that the Australian Labor Party continues to lose elections. It is because people are concerned with the performance of the parties. It is because they are concerned with the performance of candidates. It is because they are concerned with the record in government, which is a public record. It is because they are concerned with the record of Oppositions, and that is also a public record. It is because they are concerned with the philosophical approaches which are adopted. It is because they are concerned with the reputation of a Prime Minister and a Leader of the Opposition. It is for these reasons that the Australian people make up their minds. It is for these reasons that the Australian people have on three occasions elected, very handsomely, a Liberal-National Party Government. It is for this reason that on three occasions the ALP has been rejected.

Let me repeat that, at the present time, this Government is examining the Commonwealth Electoral Act from a number of points of view. The examination announced by Mr Newman last November is incomplete. I hope that the contributions made in this debate will provide a useful input into the work that is being done by Mr Newman's Department and to the amendments which he might want to bring forward to the Act in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Leader of the Australian Democrats) (4.6)-The Senate is debating as a matter of public importance the inadequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising. We have just heard from Senator Peter Baume, who is leading for the Government in this debate, a 20-minute speech which I describe as a reasonable kind of defence of the right of politicians and political parties to lie, to deceive, to mislead and to traduce. As I understood Senator Baume's speech, that is precisely what it was-a defence of the right of politicians to do those things.

SPEECH.PARA: Next up was a piece of gratuitous advice that he gave to the Democrats and the Labor Party, that is, that we should not have initiated the action in the High Court of Australia which alleged that the Liberal Party won seats in this Parliament by telling lies-by telling blatant lies. We had an admonition from Senator Baume that we should not have done it, wasted so much money, taken up the High Court's time and inconvenienced political parties because the Liberal Party had warned us before we took the action that it would fail. As Senator Baume said, he brought down a statement on 5 November telling us that we would fail. That statement relied on advice of a Solicitor-General 60 years ago and, on the basis of that advice we should never had had the temerity to go to the High Court, sitting as a Court of Disputed Returns, and asking it to disallow election results because blatant, palpable and provable lies were told by the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were we right or wrong in the advice we gave you in November?

—In answer to the interjection, I say that the Liberals were spot on in the way in which they suggested the seven highly paid people on the Bench of the High Court would interpret the section; and I will have more to say about that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I refer to the High Court judgment of 18 March and the Government's reaction to it. Simply put, the Australian Democrats asked, so far as the result for Western Australian representation in the Senate was concerned, the High Court sitting as a Court of Disputed Returns to say that section 161 (e) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act should be applied. That section of the Act says, inter alia, that it is an illegal practice to print an electoral advertisement containing any untrue or incorrect statement intended or likely to mislead or improperly interfere with any elector in or in relation to the casting of his vote. For the benefit of the people who are listening to the broadcast of this debate, I repeat that under the Act it is an offence to print an electoral advertisement containing any untrue or incorrect statement-that covers lies-intended or likely to mislead or improperly interfere with any elector in relation to the casting of his vote.

I would have thought that the advertisement, among many others, which I now hold up and which was inserted by the Liberal Party-authorised by some person called Porter in Western Australia and on which hundreds of thousands of dollars was spent in the last week before the election and which reads: 'If you vote Democrat it might be your first Labor vote and could give Labor control of the Senate'-is a blatant, palpable, provable lie. Then followed this bald, naked statement: 'Democrats voted with Labor eight times out of 10 in the last Parliament'. That is a blatant, provable, palpable lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Divisions.
—Yes, I accept the interjection from Senator Peter Baume so that it will be recorded in Hansard. Senator Baume said 'divisions'.
—Yes, that is right; eight out of 10 divisions.

—But the advertisement does not give the number of votes in that period. The record will show that there were something like 2,500 votes in this chamber and on about 100 of them we voted with the Labor Party. On 2,400, the Democrats supported the Government. Out of that set of statistics, we get this filth, this lie, printed by the Liberal Party, authorised by the Liberal Party, on which the Liberals won the fifth Senate seat in Western Australia by a handful of votes-100 or 200 votes. That is why it is important for Senator Baume, Mr Newman and Mr Fraser to cheer the High Court judgment. The High Court judgment has preserved the right of the Liberal Party or any other party which has unlimited funds-non-disclosable unlimited funds-to hire the slickest advertising agency in the business to tell the most outrageous lies in the most clever and despicable form. That is the big danger of this High Court judgment. The High Court has made the strictest possible interpretation of section 161 (e).

SPEECH.PARA: What did the High Court say those words in paragraph (e) mean? Why did the High Court not say that that advertisement was a lie, an untrue statement and that it did mislead? Why did the High Court not find that this advertisement which I have just read out improperly interfered with an elector in or in relation to the casting of his vote? The reason is that the High Court says it does not matter how much one lies, it does not matter how much one interferes with an elector in the forming of his judgment on how to vote. The High Court has said that this section simply means interfering with the physical casting of a person's vote. If one were to put out a how-to-vote card with the words: 'Vote Australian Labor Party-Don Chipp No. 1' that would be the mischief caught by this section. Some kind of action like that would contravene the section. In other words, the High Court has taken an extraordinary interpretation of simple words and has said that the words in this section mean interference with an elector actually recording his vote, that is, going into the polling booth with a pencil and putting numbers in squares rather than the formation of a judgment on how he or she is to vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the literal translation which the High Court favours.
—If Senator Missen wants to call that liberal-did he say 'liberal' or 'literal'?
—'Literal'; I don't favour it but I say that is what it is.

—It certainly is literal. I thank you for your indigestion-I am sorry, your interjection. It is the High Court that gives me indigestion, not Senator Missen. The Court's view is obviously far too narrow and unduly legalistic. There is no real chance that any elector can be genuinely interfered with in the physical process of casting his vote. As the Canberra Times in a magnificent editorial yesterday correctly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The obtaining and marking and depositing of papers in the ballot box is entirely presided over by employees of the electoral office.

They are capable employees, as Senator Baume says, and dedicated employees. There is no chance that an elector can be interfered with in the mechanical process of the casting of his vote. The judgment has dealt a severe and heavy blow to Australians who wanted to see a return to clean and honest election campaigning. No one denies that campaigns have been tough in the past and will be in the future, but the amount of misrepresentation and outright lying achieved in the 1980 election by the Government parties in particular was completely unprecedented. The High Court has effectively said by its judgment that in future it will be highly desirable, if not essential, for political parties to lie their heads off in order to gain votes. A party which sticks to the truth will find itself at a savage disadvantage. In the name of freedom of speech-I almost felt sick when I read the High Court judgment-the High Court has given its stamp of approval to future election campaigns in which unfettered lying will be the order of the day. Instead of preserving freedom of speech, the High Court gave political parties the legal freedom to spread the most mischievous and malicious lies about each other. It was rather quaint that the High Court at least had the conscience to include in its judgment a statement by Mr Justice Isaacs. Senator Baume quoted a Solicitor-General. I will quote a statement by Mr Justice Isaacs which was incorporated in the judgment. He said:

The vote of every elector is a matter of concern to the whole Commonwealth and all are interested in endeavouring to secure not merely that the vote shall be formally recorded in accordance with the opinion which the voter actually holds, free from intimidation, coercion, and bribery--
I emphasise the next portion of Mr Justice Isaacs' quote-

but that the voter shall not be led by misrepresentation or concealment of any material circumstance into forming and consequently registering a political judgment different from that which he would have formed and registered had he known the real circumstances.

The High Court has the gall to say: 'We hold that as a general principle', and then to give a judgment that goes 180 degrees against that sort of principle. It says: 'That is a fine principle; people should not be misled by untrue advertising; but we must preserve the freedom of speech at all costs.' What rot! What hypocrisy!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not want to interfere with Senator Chipp's speech as I understand that it is quite in order to comment on the judgment of the High Court, but when he says, 'What hypocrisy', I think that he is getting close to making a suggestion about the judges themselves.
—Is there a Standing Order to that effect?
—It is a matter of usage and custom.
—Order! Senator Chipp, there is an imputation there against the High Court judges. I ask you to withdraw that imputation.

—I have absolutely no intention of withdrawing the remark I made. I said that the judgment itself, which states that the electors should not be misled and which then turns around and makes a finding 180 degrees in the opposite direction, is a judgment ranking in hypocrisy. The judgment is hypocritical.
—Providing you are not impugning the integrity of the judges, you may proceed.

—I will leave it for you or anyone else to make that judgment, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will not resile one inch from what I have said about the judgment made by the High Court. The High Court, by this judgment, has not given freedom of speech; it has given freedom to lie. From now on it is open season and the party with the most money and the most able to tell lies will win the elections. The Melbourne Age of 20 March described as spurious Mr Newman's suggestion that laws to counter the effect of the High Court's judgment might inhibit free speech. If Senator Baume and Senator Martin, who will follow me in this debate, are suggesting that it might limit free speech if one stops politicians from telling lies in election campaigns, why not go the full shot? Why not abolish the laws of defamation or libel? The fact that one cannot say what one likes about a person certainly limits free speech. Why not do away with the laws of libel? I think that exposes the hypocrisy of any person who holds that view. The Court's decision has given the green light to any of the weirdos or the manic or subversive groups who want to interfere in Australian elections. Provided they have the money to hire some slick advertising firm to take out full page newspaper advertisements at the last moment and book all available space, thereby not allowing other political parties to reply, they can do anything they want. I will say-if it is necessary for me to withdraw this I will, but I do not think it is beyond the bounds of where I should go-that the few vestiges of respect I had for the seven men of this institution have now totally disappeared.

SPEECH.PARA: In taking our petition to the High Court we thought we were performing a public service. This matter had never been tested in the High Court. The only thing in evidence, other than Mr Justice Isaacs' admonition for purity in elections and decency, was a 60-year-old opinion of a Solicitor-General. It was not a frivolous or vexatious legal challenge. Even the Liberal Party had similar--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in the debate on this matter of public importance, namely, the alleged inadequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising. I would be the first to admit that this sort of discussion is a discussion of prime importance in any true democracy. As Senator Baume said earlier, Australia has the honour of being one of the world's few real democracies. Before I concentrate on the few remarks I intend to make referable to this matter, I must say that Senator Chipp delivered a somewhat emotional speech, which is not unusual for him. He began with the suggestion that Senator Baume, who led in this debate for the Government, had been defending the right to lie.

SPEECH.PARA: I take objection to that. I do not believe that anyone on this side of the Senate chamber or, indeed, on the other side of the Senate chamber would want to defend the right to lie. I believe that that is a totally unfortunate and irresponsible statement to make. Indeed, there are many tens of thousands of Australians who spent the years between 1939 and 1945 defending the sort of society we live in against a circumstance that had been built out of a legacy of lies. I hope that in future Senator Chipp and those who think along his lines will pay a little bit more attention to what they are implying when they suggest that A, B or C is defending the right to lie.

I would have thought that Senator Chipp and his party had done extremely well out of the electoral system he now abuses. I am quite surprised that he should be so abusive of a system in which he finds himself, for good or for ill, likely to be in significant control of the government of this country. That is quite a system. His party received 6 per cent of the votes and has five members of the total of 180 odd for the two Houses and yet he can control the Government. Indeed, in justification of the existence of that sort of circumstance, Senator Chipp and the men he leads will have a magnificent opportunity to vindicate the enormous responsibility they hold by still aligning themselves with the Government as against the Opposition in the proportion, I believe he said, of something like 2,400 to 100. If that is so, the post-July period will be a fine opportunity for Senator Chipp to prove the sort of responsibility that I know he will be so anxious to prove.

There is no doubt that however far we may range in this discussion this afternoon, the catalyst of this proposition was the turning out by the High Court of Australia of the petitions of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party to the High Court relating to misleading election advertisements. It is worthy to recall that that decision was unusual in that it was a unanimous decision-seven to nil-and that it included, of course, at least one justice who had significant experience in the political field and consequently in the field of political advertisements and in the promotion of political ideologies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you give his judgments the same respect in other matters.

—Yes, I certainly shall give his judgment that respect. I thought it was worthy of comment that he should have seen fit to have come to the conclusions that he did. I suggest to the Senate this afternoon that we are making a little too much of this proposition. Unfair and unrealistic emphasis is being placed on political advertisement. But I believe that the Australian people are a practical people and that the judgment observed this fact. I believe that the Australian people are interested in basic political, philosophical positions and that they will not be taken one way or another by a lot of gimmicks. They will not be side tracked down this way or that because of an unfortunate tendency, wilful or not, in the presentation of a matter. If the sort of thing we are talking about this afternoon were to resolve itself and there was a massive attempt to make a lot of tight, legal bands to control political advertisement then election results might be found in the judgment and jurisdiction of the courts, rather than in the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the very meaning of a democracy is that the decisions are made by the people and not by the courts. I suggest that it is almost impossible for this Government, or for any government, to devise sets of rules which are so watertight and so neat, that they can clearly define those areas which, in the promotion of a political party and philosophy, are unfair or untrue. So many things can be taken out of context and so many things can be distorted that the law that would control this would cover an inestimable measure of paper and be subject to goodness knows how many interpretations. So conceivably there could be an almost impossible situation in which election results were constantly before the courts and in which the people might well ask themselves whether they had any capacity to make a decision. To design laws to prevent misinterpretation may be a total impossibility and an impingement, in the final resort, on freedom of speech which is one of the basic elements of the society in which we live.

Also, of course, it is a fact that in a democracy like Australia there are an enormous variety of issues in an election campaign. As one moves from one area to another naturally different emphases are placed on different elements of that situation. Senator Baume has referred to controlling the sale of soap. He suggested that no similarity existed between that and selling a political philosophy. I reiterate that circumstance. We are not selling toothpaste; we are selling a political philosophy and to bind that down by a lot of tightly conceived laws is a virtual impossibility. I think that Australians would recognise-certainly I recognise-that they have the capacity to determine the credibility of this or that policy. Surely that is the very basis of the educational system in which we grow. Not only is it to develop a measure of technical excellence, and to produce engineers, lawyers and doctors but also hopefully, it is to produce people who have a desire and a capacity to amass and analyse facts and to come to logical conclusions. If that is the objective and the ulitmate result of education, then we do not have to fear the capacity of Australians to analyse the propositions that are put in front of them. I believe it is very little less than an insult to the intelligence of the average Australian to suggest that a whole embroidering of tiny, minute legal situations should be developed to control the way in which a philosophy is put to the people in the political circumstance of an election.

The media in this country is another safeguard against distortion. It is, of course, not always responsible and not always totally constructive in its attitude to many things but at least it creates an inquisitiveness in the Australian community which is in itself a very great safeguard. In this circumstance I think we might well remember that point. I am not entirely certain whether this debate has been engendered by hysterical reaction to a court decision, whether it is a sour grapes situation or whether it is, as I hope, a genuine attempt to indentify a need to look constantly and consistently at the electoral system and at the Act under which we operate. If that is the program then the Government has, at this time, that very matter of analysing the Commonwealth Electoral Act in hand.

So far as I can ascertain there are no provisions for controlling misleading advertisements in a political circumstance in countries such as Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom or the United States of America. It has been suggested that some advertisements in some States were misleading, but at this stage I will not enter into whether or not that is so. I merely suggest that that sort of misleading circumstance is one of which the socialist parties are certainly guilty. For instance, Mr Hayden as Leader of the Labor Party at the last election, said on 5 October that, quite clearly, by mid-1981 the price of petrol would be 45c a litre. On 6 October, the next day, he said that by the end of the year inflation would be about 12 or 13 per cent. In fact it was 9.1 per cent. Are we to regard that as dishonest or misleading? I think that the electorate would have analysed that suggestion and come to some very sensible conclusions. In mid-October, on two days running, in relation to the unemployment situation, he made the rather extraordinary claim that by the New Year half a million people in Australia would be unemployed. That proved to be an insufficient stab and the next day he said that one million people in Australia would be unemployed. If we look at the sort of circumstances that have been promoted by the socialist parties, it can be suggested that there has been a real measure of distortion. I conclude on this point-The sense of the Australian community is such that it can analyse and does analyse the situations that arise.
