TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to correct a misstatement that I made in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the course of my remarks I said that during the last three years about 2,500 decisions of this Senate were taken without division. The correct figure is 8,152.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the inadequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising. It is a big topic, but I focus solely on the nature and extent of the problem of dishonest and misleading advertising and what might be done about it. In that respect I will follow the example set by Senator Chipp, but in deference to the sensitivities of Senator Scott, and no doubt because of my own more desiccated legal personality, I will be a little less emotional in the way I put the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the problem of deception in political advertising is big and getting bigger. Politicians of all kinds are rarely averse to stretching and bending the truth to suit their party advantage. That fact must be acknowledged. It must also be acknowledged that election campaigns are never chivalrous affairs. But I believe that it has only really been during the 1977 election campaign, and in particular the 1980 campaign, that the technique of the 'Big Lie' can be said to have become, at least for one side of politics, the political norm. There have been many examples of this phenomenon. Some of them have been canvassed by Senator Chipp, others by Senator Gietzelt. But I believe that the most clear cut and absolutely unarguable example of this phenomenon, and also unquestionably the most politically devastating in its effect on the ground, was the wealth tax advertisements with which the Liberal Party peppered the media, especially the print media, in which it outspent the Australian Labor Party by at least 30 to 1, on our estimates, during the last federal election campaign. The particular statements that were contained in the most familiar of these advertisements are describable in no other terms than those that I have used. One such advertisement states:
Labor's 'Wealth' Tax threatens the unwealthy family.

Labor is committed to a new tax which would hit middle-income earners just as violently as the wealthy. This so-called 'Wealth' tax would steal the savings of people who, through superannuation, insurance policies and small investments, have attempted to provide for their old age or their children.
The advertisement states further:
If you sell your house to buy another, even if your house has only increased by the value of inflation, then you would pay a Capital Gains Tax on that.

This is an absolutely unambiguous example of the blatantly dishonest political lie. In an editorial in the Australian of 19 March it was stated that in politics there is no such thing as the absolute truth. That may be so, but in politics there is such a thing as an absolute unambiguous lie. The advertisement from which I have quoted is a classic example. The truth of the matter-this needs to be put on record because there is still some misunderstanding about it-is that the commitment, if there is any, written in the 1979 federal platform of the Labor Party is in quite different terms. It states that the party's commitment is to:

Enhance the equity of the tax system by taxing large accumulations of personal capital above a floor level that is reviewed regularly and takes into account the special circumstances of farmers, small businessmen and aged people, and excludes the normal holdings assembled over a lifetime by persons and family units.

That is a very different proposition, which speaks for itself, from that advanced in the text of that advertisement. Moreover, during the course of that campaign, in the series of statements and announcements of the actual election platform on which we were fighting and which would govern our actual behaviour, and which commitments in the platform we would introduce over the life of this Parliament, there were, of course, numerous statements from the leader of the Labor Party that we would not introduce in the life of this Parliament a wealth tax in any form whatsoever because, among other things, we saw the necessity for data to be gathered and equity considerations to be pondered by an appropriate commission or committee of inquiry. No one was in any doubt as to the foundations, in terms of the truth or lack of it, of that particular Liberal Party advertisement. In an editorial in the Age of 14 October it was stated:
. . . there is no excuse for outright dishonesty in election advertising and speeches.
and
These advertisements . . . are unworthy of a party seeking to govern the country.
On the same day in the Australian Financial Review it was stated:
It--
That is, the Government-
has attempted to pin on the Labor Party proposals which it simply is not putting forward . . .

I dwell on these matters because I think it is important to appreciate when we are debating this topic the nature of the claims that we are making about what needs to be curbed in the public interest. We are not talking about statements of belief, opinion or intention; we are talking about statements of fact which are demonstrably untrue. This advertisement is just one example of them.

The question before us is whether the present law is adequate or inadequate to deal with misstatements of this kind. In short, the position is that the law is simply not adequate. That much was amply revealed in the context of section 161(e) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act by the High Court decision a few days ago. Unlike Senator Chipp, I do not impugn the High Court for that decision. I happen to think that it was correct as a matter of law. The decision was that because of the way in which that particular section was drafted, it had no application to advertisements designed to influence a voter's choice as between parties and candidates, and that the only application it had was to advertisements designed to mislead voters in giving effect to that judgment or choice-in the way in which they recorded their vote when it came to the business of voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp says that the Western Australians fall within that narrow definition.

—He may do so. That is a matter for argument. On my own analysis of the Court's decision, I think it was probably right in reaching the conclusion it did, not on the basis of a consideration of the actual advertisements put before it by either the Labor Party or the Australian Democrats, but simply as an abstract question of law. But the significance of this decision is to point up what is a spectacular vacuum in the law as a result of that, I think legitimate, interpretation. The vacuum is partly filled, perhaps, by section 52 of the Trade Practices Act which has some application to misleading or deceptive advertising but only when it is at the instance of corporations which, of course, political parties usually are not, and only when it is in the course of trade or commerce. That means that advertising agencies or media corporations could themselves be liable for publishing misleading political advertisements. But there are other defences in the Trade Practices Act, and it is obvious that this is not a terribly satisfactory vehicle for any direct attack on the real root cause of the malaise-that is, the activities of the political parties which sponsor this misleading nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, the law on libel, which is often called in aid in this sort of debate, is simply not appropriate, not apt to deal with what can be described as advertisements impugning the integrity of, or misstating questions of fact in relation to, political parties or groups of people as distinct from particular individuals. The libel law does have a particular application when it is individuals who are misquoted or misrepresented but it does not usually apply to political parties or larger groups as a whole.

The big question to which I think we have to address ourselves-it has been raised over and over again in the Government senators' remarks-is not just whether there is a gap in the law, because I think that would be acknowledged, but rather whether there should be a law at all in this area and, if so, of what kind. Of course, the Fraser Government-the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), his ministerial echo, Mr Newman and his various acolytes who have spoken here today all say no. They call in aid the principle of free speech. They say that that principle is entitled to be given and especially robust application in the political context. They also call in aid the intelligence of the Australian voter, who they say is perfectly able to distinguish between truth and falsity in political advertising. Indeed, they say, it is an insult to the intelligence of the voter to suggest otherwise.

It is not surprising that the Fraser Government feels rather self-satisfied, even smug, on this issue. It is no wonder that Senator Peter Baume and Senator Scott find it convenient to accuse the Opposition of sour grapes on this question when one considers that the conservative parties are able to outspend their opponents by about three and one-half to one and that in the process they have demonstrated that they have only about one-tenth of the scruples of their opponents. When they have had a successful election result by applying those particular tactics and expenditure, they are not likely to acknowledge in this forum or any other that there are very many deficiencies in the electoral system.

But their protestations in principle, of the kind I have mentioned, ring rather hollow. Free speech, for one, has never been regarded as an absolute value any more than civil liberty values such as freedom of assembly have been regarded as absolute and unqualified by any other consideration. The High Court of Australia said in the James case in 1936, for example, that free speech does not mean absolute free speech; it means free speech qualified by considerations of the law of defamation, sedition and matters of that kind. The law of fraud is another obvious example that springs to mind. As the Age put it rather succinctly in its editorial recently, there is no threat to free speech here. The only people to be threatened are those who resort to trickery and lies to get their votes.

Similarly, I do not see any legitimate ground for saying that consumer protection principles which are acknowledged to be appropriate elsewhere are inappropriate or indeed insulting to be talked about in this context. The truth of the matter is that sophisticated advertising packaging can mislead not only the gullible and the naive but also those of ordinary or above average intelligence and information. That is particularly the case when one side is able to saturate media outlets completely with its particular point of view. I make the further point that the absence of law in this area does not mean that there will be in fact an absence of regulation. One of the phenomena that we have had to contend with in the past is that even without going to court there has been the question of media proprietors themselves imposing their own often rather double standards on the advertisements submitted to them. I think in particular in this respect of Mr Murdoch who in 1975 demanded the withdrawal of a series of Labor Party advertisements. One stated: 'We know that a Liberal Government will dismantle Medibank. What about the things we don't know?'. Another read: 'We know the Liberals are going to dismantle the Australian Legal Aid Office. What about the things we don't know?'. We were forced to withdraw those advertisements until we could produce detailed documentation to support those assertions. It is not treatment, I suspect, which was meted out to the Liberals in the context of their wealth tax advertisements of the last campaign.

The question is not whether there should be some kind of law. I think that is unarguable. The really difficult question is what kind of law there should be in this area. In the very short time available to me, I have no more opportunity here and now than to offer anything more than a simple checklist of what I would regard as the relevant elements in an appropriate law in this area. I suggest five such elements as a basis for future debates, and there will be future debate on this topic. In the first place I think any such law should be confined in its operation to the pre-election campaign period. A breach of the prohibition should enable an action to be taken in the course of the campaign to stop dishonest advertisements-but not after the votes are in. That is mainly for practical reasons relating to the management of this kind of litigation which were I think at the heart of the recent High Court decision in the section 161 case. The difficulty here lies in testing the truth of the assertion that the effect of an advertisement was to influence 600, 900 or 300 votes, as the case may be. That is-I think I agree with Senator Peter Baume's suggestions to this effect-an almost impossible task. I do not think that is an appropriate business for the courts to be looking at. So, the law should be confined to the pre-election period.

The second point is that the prohibition should operate only against advertisements and those in the electronic media as well as the print media; there is uncertainty in some of these areas at the moment. It certainly should not apply to speeches, comments and statements of the kind that are delivered in the course of a campaign by politicians and reported as such. Thirdly, the prohibition should apply only to statements of fact and not to statements of belief, opinion or intention. It should apply to those statements of fact which are untrue or incorrect and are intended, or likely, to mislead or deceive voters. The fourth point is that the enforcement mechanism should be by way of injunction, if court orders are necessary to stop offensive advertisements in this way, or orders to compel the publication of corrective advertisements. A further appropriate remedy might be a declaration by the court or tribunal in question as to what is or is not permissible, a declaration which might be sought by media proprietors in advance when they are uncertain as to the propriety of a particular advertisement.

Finally, while to the extent that judicial orders might be necessary in particular cases, and might be constitutionally required if judicial-type orders like injunctions are to be made, and while the federal court to that extent should have some jurisdiction in this area, I believe that there ought to be a permanent electoral commission which would have the basic task of making determinations in this area, a commission with a composition agreed upon by all parties, as Senator Gietzelt and others have said, and which might, in addition, have a series of other functions in relation to public funding and disclosure in election campaigns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition this afternoon has raised in the Senate as a matter of public importance the question of the adequacy of the law relating to political campaigning and advertising. I think the debate has been very valuable for a number of reasons. It has enabled the airing of a number of issues and I think it has given us all an opportunity to put our view on a very wide number of topics. It has also been revealing by showing the attitude of some of the speakers. A large number of subjects has been covered. Senator Evans confined himself virtually to the subject of misleading advertising, but a number of other issues have been raised by speakers and notably by Senator Gietzelt who proposed for discussion this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt's speech raises a number of questions as to intentions and what is desirable in political campaigning and advertising. I would like to move, in the limited time available to speakers in a debate such as this, through a number of the points that were raised. I will try to cover as many of them as I can. It is not possible to cover all of them. It is certainly not possible to cover, in detail, the five points raised by Senator Evans, the immediately previous speaker, in just two minutes at the end of his 15 minute speech. Therefore, if I do not address myself to all of the issues he raised it is not that they cannot be debated or there is not some value in debating them and in looking for what might be positive aspects; it is simply that he raised so many points so quickly that time will not permit for them all to be dealt with. That is not to say that there is not something to be said about them.

I would like to deal first of all not with the subject of misleading advertising but with two other major isues which were raised initially by Senator Gietzelt. I shall come to the subject of misleading advertising later. The two major issues raised by Senator Gietzelt related to the establishment for certain purposes of a joint parliamentary committee on electoral reform and to the subject of disclosure of donations to political campaigns. Senator Gietzelt was very critical of the Government for not having set up a joint committee on electoral reform in view of the fact that it is known and has been announced by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) that a comprehensive review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act is currently under way. One hopes it is nearing completion. A joint committee is one way of reviewing the situation. It is always the prerogative of the Government to move to review any sort of Act including an electoral Act. I have to admit to some disquiet and a little jaundice in my views on what Senator Gietzelt proposed. Firstly, Senator Gietzelt was a member of a Labor government for three years. I do not recall his advocating when his party was in government that it ought to set up a joint committee in which members on both sides would have the opportunity to comment on electoral reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I did.

—Thank you, Senator. I am not suggesting nobody did. I am suggesting that Senator Gietzelt, who thinks that it is such a good idea today and that somehow this Government is reprehensible for not setting up such a committee, had an opportunity which he did not choose to rise to. The fact is that the Labor Party's actions on this matter are not very good. I refer to the New South Wales Labor Government's activities on the subject of inquiries by parliamentary committees. A joint committee was set up by the New South Wales Parliament to conduct an inquiry into the public funding of election campaigns. Its terms of reference were pre-emptive. The terms of reference were:

SPEECH.PARA: To inquire into and make recommendations on the introduction of a system involving public funding of campaigns for elections to the Partliament of New South Wales.

As has already been mentioned by a previous speaker, the Opposition in the New South Wales Parliament initially participated in, but eventually boycotted, the sittings of that joint parliamentary committee set up by the Labor Government because the terms of reference were being interpreted by the committee as a means of determining the type of scheme that should be set up and not whether such a scheme should be set up. In fact, there is evidence in the form of public opinion polls that there are massive objections by the public to public funding of election campaigns. The latest Australia-wide gallup poll on this subject showed that 70 per cent of those interviewed opposed public funding of election campaigns. In New South Wales 71 per cent opposed it.

Nevertheless that parliamentary committee has now reported, having conducted what the Opposition in New South Wales alleged was a biased inquiry. The Wran Government has announced that it intends to legislate, regardless of public opinion on that subject. So Senator Gietzelt's protestations, as a Labor senator from New South Wales, on the subject of how public opinion ought to be being sought through joint committees ring a little hollow. His own party's performance on the issue in both the federal sphere and the State sphere is not good. I think that must be the kindest comment one can make.

On the subject of the disclosure of donations, Senator Gietzelt did indeed wax loquacious and make some dramatic statements. He certainly conveyed to the Senate, and I am sure to anyone who was listening to his speech, the feeling that he considered this to be a very important matter and that donations should be disclosed. He referred to scandals-that was his word-in other countries, such as Italy and Japan, that have been brought to light because of a link between funding of political parties at election campaigns and policies pursued by governments in office. I must admit that at that stage I was waiting to hear about an Australian scandal.

Senator Gietzelt said that we would be foolish to believe that the fact that private individuals, groups and so on can donate to political parties and political campaigns does not lead to corruption in Australia. He said that he knew of some instances but, unfortunately, could not prove them. He raised one issue that he said he knew had happened. Unfortunately, he could not produce the proof. Of course, one always has to treat with some discretion the raising of issues under parliamentary privilege in the Senate on matters one knows but cannot prove. One would be making an allegation one cannot substantiate. On occasions there may be good reasons for using parliamentary privilege but the use of parliamentary privilege should be treated with caution.

What was this enormous scandal that so agitated Senator Gietzelt and exercised his mind to such a degree? It was the fact that he knows but cannot prove that the Shell oil company used to fund the Australian Democratic Labour Party. That is some scandal! I was shocked and dismayed when I heard that. Really that is not a scandal at all. I do not know about and I certainly could not prove anything in favour of or to the contrary about the funding of the DLP by any oil companies, but it does not amount to a scandal. That was the only example Senator Gietzelt could give. If he claims that there are reasons to believe that private funding of political parties and campaigns in Australia leads to corruption, to use his own words, he ought to substantiate his claims in some way. But even the example he gave in no way goes towards substantiating an allegation of corruption by government in Australia; that is, the donation to a minor political party for whatever reason the donor may have had.

One remembers, however, that the ALP derives a large part of its funds from trade unions. One also remembers a promise made by the ALP to certain trade unions in 1972 when accepting campaign donations not to have penal clauses in industrial legislation. It is up to the ALP to decide whether it is going to be open or secret about what are its promises to trade unions and what sort of favoured treatment it will give to trade unions in general or to a particular trade union when the Labor Party is in government. I do not think anyone who votes for the Labor Party is under any illusions about its close links with the trade union movement. Nobody would be surprised if in general terms it favours the trade union movement in some way. However, it seems that direct promises in relation to campaign funds are not all on one side of the fence.

I think we ought not to be at all shy about the reason for the Labor Party's suggestion that there should be a disclosure of public funding. Of course, this is not necessarily to argue against public funding but we should not be shy about the reason why the Labor Party has done so. Far from uncovering these corruptions that are alleged-not one scintilla, word or even opinion is forwarded to substantiate that allegation of corruption-the Labor Party's aim is to reduce the funds available to the Liberal Party and the National Country Party. The Labor Party is certain of base funding from trade unions. It is known as a trade union party, so it does not have to worry about any sort of connection. The Labor Party is only concerned to make sure that fewer funds are available to other parties. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, in leading for the Government on this subject, pointed out that there are a number of good reasons why one ought to take care on this subject of the disclosure of public donations or proposals for it.

It is clear that there are donors who could face retaliation, threats or harassment on account of campaign gifts. It is also clear that disclosures of names of donors to parties could lead to a substantial decline in voluntary contributions to campaign funds. Some people might just wish to remain anonymous for reasons that are in no way sinister because they like to preserve the anonymity of their own political views. They have to live in the community and they have to live with a variety of people with a variety of beliefs. To force people to declare that they are prepared to make some sort of financial contribution to one party or the other is not a solution to any problem at all. I still remain to be persuaded that the problem exists. Certainly Senator Gietzelt, who was advocating this line most forcibly, did not persuade me that the problem existed.

In the very small amount of time left to me today I will spend some time looking at the subject of misleading advertising and what it is claimed may or may not be able to be done in that regard. Of course, the great difficulty lies in determining what types of amendments could ever take place. The High Court of Australia, in its decision, recognised that some issues are not proper for adjudication by the courts and are matters for adjudication by the electorate. That is the present situation. It is certainly a safe way to leave the matters to the good sense of the Australian people to determine for themselves. What would such an amendment cover? Would it cover facts, opinions and beliefs? Senator Evans said that in his opinion it would not.

I point out to the honourable senator that there was an occasion on which a certain advertisement was used in support of a candidate of his party against Mr Jack Birney, a Liberal member of parliament. All that was necessary was to reprint an extract from Hansard and put a suitable political caption on that extract. People cannot be prevented from showing beliefs, intentions, opinions or whatever in the Parliament. As long as Hansard can be reprinted-it can be reprinted quite freely; I am sure Senator Evans would not want to suggest that it cannot-and can be used in that way one cannot effectively give the safeguard that Senator Evans said he would like to see.

Finally, there were some complaints about the way the Labor Party was dealt with in relation to the wealth tax. I shall run through very quickly some of the public statements that were made over a period by the Labor Party on the subject of capital gains taxes and wealth taxes-subjects about which it was very distressed and about which Senator Evans was so distressed this afternoon-in relation to the last election campaign. In December 1979, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, said:

Unequivocally, I have committed my organisation to a capital gains tax, a resource rental tax, a levy on domestic oil producers, a number of initiatives in the taxation area and other measures of that nature.
In March 1979 he said:
This tax-on 'capital gains'-would be levied on the difference between the amount the asset was bought for and what it was sold for.
In a speech to the National Press Club in March 1979 Mr Hayden said:
We're in the process of refining this proposal, but I say quite bluntly that we won't retreat from it.

Even though further things about inquiries and so on were added, together with what was a clear statement of policy by the Labor Party in relation to capital gains, stated over and over again by key spokesmen of the Labor Party, it was not until the election campaign that they said that the measure to which they were committed would not be introduced before 1983. It is a case of the truth hurting the Labor Party. It did not like the debate on its policies, and it squealed when the Australian people clearly indicated that they did not like the Labor Party's policies. Mr President, the time for debate has concluded, and I therefore move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the previous debate, this Bill is largely uncontroversial, and the Opposition states from the outset that it does not oppose the legislation. However, there are some comments we want to make as there is a difference between the legislation and the views of the Public Works Committee. The Bill seeks to make certain changes to the Public Works Committee Act enabling the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works of the Parliament to undertake a wider range of inquiries. It will also extend the ambit of the Committee to include statutory authorities, with a group of exceptions which are set out in the Bill. I think it is proper that the statutory authorities should come under the jurisdiction of the Public Works Committee Act.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probable that, at least to some extent, works of the National Capital Development Commission could have been brought within the ambit of this Committee for selective inquiry. I am not suggesting that every work carried out by the NCDC should be examined in this way but, given the nature of the Committee's work, some authority ought to be given to it to indicate which works it would like to examine. The NCDC carries out substantial works, and it would not be unreasonable for the Committee to examine such works as it determines. As an example I point to the High Court building in Canberra, which could well have done with some parliamentary scrutiny before it was built. I do not wish to enter the debate about whether it is a good design or a bad design, or even about its location. However, I think it would have been of some value if the Committee had had some input into the project before construction began.

The Bill also extends the Committee's ambit to work overseas but not to overseas aid works, and I am not sure of the wisdom of that. Given that the Committee's work load is extremely heavy, it is probable that it would not be able to carry out inquiries on such aid works. I think we ought to pay tribute to the Public Works Committee because it undertakes with great diligence an onerous task. I am concerned, however, that in respect of overseas constructions the legislation limits scrutiny to that which can be carried out within Australia and does not allow any form of site inspections, even on major projects overseas. In recent years at least two projects were the subject of considerable controversy and extreme expense, and I point to two embassies, one in Tokyo and one in Paris. I saw the embassy in Paris when I was in France some three years ago, and I agree with the comments that considerable improvement could have been effected had a proper scrutiny of the design and construction been carried out and had a site inspection been properly conducted. I am not suggesting, of course, that the whole Committee would necessarily be sent on a jaunt to do that, but means could have been found whereby an inspection team could have been delegated to make the necessary comments upon such a major construction work.

I believe that public scrutiny should be extended, and it is my belief that the Public Works Committee is a valuable mechanism for airing publicly issues of government policy. Far too often the Fraser Government likes to keep things hidden from the Parliament and, most importantly, from the public. In that context I quote from an editorial in the Canberra Times on 13 December 1979, which stated:

The Parliamentary Committee system, whatever governments might think about it, provides the only method by which thorough public scrutiny can be brought to bear on the activities of the Government . . . In committees, Members are able to give the most workmanlike examination of the proposals before them and have the opportunity to examine relevant experts in the fields of inquiry as well as testing the basics of the propositions put before them. Such examinations are among the major guarantees of the electorate that Parliament does not become a mere rubber stamp for the Executive Government.

All of us who have been involved in the committee work of the Parliament would attest to the veracity and importance of that editorial. We want to see more of that work, not less. The hypocrisy of the Government's policy becomes clear when it is realised that, just as the Government is reducing its own expenditure, it is pushing the States into providing massive infrastructure facilities for the resource development that is taking place in Australia. In effect, the Government, while cutting back on its own expenditures, is transferring the economic responsibility to the States at a time when I and the members of the Australian Labor Party believe that a strong central co-ordinating hand is needed. There are grave consequences in the way this is operating.

I now return to the Bill. Another area about which the Opposition is concerned is the ability to exempt certain bodies. I am not saying whether they should be exempt by regulation. I think whether organisations are in fact to be exempt should be spelt out in the Act. The examples given in the notes are Trans-Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd. I wonder whether that ability extends to Australia Post and to Telecom Australia. I draw attention to some activities in that area because organisations and statutory authorities are specifically exempt. We have had debates ad nauseum on industrial disputation in the Parliament. Such disputes are not all caused by pig-headedness or by such other causes to which Government members often refer in parliamentary debates. Some buildings, however, so I am advised, expecially exchanges for Telecom built over recent years, will be, if they are not already, causes of industrial problems. They are built without any consideration of the effect that a lack of proper amenities can have. This is an aspect about which I believe, if we are concerned about improving industrial relations, the Public Works Committee could well have some investigative powers. The most important feature of the Bill is that works undertaken by statutory authorities are, as defined, to come under the jurisdiction of the Public Works Committee. It was obviously an absurd situation that the Government could circumvent a proper parliamentary examination of works progress by setting up a statutory authority. To the extent that we have extended the work of the Committee, that is to be supported.

The other matter I wish to deal with is the Government's rejection of a proposal contained in the latest annual report of the Committee. This proposal-I have discussed this matter with my party's representatives on the Committee-specifically calls for the extension of the powers of the Committee to enable it to inquire into much of the capital expenditure of the Commonwealth Government, especially that of the National Capital Development Commission. The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, or his representative in this place, has a duty to explain in detail the reasons why the Government has rejected this recommendation, as I am led to believe that it was the unanimous view of the Committee. I can see no good reason why the National Capital Development Commission should not be included in the provisions of this Act, as has been proposed by the Public Works Committee. There has been no rational or suitable explanation given to the Parliament, either in the House of Representatives or in the second reading debate in this place. Here in Canberra we have a model developmental project taking place on a continuing basis. It is the only place in Australia where we can say that we have a planned and the best endowed city in the whole of Australia so far as financial resources and technology are concerned. We should be looking at this body very carefully. It should be under the influence and the surveillance of parliamentarians because many other forms of development emulate the pattern set in the Australian Capital Territory. One therefore can wonder why there is this exception to the rule.

Finally, I wish to say a few words about the rejection of the Committee's findings. It is clear that the Committee's recommendations should not be dismissed without reason by the Government. This rejection occurred. I remind the Senate that in respect of the $40m Australian Defence Force Academy, the Committee, again in the non-partisan way in which it operates, was prompted to state that in this case the Government's action 'appears to disregard the Parliament, and indeed appears to attack the basis of the parliamentary committee system'. How pious was the Minister's rhetoric when he spoke in the Parliament when introducing this Bill in the House of Representatives. Honourable senators should bear in mind that I realise that the Minister in this place in fact only restates the original Minister's words.

This legislation continues a policy of strengthening the parliamentary system. The Government has yet to explain why it is prepared to spend some $40m on the Academy against the recommendations of the Committee. I think the Public Works Committee, therefore, should continue to express its views on these matters and try to persuade the Government to its point of view. The Public Works Committee Act therefore should contain a provision to ensure that when a government is inclined to reject recommendations of the Committee full and adequate explanation should be given to both Houses of Parliament. The Public Works Committee has played a valuable role and I hope that role will continue and will be expanded in the future. I hope the Committee can take some consolation from the fact that it has made some progress in persuading the Government to enact this piece of legislation. The Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is dealing with the Public Works Committee Amendment Bill which will introduce many amendments to the Public Works Committee Act. I was pleased to hear Senator Gietzelt say today that he and his party support these amendments, even though he expressed some concern about some areas. I will express concern about some of these areas also. These amendments will give the Public Works Committee greater flexibilty-if I may put it that way-and greater effectiveness than it has had in the past because it will take on a much expanded role with regard to scrutiny of public expenditure and of public projects. This is something which the Public Works Committee has been requesting for quite some time. I commend the Government and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) for at last bringing in amendments to this Act and expanding the activities of the Committee because the Bill will now bring the works of statutory authorities, which in the past were exempt, instrumentalities, and other bodies as well as overseas works into scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I must say that scrutiny of overseas works will be done in Australia. The Committee will be limited to some extent with regard to its inquiries, but nevertheless this limitation upon an inquiry will not adversely affect the Committee in the sense that it will not be able to look at proper expenditure in relation to projects. Perhaps I should give an explanation of the activities and the structure of the Public Works Committee. It is a committee which has been set up for many years within the Federal Parliament. It was established, as I have said earlier, to have public scrutiny and to allow the public to give evidence to the Committee on any projects above a certain costing which were to be established throughout Australia, and until New Guinea became independent it also included Commonwealth expenditure in Papua New Guinea. The Committee is made up of members from both parties of the House of Representatives and likewise of senators from both parties within the Senate. So there is a joint parliamentary committee made up of senators and members of the House of Representatives from the major parties represented in the Federal Parliament.

Senator Gietzelt has said today that the Committee is non-political, and I agree with what he has said. It is a committee made up of politicians, but from the time I have been a member of this Committee I have been impressed by how non-political that Committee has been. There are many occasions on which people from the Opposition may have been opposed to some matters and they have had the support of certain Government members of the Committee. I think one great example of that was in relation to the Australian Defence Force Academy, when, after a long inquiry, the Committee brought down a unanimous decision opposing the establishment of a defence force academy. I mentioned earlier that any projects estimated to cost a certain amount would have to come before the Public Works Committee. In 1969 the ceiling was raised to $2m for any project, but of course with inflation and erosion, today we find many more projects are coming to the Public Works Committee than in the early 1970s. One of these days, with the expanded activities and the limitations of time which the Committee has, it may be necessary to reconsider this $2m figure. I hope that that will not be in the immediate future. Of course, the Committee has been extremely busy in the last two or three years in particular because of the greater number of proposed works which may have cost $1m in the past but which may cost $2m or $3m today.

I am also pleased to see that by this legislation the Minister has given the Public Works Committee some control over another type of expenditure over which scrutiny by the Public Works Committee was by-passed. I refer to projects for which the initial expenditure is less than an estimated $2m but which, because of more and more of the project being phased in over a period, finish up costing well in excess of $2m. Such projects never came under the scrutiny of the Public Works Committee. I am delighted to see that the Minister has made provision for that in the Bill. I quote verbatim from the Minister's second reading speech:

It is understood that the Committee was particularly concerned with cases where major works costing over $2m have been phased in over several years with small projects, that is below $2m. These projects have either escaped committee scrutiny, or if referred to the Committee, have been referred at a stage where proper Committee investigation has been pre-empted by the work already done . . . I have assured the Committee that should it wish to examine any work below $2m the Government would treat any request sympathetically, and would facilitate Committee investigation of any such work.

I agree that that is only an assurance given by a Minister on behalf of a government. I would like to have seen it spelt out clearly in black and white in the legislation. It is one of those very difficult areas because there are occasions when a project starts with an estimated cost of $2m, but within two years, because of circumstances, there may need to be additions to it. To try to cover every aspect in the legislation can cause many mechanical problems. In view of the Minister's statement and with the watchful eye of the Public Works Committee, I hope that when a justifiable request is made to the Minister, he in turn will treat that request sympathetically and facilitate Committee investigations of such work. There has certainly been a need for that in the past.

The question might be raised as to why the Public Works Committee becomes so concerned about the need for scrutiny of certain public works. As a South Australian I can give you, Mr Acting Deputy President, an example of the need for such scrutiny of projects. At present, extensions are being undertaken to the navigational facilities for Adelaide airport, including a new control tower. I knew the area and I knew of the need for a certain type of building. As a member of the Committee, I became very concerned about not only the type of material proposed to be used in the building but also about the design of the building. I raised strong objection to the materials as well as to the design. Fortunately, I had some support from members of the Public Works Committee. I must mention one senator in particular who gave me magnificent support. I refer to Senator Jean Melzer, who stood by me. We fought and we delayed that project for six months before finally the departments agreed that our design was right and that we had every right to stand up for what we thought was the right type of material. I have no regrets about that delay other than wishing the departments had been quicker with their response so that we could have avoided the delay. Our demands were justified, which was clearly seen later. I mentioned that as an aside to give one example of the effect that the Public Works Committee can have upon certain projects. One could give many such examples, but this is not the place to give a history of the Public Works Committee.

I am pleased that the Bill makes reference to statutory authorities, which in the past have avoided public scrutiny. Now many of them will come within the ambit of this legislation. As Senator Gietzelt said, some authorities which are concerned with trade or which compete with private enterprise will be exempted from the provisions of the proposed Act. I accept that. There are reasons for many of the exemptions. Nevertheless, all of those exemptions will still be subject to parliamentary inquiry because they will be made by regulation. The Parliament will still have control over the exemption of any authority. I accept that the Parliament House Construction Authority should be exempted because it has parliamentary representation on it. It is the Authority responsible for the new and permanent parliament house for Australia. I accept that exemption because the Authority has parliamentary input and involves parliamentary responsibility and discussions. But I am concerned that the National Capital Development Commission has been exempted, firstly, because it does not allow for any inquiry by the Canberra community. It does not allow any input whatsoever. I think it essential that the citizens of this fair city should be allowed to have some input into the various projects that are being undertaken in Canberra. I am certain that if that had happened in the past, Canberra would be a much better place today. I am certain that some of the mistakes of the NCDC would not have been made if, firstly, its operations had come under the scrutiny of the Public Works Committee and, secondly, the citizens of this city had been given an opportunity to have their say as to what they thought certain buildings should be and the reasons they should or should not be in certain positions.

I wish to refer now to former Senator Reg Wright. When he was a member of this place he expressed concern that the NCDC saw fit to put a ring road around Capital Hill. Many honourable senators expressed a lot of concern about that. Through the initiative of former Senator Wright, legislation was eventually introduced. We now have what is known as the parliamentary triangle which flows out from the peak of Capital Hill and over which the Parliament has control. Until that legislation was passed, the Parliament had no control; only the NCDC had control. Certain steps were taken only when the scarring for the new road appeared around Capital Hill. Many feared that the road would affect a new parliament house. I am concerned about that aspect although I am aware that new section 6B of the Act will enable the Government to prescribe certain works of the NCDC as public works which will come under the scrutiny of the Public Works Committee. Of course, those works could be very limited, and their scope depends upon what the Minister and the Government see as public works within the ambit of the operations of the NCDC. I think that the assurance given by the Minister in his second reading speech should be read into Hansard. He said:

The Government can assure the House and the Committee that should the Committee wish to examine any specific work of the NCDC, the Government would treat any such request sympathetically and would facilitate Committee investigation of any work.

I am pleased that the Minister was prepared to make that statement which is now recorded in the Hansard record of this Parliament. If there are times when I feel that the Public Works Committee should be inquiring into certain projects, I can assure the Senate that while I am a member of the Committee I will make sure that it makes requests to the Minister to enable it to undertake such an inquiry. If the Minister refuses to give us this facility, I hope there will be enough members of the Public Works Committee prepared to stand in their places and let their displeasure be known. I think there is a need for this Parliament and the people of Canberra to have some say in the building projects taking place. I will not refer to certain buildings in Canberra although I could refer to buildings which I think are very poor. One does not have to go very far from Parliament House into a satellite area to find buildings, not very old, that already are showing rust from reinforcement rods. To me there is a question mark over why such buildings were allowed to be placed as they have been. One questions whether quality control was as strictly adhered to as should have been. I do not know. There has been no inquiry so one can only see the stains on walls. I mention this to express some of my concern.

I mentioned earlier that the Committee can look at overseas projects. While dealing with that matter I will refer to Norfolk Island where the Committee inquired into the proposed new airport. In the terms of this legislation, many of the works on Norfolk Island undertaken by the administration itself will be exempt from this legislation. I agree with that. As is the case with the Government, these administrative bodies should be given responsibility for their own areas. Nevertheless, any of the Commonwealth buildings to be built in those areas will still come under the responsibility of the Federal Parliament and the scrutiny of the Public Works Committee.

I wish to say that I am very pleased also that the Minister has seen fit to include in the legislation power for the Committee to sit in private if it considers that action necessary. I do not like the habit of committees just willy-nilly sitting in private; I think that committees should operate in public as much as possible. But there are occasions when a committee to be fully effective needs to close the doors, even for half an hour, to give witnesses an opportunity to expand on very sensitive subjects. I am glad we had this provision in the Act. I hope that as we go along future public works committees will not abuse this facility but will use it to become more effective. I am concerned that, sometimes, in camera sittings can be counterproductive and detrimental to the full purpose of a committee.

I am very pleased to support this Bill. I am very pleased that the Opposition has given its full support. The Opposition, through Senator Gietzelt today, has expressed some concern at the legislation. Likewise, I express some concern. I myself would have liked to have seen a few more matters included in the legislation. Having said that, I am thankful that at last we have made quite a deal of progress with regard to the powers of the Public Works Committee within this Act. We cannot expect to get everything at once. I only hope that, with the co-operation of the Ministers, the Bill will now allow us to become a more effective committee than was possible in the past because of the limitations under the Act.

It has a very important part to play in the operations of the Parliament itself and in the work which the Parliament is able to do in respect of watching the work of the Executive Government. It is not surprising that both the Opposition and Government senators generally should be in support of the present legislation before the Senate which in fact extends the ambit of the Committee's operation. SPEECH.PARA: I was struck the other night when in committee room 7 by the photographs of the Committee which go back to its very earliest days. In fact, I particularly enjoyed looking at the photograph of the committee of 1967 of which my father was Chairman.
