DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (REDEPLOYMENT AND RETIREMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1981, associated with which is the proposal to disallow a determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or, in the initial instance, of the Public Service Arbitrator. This is yet another piece of Fraser Government legislation dealing with industrial relations. The Government has had many pieces of legislation dealing with industrial relations since it came to power. None of this legislation can be pointed to as having any particular demonstrable success in solving the industrial relations problems of this country. One would have thought that after six years the Government would be able to point to what it might call the milestones in its policy development in an area as important as industrial relations. In this area the Government can only point to a series of tombstones which have made the situation much worse.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government sought to make as an area of importance for its own policy development and was concerned to develop as a bandwagon has in fact turned out to be a hearse. This legislation is yet another example of that fact. I do not want to dwell too much on the funereal analogies which I have drawn today. I wish to point out some of the basic inconsistencies in the Government's attitude on these matters and to indicate the Opposition's strong rejection of the legislation, for some of the reasons I will indicate in detail. I have often said in this place that confusion over industrial relations in the Fraser Government goes back a long way. It has always been recognised by the present Government that there are certain things which are effective in industrial relations. They were described by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) as Leader of the Opposition in 1975. He said:
Our view is that satisfactory industrial relations depend ultimately upon the attitudes of mind of people in industry.
I might say that sort of statement applies to the Australian Public Service as well as anybody else. The Prime Minister then stressed the importance of what he described by stating:

Attitudes of mutual respect, of willingness to listen, to understand, to reason and discuss in an informed way, are essential. These attitudes cannot be created by any party's industrial relations policy.
The Prime Minister is quite right about the latter statement.

What this legislation is all about is who shall determine the salaries and conditions of employment and so on for members of the Australian Public Service. More particularly it questions the legislation as it fits in with the existing Determination 509. It also concerns matters of reallocation of staff and the termination of employment in the Australian Public Service. The question of the termination of employment is always a delicate subject to handle in relation to employee-employer relations. It is a question which should be handled, one would think, with a good deal of sensitivity. However, one of the great tragedies of this Government's industrial relations policy is that in the context of chronic community concern about the tenure of employment, the method of termination of employment and the sort of recommendations contained in the report of the Myer Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, whatever one thinks about the merits of that report in a more general sense and the recommendations which the Committee described as the social safety net recommendations, there is not a chink of light from this Government about its willingness to deal with those issues which are of fundamental importance to employment relations.

No one can argue fairly against the fact that ultimately it is the Government's right to lay down the broad parameters of the way in which the Australian Public Service will be administered and the way in which changes will be made in the Public Service. The sad fact is that very few changes have been made in the Public Service, very few new directions have been given to the Public Service by the Government, and very few new visions, if I may be so bold as to use that word, have been given to the Public Service in respect of the way in which it might perform its work. So there is a sort of vacuum in the whole of the industrial relations scene about, particularly, the question of the termination of employment.

The debate which took place in the House of Representatives centred very much on the attitudes and comments of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), who was responsible for the passage of the Bill. It is interesting to note that what the Minister did in that debate was to pretend that the disallowance, as has happened on this occasion, by the Government of a determination of this kind was something which happened with almost monotonous regularity in Australia and was not a matter to which great importance could be attached. The Minister said that there was a similar disallowance as recently as 1973-more than seven years ago. Clearly if it is in fact seven years since there was a similar disallowance this sort of action is not something which should be taken lightly. In 1973 the then Opposition opposed a four-week annual leave determination which had the support of the government of the time. That piece of enlightenment by an Opposition which in this place sought to be a sort of Bonnie Prince Charlie Government in exile and pass judgment on the existing Government's decisions about those matters has been aborted, as it were, by the passing of events and four weeks leave is now accepted in Australia as a standard for employees generally.

The Minister has cited on several occasions the frequency with which the power to disallow determinations or ordinances has been exercised. It is instructive to look at how often this has in fact been done. It has in fact been done on three occasions since the legislation was enacted-in 1927, in 1929 and in 1932. Those occasions were prior to the incident to which I referred a moment ago. The last time the Government disallowed a determination of an arbitrator was in fact nearly 50 years ago and it was during the Great Depression. There is no doubt about the powers of the Government to take the action but the powers have laid in abeyance unused by governments since the Depression. It is interesting to note that the power to disallow was the subject of a recommendation in the report of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, which is known as the Coombs Commission. Recommendation 245 states that the Government's power to disallow a tribunal's determination should be removed. I take it that the main reason for that recommendation was one of certainty. The report of the Commission states:

Disallowance has occurred on four occasions only and the procedures in meeting the provisions under this section involve an unwarranted use of resources. But, more importantly, it seems to us to be wrong in principle for an arbitration procedure, whether in the public or the private sector, to be qualified in this way and it is at variance with the way arbitration awards are viewed in the private sector where the employer has no right of veto on arbitration awards.

Although recommendation 245 was said in May 1980 to be under consideration by the Government, clearly it is no longer under consideration. What the Royal Commission is really saying is that society is best served by a system which provides some certainty for employees in respect of terms and conditions of employment. In pointing to the private sector it acknowledged, as it has always acknowledged, that an employer has a right of appeal from an arbitral decision to an appeal bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and so on. But the Royal Commission was pointing out that an employer has no power to change the decision of an arbitration tribunal once it has been given. The consequence of what has happened on this occasion is that the employer, the Australian Government, having allowed the matter to go to arbitration, has then said: 'We do not like the decision and we as the employer are going to change that'.

The real issue is not the Government's power to take the action. It clearly has the power and it is clear that the Government could at any time use its numbers in both chambers to disallow an award, for example, by amending legislation, as it is in fact doing in this legislation with a resolution accompanying it from the House of Representatives to disallow Determination No. 503. What really is in issue here is why the Government seeks to overthrow the decision of an arbitrator which the Government supported until it found itself in disagreement with the determination. Once again that goes to a basic question of certainty in relation to the development of a system; certainty in relation to the determination of rights. The Minister sought to justify the Government's view that it could overthrow the decision of an arbitrator-clearly it can; however, with some degree of industrial morality-by saying that the Government's disapproval of the determination must be seen 'against a long history of irresponsible and persistent union activity opposing the CERR Act'-the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. It is extraordinary justification for the Government to say, on the one hand, that because there has been union activity opposed to legislation which the union movement really was not consulted about and does not like and, on the other, because of some quite different action against the substantive legislation, there is reason for rejecting the arbitrator's decision in this matter, as the Government is doing. It is pretty sloppy logic. Union activity in this regard clearly is relevant. The simple fact is that the Government is not disallowing some union determination. It is disallowing the determination of a supposedly independent tribunal; a decision which the union movement clearly accepted and a tribunal which it is usually enjoined to go before. I refer, of course, to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, a body which the Prime Minister has always been keen to refer to as the umpire. Many honourable senators will remember those passionate appeals for 'A fair go in Australia', 'Take your decision to the umpire', 'Come on, Aussie'; and all that sort of stuff which one gets from the Prime Minister from time to time. What happened, of course, was that following union dissatisfaction with existing determinations, in this case and in respect of these matters, the Prime Minister specifically exhorted the unions to go to the umpire. I want to quote to honourable senators what was said in one of his famous Sunday fireside chats in his Address to the Nation on 22 July 1979. He made this great rhetorical appeal:
I again ask all working men and women to stand up for your own rights. You can support arbitration-that is your right. You and your workmates can see that the union also supports arbitration.

There is no need to strike. No need to disrupt work. No need to damage yourselves, your industry or Australia. There is a better way-conciliation and arbitration-the way of the umpire. Australia needs your support.

That is an extraordinarily colourful and flamboyant injunction by the Prime Minister, if I may say so. It is a very eloquent expression, if not almost somewhat inflammatory, I suppose one could say. The slogan, of course, is: 'Do not strike. Go to the umpire'. But, in this case, sad to relate to people who may be asked to listen to those sorts of words again from the Prime Minister, when the umpire gives its verdict the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs say that the tribunal's determination is no good because of union activity and therefore has to be rejected. So, if I can put it in simple terms, which an old footballer like Senator Bonner who is sitting over there will understand, you play a game, play it according to the rules, the umpire gives a decision and then, if I may use a colloquialism, you drop him. That is precisely what has happened in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was like the Olympic Games.

—Indeed, Senator. Let me put it this way: The considered deliberations of an independent and highly respected body, deliberations which took place over 31 days of proceedings and producing 1,500 pages of transcript before the Arbitrator, are overturned summarily because the Government does not like the decision, because of the Government's reaction to the union claims.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's expressed rationale for disallowing Determination No. 503 and for removing power from the Public Service Arbitrator to make determinations under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act is simply to be found in the Prime Minister's words. Determination 503, he says, has the effect of altering Parliament's intention. I must say that Parliament's intention when the Act was passed was pretty vague on the particular subject matters involved. Of course the Senate will recall the very long time which elapsed before it was indicated by proclaiming the legislation that Parliament had any intention at all. As I said, the view of the Prime Minister is that the determination had the effect of altering Parliament's intention. The Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-the umpire; the Prime Minister's umpire-considered this point at some length. The Public Service Board put the same submission to the Commission as the Prime Minister made in his defence of subsequent actions. It argued that union claims would render inoperable the Act's intentions. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission rejected the arguments, as set out on page 8 of its decision, and said that the Determination would 'not be out of accord with the redeployment and retirement Act'. Not only are the Commissioners the umpires but also they are the experts in some ways.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I had been speaking about the disallowance by the Government of the determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission relating to the Public Service. The point I had been making was that although the Government clearly has power to disallow determinations it is a power which has been very infrequently exercised in the past. But that is not the issue. To blame the disallowance of this particular determination-that is, by this piece of legislation-effectively on trade union activity generally, as if one can deliver a particular punishment in respect of conduct generally which one does not like, is spectacularly wide of the issue. What is at stake, of course, in these proceedings and in relation to the Government's action, is the question of the credibility of the Arbitration Commission as an effective agent for setting standards and having the confidence of both parties which appear before it in an industrial dispute situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I put it in these terms, that if one believes that the Arbitration Commission is not a credible agent for resolving disputes of this kind, then the parties to a dispute can appear before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for many days in order to get a solution to a dispute and say: 'Well, we don't like the decision, so we will get rid of it'. That is not the way to deal with the general issue of the credibility of an Arbitration Commission decision. The real way in which a Government should handle this matter is to grasp the nettle and say: 'We do not believe that these sorts of proceedings are appropriate'. In a sense, of course, it has said that in respect of this particular matter, but the way in which it is being handled is by an attack on the whole system of arbitration which is something the Government so consistently seeks to uphold.

The confidence in that system is undermined when there is no commitment from the Government to the rulings of the Arbitration Commission in relation to the Public Service. Once again, the adventures of the Prime Minister in the area of political philosophy which were displayed in December last year stand in ironic contrast to his actions in respect of this matter. I repeat that the Prime Minister believes that society is healthier when responsibility, enterprise and power has spread widely throughout the community rather than concentrated in one or a few places. So he and this Government support the devolution of authority to an independent umpire in many ways. They support devolution as a matter of Government policy, as I understand it, and certainly that is a matter of much rhetoric in this Parliament. They support the devolution of authority to the Arbitration Commission as an organ to deal with industrial disputes. The tragedy is that the iron fist inside the velvet glove, if I can use that expression, is quick to reveal itself when the Government happens to disagree with the determination of an independent tribunal. We see the reality of the Prime Minister's belief as against the rhetoric when he uses numbers in Parliament to redirect power which has resided undisturbed in an independent tribunal for almost 50 years and redistributes that power back into the hands of the Cabinet. We have heard numerous instances of the sorts of things in which the Government says it believes in relation to these matters. In summary, let me say this, that the action of the Government in relation to this legislation and to the determination undermines the principle of the arbitration system in the sense that it shows that when the principle which is so much espoused does not suit, we can resort to total expediency as a way of getting around the principle. It is an extraordinary proposition for a Government which indulges in so much high sounding waffle about its philosophical commitments to principle.

I shall illustrate this in another way. I think it is unkindly said of Scotsmen that they never let principles interfere with their purse. This Government never lets principles interfere with anything which it particularly wants to do. I said earlier that the whole question relates to purported changes in the Public Service. We, as an Opposition are not against change in the Public Service. There are many things which need to be done with the Australian Public Service in terms of flexibility and the capacity of people to move in and out of the Service to gain fresh experience and fresh insights. There needs to be a capacity for people to move between departments and instrumentalities of the Government. Tragically, none of those things have happened under this Government. Australia is now moving into a period where, more than ever before, there will be demands on the Public Service in terms of rapid social change and rapid change in employment relationships and conditions in the work force such as we have never known before. Great demands will be made on the Public Service in relation to those matters. There is no evidence of the Government having done anything about these questions. Instead of introducing the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) legislation and so on-there is no evidence of this-the Government should be giving serious attention to the questions of portability of superannuation in and out of the Public Service and to questions of flexibility of movement of people within the Public Service and other Government instrumentalities and outside into industry and back again. Very little attention has been given to these most important considerations and very little attention is being given to the matter of introducing methods of voluntary retirement in the Australian Public Service.

I mentioned earlier the Myers Report on Technological Change in Australia. In the view of many people this is not a satisfactory report about that particular question. The one matter in that report which bears close examination in a time of rapid social change and changes in the work force is the notion of the social safety net which the Myers committee discussed at length in terms of provision of adequate pay, severance pay for people who are forced out of work by technological change and so on. None of these issues have been dealt with either in relation to private industry or in relation to the Australian Public Service in respect of which the Government is the responsible employer. These are the sorts of matters one would look for as coming from a Government which was prepared to face the future. When I say 'face the future', I do not mean next week or the next by-election or something of that kind which is what this Government understands by future. I am speaking of the future as the remaining years of this century. These are the things which a Government ought to be doing and ought to be considering rather than the sort of proposal which is before the Senate now.

Finally, may I reiterate that the greatest iniquity, if I can use that very moral term, about this piece of legislation and about the disallowance, is simply that a Government and a Prime Minister can say to people and particularly members of the Australian work force: 'Look, you must not disrupt this country in any way. You must not disrupt this country by strikes and go slow campaigns and things of that kind. What you have to do is to go to the umpire which we are good enough to provide you with. The Arbitration Commission constitutes an umpire. You can go there and get a fair decision which will be in your interests and in the interests of society.' The Government's action in relation to this matter completely negates that principle. What will happen from now on will be similar to the occasion when the Prime Minister gave his pompous advice about going to the umpire, as he did in that famous July 1979 narration. He said:
There is no need . . . to disrupt work. No need to damage yourselves--
A patronising piece of advice, I would have thought-
your industry or Australia. There is a better way-conciliation and arbitration-the way of the umpire. Australia needs your support.

This is high sounding rhetoric, meaning nothing, out of the mouth of a man who, when it suits him, says: 'Look, I am sorry chaps, we do not like the umpire's decision. We are going to upset it.' That is precisely what has happened in relation to this particular matter. It happens to involve members of the Public Service who are employees of the Government in that sense. The fact of the matter is that the principle goes far beyond the Public Service. The principle, as it is developed under this Government, means that people who listen to that sort of advice can have no confidence or trust in it. That is very disrupting and very damaging to the fabric and morale of a society, particularly to the morale of a work force which is so frequently exhorted to work harder in the interests of Australia. That is the problem with the legislation. A basic criticism of it is its fundamental hypocrisy. It is for those reasons that we oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: -Late this afternoon I was not entirely sure whether the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) was totally convinced of what he was promoting, but since the resumption of the debate he has convinced me that he now shares a real conviction in what he is promoting. We are debating the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1981. It is a Bill which relates, as a number of Bills coming through this place do, to an area of industrial relations. As such, it is a Bill of great significance. In this country, if and when we succeed in solving significantly the problems that relate to industrial relations, then and only then will we move towards fulfilling the capacity that we have as Australians-as individuals, as organisations and associations in this country and last, but certainly not least, we will do so in the public and national interest. Until we recognise that the solution to these industrial relations problems and the smooth and co-operative working of industrial relations is basic to the achievement of success for all the people in this country, in some measure we are floundering.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button referred to what he described as the confusion of the Fraser Government in industrial relations. Industrial relations is a difficult and in some measure confused area, but I guess that our predecessors in government had a more disastrous circumstance and achieved probably the greatest measure of industrial unrest in the history of this country. I hasten to say that I am absolutely tired of hearing talk about the level of industrial unrest, regardless of whether that talk comes from honourable senators on this side or on the other side of the chamber. It is about time that we became mature and responsible enough to recognise that the solutions to these problems are of absolute and total importance to all Australians.

I do not believe that this legislation contains anything of great horror or dynamic significance. Its purpose is to remove from the Public Service Arbitrator the power to make determinations in relation to matters covered by the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1979. That power covers determinations which are referable to the administration and the efficiency of the Public Service. I would have thought that that was a matter of interest and concern to all people within and without the Public Service. The catalyst or the starting point of this amendment perhaps came with the move to disallow Determination 503 which the Government believes unnecessarily protracts the working of the administrative process in the Public Service, it unnecessarily complicates a situation for redeployment and retirement which is clearly stated and I believe, as I shall attempt to demonstrate directly, is a reasonably generous and sensible approach to the problem which is relevant above all things to the efficient operation of that Service, a Service which has a long history and a good name in this country.

Determination 503 was considered by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to frustrate the operations and intentions of the Act and since those operations and intentions are relevant to the efficient working of the Public Service, in this case it was seen fit that the Determination should be disallowed. It is not something, as Senator Button has demonstrated, that has been done commonly. It has been done five times since the Commonwealth acquired the power in, I think, 1922. What is the position in regard to redeployment and retirement? What is it all about? In the context of this legislation and in the context of the economy in which it operates, it is about the efficient operation of the Public Service. So it concerns in the first place the public interest. Surely, in the second place, the efficiency of the operation of this Service is in the public interest and it must be in the interest, I believe, of public servants because, after all, we are talking about the effective and efficient expenditure of taxpayers' money. Public servants, like the rest of the community, are significant contributors in the taxation field. It cannot satisfy them any more than it satisfies anyone else in the community to see government expenditure wastefully and ineffectively promoted.

Again, I think we must concern ourselves with the question of merit in the deployment of a service and in the operation of whatever industry or whatever operation that may be. It seems to me totally wrong that mere non-unionism, rather than merit, should be the yardstick, the guideline. It is blatantly impossible to establish the most efficient operation, the most efficient deployment of labour in whatever industry we may be talking of unless we pay full regard to the merit of those people available for and seeking to operate in that industry. One wonders, if merit is not to be considered, what is the position in regard to freedom? What is the meaning of freedom? What is the meaning of the right to work? Senator Hearn, in her initial address in this chamber a short while ago, referred to the basic importance of the right to work. Is the right to work under current circumstances, regulations and awards to be denied without reference to merit but purely on a question of union membership?

I refer to another matter that has arisen in the process of discussion of this legislation-a mischievous area in my view, an area in which Australians tend to describe other Australians in a way that creates the divisiveness which Mr Hawke, amongst others, is constantly talking about and perhaps, whether he knows it or not, is attempting to generate. It is mischievous to describe, as Mr Hawke did in front of this Parliament House some weeks ago, the public servants as second class employees. That is mischievous rubbish. Most Australians would agree with that description. Of course public servants are not second class employees, nor should they be. In fact, circumstances which apply to their engagement and work are in many areas of the economy the envy, rather than the opposite, of Australian working people.

Determination No. 503, the determination which has been disallowed, seeks to give preference to union members. I repeat what I asked earlier: What of merit in this circumstance? What is the relationship of merit to efficiency? Is it not to be considered--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read Determination 503? It doesn't say that at all.
—The honourable senator will have an opportunity to expand on his vast knowledge.
—Yes, I will. I will prove that to you.

—We will be happy to listen to him. There is no shadow of doubt that Determination 503 tends to frustrate and lengthen the process of redeployment and retirement. The very object of the legislation is to allow generous terms of redeployment and retirement to apply in terms of time and remuneration so that the process of increasing the efficiency of the operation is carried out with the least possible damage to those who are directly involved. That is the object of the legislation. This Determination would involve something like 16 months instead of 13 months, at a maximum, and could extend to a significantly longer period-even beyond two years. Quite clearly, that sort of proscrastination, that sort of protraction of the operation, can only help to avoid the establishment of the sort of efficiency that the Government and the Parliament would want to establish and, indeed, that most Australians would want to see established.

SPEECH.PARA: Provisions for warning and appeal, which are basically generous provisions, do exist. After all, surely in this circumstance the Parliament has the right to be and, indeed, should be, the final arbiter in matters of administration. That, and only that, is what this legislation is all about. As I mentioned earlier, the pre-conditions for disapproval have been met. The opinion of the Attorney-General has been obtained. His opinion is that Determination 503 is not in accord with the purpose of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill. Any future change from this point must be effected by legislation. Under this legislation, the Parliament will be, as indeed it must be, the final arbiter in relation to redeployment and retirement in the operation of the Service.

This Bill dates back some years. Similar legislation was introduced in 1976. There intervened not only an election at the end of 1977 but also the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, which concluded with some specific recommendations which have been adopted in this legislation. It is interesting that Mr Paul Munro, who is now the Federal Secretary of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association, was a member of the body that made those recommendations.

I believe that it is worthwhile looking very briefly at what seemed to be the reasonable, fair and, indeed, generous recommendations of Determination No. 509, which remains in the legislation. That determination provides for consultation with relevant organisations on redundancy situations. That consultation is to be continuing, reasonable and responsible. It provides for six or 12 months' notice, during which time an employee remains on full pay, when a permanent office is excess to requirements of the Service. There again, I believe, is an obligation which is reasonable and responsible and which may well be described as generous. I believe that the 12 month period applies to people who have given some 20 years service or are beyond the age of 45 years, and a six months period applies to other permanent employees in the Service. So it can hardly be said that redeployment is a rough, savage or off-the-cuff action when that sort of notice and the maintenance of full pay are a pre-requisite of any action at all in that regard.

The Public Service Board is requested continually to redeploy excess staff. That in itself makes the whole operation more gentle-a continuing or gradual circumstance. I believe that that is as it should be. That provision is written into Determination 509, which remains part of the Act. The object of that determination, as indeed it should be, is to minimise the measure of disruption that may occur when, for all sorts of good reasons, people have to be moved to other jobs or other places or even to be retired totally. A further final one month's notice is available to permanent officers who are transferred to a lower level or whose service, for reasons of efficiency or other appropriate and identified reasons, has to be terminated.

The Bill provides for appeals procedures and protection of employees against arbitrary and capricious action. Indeed, so it should. The ACOA sought determinations under the Public Service Arbitration Act to take out of the hands of management its rightful prerogatives for the efficient and economical management of the Public Service as provided under the Public Service Act. It is for that reason alone that we are debating and promoting this legislation at this time. It takes out of the hands of the Government, the Parliament and, in other words, the employer, the right fully to administer its own operation with a view to total efficiency. Of course, those areas of conciliation and arbitration that are referrable to salaries, the length of leave, hours of work and so forth, remain the province of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Much has been said tonight by Senator Button and by others in other places of the decision of the umpire. What fails to be said in this circumstance is that the umpire is the Parliament. In terms of identifying the best and most efficient distribution and administration of the Service, the umpire is the Parliament, the employer, the payer who uses the taxpayers' moneys. This is the umpire. It differs from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which, of course, is the umpire in cases of award wages, salaries, leave and so forth. I believe that there is really a misunderstanding or misinterpretation of that situation.

The Act we are dealing with tonight, plus Determination No. 509, provide, as I believe I have indicated in this short time, fair and just provisions for management and staff. There is a proper measure of appeal, there is a proper gradualism and there is a proper capacity for management to achieve the best possible development or deployment of its work force. The Act also introduced the capacity to retire voluntarily at the age of 55 years. This is a useful contribution to the Public Service system. It enables people with perhaps 25, 30 or even 35 years service to move to other fields of their choice and to have a significant superannuation base at an age at which they are able to look forward to a significant and, I hope, enjoyable and different future.

I conclude my remarks by making one or two comments to try to round off the promotion that I have been observing. I suggest that the question is one of administration, not wages and salaries or industrial matters as such. Consequently, the reference to the umpire becomes inappropriate if it is referred purely and simply, as it often is, to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which of course, is the umpire in the appropriate and apt situations. Members of the Opposition in this chamber and in the House of Representatives are virtually saying that the responsibility for administering the laws of the Parliament should be with the Commission. Surely it is the function of the Parliament to do just that, and that is what this legislation promotes.

Let me briefly sum up the reasons that I believe apply. (Quorum formed). As I was saying as I approached the final remarks that I want to make tonight, this piece of legislation has developed over a long period in consultation with a wide range of people and with a view to the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. Its objective clearly and absolutely is to advance the efficiency of the Public Service. I cannot see how Australians, whether public servants or others, can have any argument at all with that objective. It also seeks to cut out the delay-this is important-in implementing redeployment and retirement with a view to establishing a more efficient organism of the Public Service, and that should be an agreeable situation and a promotion which all Australians would want to follow.

I believe it is proper that the Parliament on behalf of the Australian taxpayers-as I said earlier, public servants are significant amongst the taxpayer group-should be the final arbiter in determining the objectives of the legislation. The possible frustration and distortion of the objectives could be the reason for this piece of legislation being introduced. The terms which apply to appeal provisions are generous and reasonable. In our view public servants are certainly not, as described by Mr Hawke some weeks ago, second class employees; nor should they be. Public servants are far from that. They are significant members of the Australian community. It only tends to increase, to use the word that Mr Hawke and others seem to love, divisiveness to refer continually to public servants as second class employees and, as many people in this country choose to describe those who wish to exercise the right to work, as scabs. If anything is more conducive to divisiveness than that sort of description, I have yet to hear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dole bludger. Try that.
—I would not try anything that the honourable senator suggests.
—The Pommie disease, Mr Sinclair's term.

—My remarks seem to have disturbed some members of this chamber. I do not know whether that is an indication of their approval of the description. I support this piece of legislation. I believe it serves a realistic purpose and it will lead to a gradual and successful operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1981, which is before the Parliament tonight, strikes a blow at the heart of the principles of conciliation and arbitration and undermines the authority of the Public Service Arbitrator, whose position was established by this Parliament to be the umpire in matters with which this Bill deals. The Bill is part and parcel of the Government's policies which slowly but surely are leading to the politicisation of the Public Service. I am gradually coming to the view that it is just not worth wasting words on this Government. I want members of the Government to bear that in mind. I am coming to the belief that, in the issues which matter to this country, apart from the issue of foreign affairs and defence, it is just not worth wasting words on this Government. I say that on behalf of the people who have elected me. Two of the issues upon which those people elected me were: Support for the family, and sensible industrial relations policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Already we have had the promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made in Launceston two days before the election was held that the additional revenues from the oil levy would, from 1 January, be returned to the family. Already we have had procrastination on that matter. On the figures of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that would return $171m in this half year. The money is flowing in the back door but not out the front door. On the other vital issue of sensible industrial relations, it appears that again the Government is just not worth wasting words on. But action is required.

If Government members stay in the chamber long enough I will detail to them what I mean about this legislation. Of course, the test of what they think about this legislation lies in the fact that two quorums have had to be called. Let us see how this legislation strikes a blow at the heart of the principles of conciliation and arbitration and undermines the authority of the Public Service Arbitrator, that is the umpire who has been appointed to deal with these matters. Let us see how it does that. Sub-section (4) of this legislation precludes the making of any determination or award by the Public Service Arbitrator in respect of the important matters of redeployment or compulsory retirement of public servants. As Determination No. 503 of 1980 has been disallowed, Determination No. 509 of 1977 is to be read in conjunction with the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. That is supposed to provide the code which is to be followed in the handling of redundancies and retirement issues. This code will be removed from the arbitration system and will be variable only by legislation. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his second reading speech said:
Its true effect--
That is, the effect of this Bill-

will be that any future change which might be thought necessary to the code of practice and benefits applicable to the situations referred to will have to be brought about by the government of the day by legislation and thus it will, as it should, make the Parliament the ultimate arbiter on matters relating to redeployment, retirement, termination and other aspects covered by the Act and Determination No. 509 of 1977.

That is a joke. Does any honourable senator say that we ought to be the final arbiters and that we have greater expertise than the umpire who has been appointed to deal with these matters? Of course we do not. Does the legislation take into account the principles of conciliation that should go into discussions on these matters? Of course it does not. Unless we bring the parties before the bar of the Senate, before this chamber, and have the matters thrashed out here the final arbiter means the use of numbers and nothing else. That strikes at the heart of the principles of conciliation and arbitration. These are matters so fundamental to the future of industrial relations in this country that they deserve better treatment than they received in the House of Representatives and that they are receiving in this chamber. We should not be the umpires. We do not have the expertise for that task. Yet this legislation attempts to clothe us with that power. Of course parliament cannot have the power, but this legislation strips the Arbitrator of the power and attempts to give it to us. In reality what will that mean? It will mean giving the power in relation to these fundamental matters of redeployment and retirement to the Public Service Board or to the departments. I will read again from the second reading speech of the Minister in which he states:

An important responsibility of the Parliament and the Government is to ensure that the Public Service Board and departments have the appropriate powers to ensure that the services of staff are used efficiently and effectively.

But this is a matter of employment life and death to a number of public servants. It is the matter of their compulsory retirement. Should that be left solely in the hands of the boss or should that ultimately be left for consideration before an arbitrator and an umpire? I could give many examples but I have only 20 minutes to deal with this whole matter. I will again read from the Minister's second reading speech. He said:

The Government considers that the provisions of Determination No. 509 of 1977 taken together with the provisions of the legislation are fair, just, adequate and appropriate to protect individuals and to see that they are fairly treated in relation to redeployment and retirement.

Mr President, you and other honourable senators must be convinced that that statement is true before we vote on this legislation. I just question whether that is a factual statement. In fact, it is not a factual statement. It is not adequate to deal with the situation. It certainly is not adequate in the opinion of a number of moderate trade union officials who are experienced in this field. That statement certainly is inadequate when one considers the situation of technological change. In no way is it adequate. I again read from the Minister's speech in which he states:

The Determination requires the Public Service Board to advise the relevant staff association immediately it appears that a surplus staff situation has occurred or is likely to occur, and to provide all relevant details and arrange discussions with union representatives.

Is that so? If it is, so what? That is why I asked Senator Scott whether he had in fact read Determination No. 503. I will guarantee that he has not read Determination No. 509. Let us see what Determination No. 509 says and let us look at these consultative procedures. Of course, what we are doing is accepting Determination No. 509 as being the ultimate guidelines until we change them. The House of Representatives has disallowed the variations to Determination No. 509 considered by the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as being most important and worthy in these circumstances. Clause 3 of Determination No. 509 states:
Where, after the consultation referred to in clause 2 of this Determination the Public Service Board decides that redeployment of any excess staff is not feasible-

Then formal notice of a specified period is given to the officer or employee that he is excess to the requirements of the service. Nobody else but the Public Service Board has any effective final say over whether redeployment is feasible. That is the sort of consultation which takes place. Of course, there is provision in Determination No. 509 for agreements, but if there is no agreement, it is up to the Public Service Board to make the decision. There is a right of appeal, but it is stated that 'the Committee shall report its findings to the Public Service Board with a recommendation for action appropriate to the case'. The Public Service Board does not want that. It can do what it likes with the findings. So Determination No. 509 is not adequate, as is alleged by the Minister, to cover the situation. His statement is certainly less factual than it should have been in the circumstances I have outlined.

I now turn to the fact that these procedures are inadequate for situations of automation and technological change which will be faced in many Public Service departments, where the Public Service Board is the final arbiter, not the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and not the Public Service Arbitrator. That is contrary to the express statement of Ministers for industrial relations-Mr Street, the former Commonwealth Minister, and others-in regard to the question of what should occur when technological change takes place. I refer to the National Labour Consultative Council and other bodies to which the Government was a party, and to my time on the Australian Council of Trade Unions' executive, as far back as Albert Monk's day. There were recommendations by successive Ministers for Labour that when technological change occurred three things ought to happen; there should be notification of future technological change, consultation about it, and, if there is no agreement, reference of the matter to the arbitrator. But what the Government is asking us to do in this legislation is to refuse that last step, to deny to the person who should be redeployed, who possibly could be redeployed because of technological change, or even compulsorily early retired, that last step. That is contrary to everything which Ministers for labour have said over the last 15 years. What has the Government to say about that? Let us have a look at the real reason why the Government has chosen to amend this legislation and has chosen to disallow Determination No. 503 which was recommended by the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I again refer to the Minister's second reading speech in which he said:

This Bill arises in connection with the Government's decision announced on 5 February, the day before the Act was proclaimed to come into operation, that the Government would move to disapprove under section 22 of the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920, Determination No. 503 of 1980.
I also refer to Mr Viner's statement in relation to this Bill which he made in the House of Representatives on 3 March 1981. He said:
. . . my comments in relation to this Bill need to be seen in the context of remarks that I will be making in support of the motion for disallowance of Determination No. 503 of 1980.

So we have to turn to the Minister's remarks made during that debate. We did not have that debate here, honourable senators will recall, because the Government has the numbers in the House of Representatives. This is what the Government really said. After all of the hogwash that went on before, this is what it got down to. Senator Scott really admitted that when he spent so much time on this question of preference for unionists. The Minister said:

The determination establishes preference for union members. Such preference is completely contrary to the objects of the Act and to the principle of merit, a principle which is the cornerstone of the personnel management system of the Service. Preference to union members is quite unacceptable to the Government . . . This Government also rejects the concept of union preference.

That is hypocrisy. In 1977 the Government introduced legislation which all honourable senators opposite voted for to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in respect of waterside workers. On the very issue of retirement, the Government not only gave preference to members of the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia but also made sure that before they got a brass razoo out of it they had to be members of the Waterside Workers' Federation. That was the Government's legislation. I refer, of course, to the definition of stevedoring operations in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2), Bill No. 124 of 1977, wherein it is clearly stated:
. . . when that work is performed by a person who is a member, or who has applied for membership, of the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia;

It is a case of double standards, is it not? It might be responded by the Minister that we are talking about the Public Service and that we are not talking about the Waterside Workers' Federation. I do not accept that argument, but even if that argument is to be advanced let us have a look at it to see whether the Government in fact is consistent on this matter. I now turn to Determination No. 769 of 1978 which was tabled in the Senate and with which every senator concurred. In other words, it was one of those determinations which nobody sought to disallow. This determination was similar to Determination No. 503 which was disallowed by the Government on the grounds of preference for unionists. This Determination, which was made by the same Arbitrator, Mr Watson, reads as follows:
Determination 509 of 1977 made on 8 July 1977.
In the matter of
The Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association,
Commonwealth Public Service and others
Claimants
and
The Public Service Board and others
Respondents
As varied to date be further varied by inserting a new clause 4A as follows:
Preference in retention, Health Insurance Commission.

4A 1. If the Health Insurance Commission decides to retrench officers or employees covered by this determination it shall where practicable (a) as between officers give preference in the retention in employment to members of the Association concerned who are employed under the Determination in the particular area or locality.

How is that? What can the Government say to answer that? Double standards! The very reason the Government has given to disallow Determination No. 503, it agreed with in respect of the Health Insurance Commission. What double standards! As I said, the Government is not worth talking to. The Determination continues:
as between employees, give preference in the retention in employment to members of the association concerned employed under the determination in a particular area or locality;
It is precisely the same. It is of no use for the Minister to talk to the advisers; they will say that it is true. If honourable senators want it tabled, there it is-exactly the same.

Senator Scott talked of efficiency and gave as a reason that Determination 503 should not be approved that it does not have regard to efficiency between a union member and a non-union member. That is untrue. That is why I asked Senator Scott in all fairness whether he had read Determination 503. Even Mr Viner, in his speech when moving for the disallowance of Determination 503, said:

Apart from the inequity of preference the operation of preference under the Determination would mean that the union member could be retained in employment in preference to a more efficient non-union member.
I noticed that by the time that got from the House of Representatives to here Senator Messner had omitted that sentence. Of course, he omitted it because clause 11 (3) of Determination 503 states:
The provisions of this clause--
That is the preference clause-
shall be applied in such a way as to ensure consistency with the objects of Part 2 of the Act.
That Act is the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act which, in Part II, states:
The objects of this Part are-

(a) first, to ensure, to the greatest extent that is practicable, that each Department and each prescribed Commonwealth authority operates in such a manner as to make efficient and economical use of the services of the persons employed in the Department or by the authority;

Obviously Senator Scott had not read Determination 503; nor had he read the objects of the Act. I am afraid that we have come to the situation where the Government is burying itself by its industrial relations policies. That does not worry me much, but what does worry me is that it is burying the moderate elements within the trade union movement very quickly indeed.
The Minister, in his speech when moving for disapproval of Determination 503, said:
It is a great pity that the actions of a minority of public servants and of some of the present leaders of the ACOA have tarnished the proud history of a non-political public service in Australia.

That is precisely what the Government is doing. I warned the Government two years ago that its actions within the Public Service were going to lead to the takeover of the Public Service unions by these elements. I warned the Government that its petty action in chopping off union deduction facilities was going to have the effect of forcing people to drop out of union membership. I warned the Government that its confrontationist attitude to the Public Service was going to throw together the moderates and the militants and was going to mean that the militants would come out on top. That is precisely what has happened-the moderates have been defeated in Victoria and at the Federal level. This Government contributed to that. By this sort of legislation it is continuing to contribute to it.

It talked about knocking off preference. That again will mean that more and more people will opt out of membership of the associations in the Public Service. That is good for the Government's public relations but it is not ultimately good for the Public Service. I quote from Arbitrator Watson's decision in Determination 769 of 1978:

It is reasonable to assume that since determinations of the Arbitrator can only apply to members of an organisation, the Public Service Arbitration Act is structured on an assumption of strong union membership. It is true that the Board can by regulation confer determination benefits on non-members, but in my view this is an administrative action which, when taken in respect of a determination, must be as a consequence of and therefore follow that determination . . . There is ample and appropriate precedent from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and I find nothing in the Public Service Arbitration Act which would prevent the consideration of these claims--
Those are the ones I referred to previously-
nor, if they were granted, any inconsistency with either Act.

It is time the Government woke up to itself. I hope that it takes to heart what I have said because time is running out for it. Worse still, it is running out for the moderates within the trade union movement who are fighting the real battle. If there is a change of Government, or if other means are adopted by unions to ensure absolute preference for unionists in the Public Service, those people who have drifted away from the organisations will find when they come back that they are headed by people who want to politicise the Public Service and are being assisted in that task by this Government. Unfortunately I will have to remind the Government again in a couple of weeks of its lunacy with regard to industrial relations because I know that at the moment there are, in draft form, amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in relation to amalgamations and other matters which will do the same thing.
