SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Bill before the chamber is to remove from the Public Service Arbitrator the right to make determinations in relation to matters covered by the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. As has already been said, this amending legislation is the result of the Government's decision to disallow Determination 503 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The long debate in the House of Representatives hinged on just who should make these decisions in relation to the effective and economical administration of the Public Service. I believe that responsibility lies with the Government on behalf of the people who put us here. It lies not with outside influences, but with the Government. It relies on the philosophies of the Government of the day. Whichever Government is in power at any time, the philosophies of that Government are put forward. It also ties in with the Budgets of that Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Determinations have been disallowed on four separate occasions. I will go through them. In 1926, Determinations 47 and 48 were disallowed because of budgetary considerations. In 1928, just two years later, another Determination was disallowed because of philosophical as well as budgetary considerations. In 1932, yet another Determination was disallowed, that time because of budgetary and philosophical considerations. The disallowance in 1973 resulted from the philosophy on that occasion of the Senate. Disallowance of a determination is not something new, as has been put forward in this place today; it has been done on four separate occasions. If we look back at who introduced provisions for determinations to be disallowed we find that it was the Labor Party. It was done by the Fisher Labor Government of 1911. Admittedly, it was an old type Labor government which believed that governments-not unions-should run the country. The Opposition today appears to think that militant unions-I stress the words 'militant unions'-should have enough power to force the government of the day to fit in with their way of thinking. That is the attitude of the present Labor Party. The Fisher Labor Government of 1911 thought that governments should have some say in this regard and therefore introduced that provision.

Having dealt with the philosophy behind disallowances, I will now deal with budgetary considerations. Some of the disallowances were done because of budgetary considerations. I believe that a government should have power over its own Budget and that this should not be left to any outside influence. It is perhaps rare for the Opposition to have any consideration for or interest in budgetary matters because it showed when in government that its interest in budgetary matters lay in handing out money hand over fist. It was the last of the big spenders. The Opposition put forward the same philosophies in the last election, but the people of Australia had had enough and they threw out those ideas, as they threw out the Whitlam Government in 1975. Perhaps we should look at the consistencies underlying the disallowances. Until Senator Harradine spoke tonight, I was under the impression, as I said, that in 1973 the Liberal and Country parties had disallowed in the Senate a determination on the same grounds or similar grounds as the disallowance of this determination when they disallowed a determination that four weeks' annual leave be given only to union members. That was against the philosophy of the Liberal and Country parties.

Senator Harradine put forward tonight a couple of determinations which he says have not been consistent with such a philosophy. I was surprised to find that what he said is apparently correct. I ask Senator Harradine whether the Arbitrator in fact put such determinations before the Parliament. The Arbitrator may, where he thinks it proper to do so, make a determination that, in his opinion, is not or may not be in accord with the law of the Commonwealth relating to conditions of employment of employees in the Public Service. If so, he brings it to the attention of the Parliament. On that occasion did the Arbitrator bring it to the attention of the Parliament? Did the Parliament have those determinations laid before it? I ask Senator Harradine that because I am not aware of their being laid before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get the date for you.

—The date of the determination is of no value. I wish to know whether they were laid before the Parliament. That is the crucial question that I would like answered. I am not aware of their being laid before the Parliament. If they were not laid before the Parliament, there is no way the Parliament could have done it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has abided by the rules of a disallowance by forming the opinion, and putting that opinion before the Parliament, that it does interfere with the legislation that the Commonwealth has passed. There is very little doubt that this is the fact. It has been mentioned several times tonight that it interferes with the economic aspect. Part II of the original Act states:
7. (1) The objects of this Part are-

(a) first, to ensure, to the greatest extent that is practicable, that each Department and each prescribed Commonwealth authority operates in such a manner as to make efficient and economical use of the services of the persons employed in the Department or by the authority;

Determination No. 503 extends the periods of consultation and so eliminates, in the opinion of the Attorney-General and certainly in my opinion, the efficient and economic use of the Service. It has been stated previously and it was mentioned by Senator Harradine that unionists must have priority here in any redeployment. I believe that this is not in the best interests of the Public Service. It is certainly not conducive to efficient and economical use of labour. For example, a non-union employee may be far superior in every way to a union member but, as a result of this Determination, he must go for the sake of the union member. For this reason the Government decided to disallow the determination. If we compare Determination No. 509 and Determination No. 503 we find that there are only two areas that really concern the Government. We find that there is an additional three-month period for appeal. Senator Harradine did not mention this in his speech. Senator Button also did not mention it. Senator Harradine said that the Government and the Parliament are not experts in the arbitration area and that we should not even try to make any effort to look after our employees or to determine what is right and wrong. If members of this Parliament have no expertise in this area, if we cannot organise our own employees, we should not be here. If that is true, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be running the place.

I feel that Senator Harradine has lost all his expertise in dealing with this area. He certainly did not mention the appeals provisions. If the Public Service Board makes any decision, there are areas for appeal in several places in Determination No. 509. Neither Senator Button nor Senator Harradine mentioned that appeal provision. For example, appeals can be made after the permanent head declares that staff are eligible for redeployment. If a person's appeal fails and the Public Service Board decides not only that the person is unable to be redeployed but also that that is not practical, that person has another six to 12 months in which to appeal. I believe that this is quite fair. It allows the members of the independent tribunal to look at the matter. The chairman of the tribunal is to be appointed by the Governor-General and employees are to be represented on the tribunal, as is the department. I believe that takes into account the area in which Senator Harradine believes that we lack any expertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not because it can only recommend to the Public Service Board and the Board is the final arbitrator.

—The Appeals Tribunal is the answer to that, I believe. Let me come back to the main disagreement between the Opposition and the Government on the differences between Determination No. 503 and Determination No. 509. I believe that the crux of the matter is that this Government has disallowed Determination No. 503. I suppose it is a matter of who should bear the responsibility of introducing legislation to fit in with the Government's philosophy or its Budget. Should it be the Government or should it be some outside control whether it be the union or the arbitration system? We on this side of the House, as I said earlier, agree with the action of the Fisher Labor Government which originally introduced in 1911 the Bill that put the responsibility fair and square on the shoulders of the Government, not on outside organisations. It gives me great pleasure to support this Bill.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Determination No. 769 of 1978 was tabled in the Senate on 21 August 1979.
—That is not a point of order, but it is explanatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Leader of the Labor Party, Senator Button, in opposing this legislation. I do not intend to deal with all of the details that Senator Walters has brought up. It was the usual diatribe against the trade union movement which she goes on with. But I am pleased that she brought up the fact that the last time a government disallowed a determination of a Public Service arbitrator was in 1932.
—What year was that?
—It was in 1932-50 years ago.
—I didn't say that. I said 1973 and 1973 was the last time. I particularly said that.

—The honourable senator ought to listen to what I have to say. I said that the last time a government disallowed a determination was in 1932. It was an Opposition that disallowed a determination in 1973. I also found it fascinating that Senator Walters had to go back to 1911 to try to justify the actions of the Government in 1981. I think this legislation has to be seen in the light of this Government's appalling industrial relations policy. The legislation before us tonight represents another low point in that policy-a policy of whatever the trouble, be it unemployment, or inflation, blame the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should examine the record of this Government in industrial relations. When Fraser came to power in 1975 as the Prime Minister wage indexation was accepted by all parties. Fraser promised to support wage indexation. Two months later, after the election, he argued for partial indexation at the first national wage case in 1976 and the next three out of four decisions went the same way. Certainly this led to the erosion of living standards for trade unionists and their families. As to the Industrial Relations Bureau, I think we ought to ask ourselves what it has achieved. In the two years it has been in operation it has done nothing. It has cost $12.9m. It is a costly mistake. It ought to be scrapped. I suggest it will not be long before this Government scraps it. Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act is now seen by employers and by employees as an irritation and a mistake. I ask honourable senators just to look at the resolution of the Laidely dispute with the Transport Workers Union of Australia. That showed one thing. It showed that a dispute will be settled in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, not by the Trade Practices Tribunal.

Then we had the Staples amendment which was an attempt to curb the independent jurisdiction of individual members of the Arbitration Commission. That was opposed not only by employers and employee organisations but also by members of the Commission themselves. We then saw the Government's attempt to impose a tax on workers' housing concessions which was an arrangement whereby workers who lived and worked in remote areas received a housing concession. This piece of industrial relations legislation, put up by this Government, was opposed by the Premier of Queensland who is not known as a strong supporter of the trade union movement. What happened was that this Government was forced into another humilating backdown.

This Government has conducted a continuous campaign of denigration against the Arbitration Commission and the integrity of the Bench. It has also carried out a campaign against the integrity of the President of the Commission, Sir John Moore. We now have Government threats of secret ballot legislation despite the clear evidence that that will not solve strikes and will not solve industrial disputes. In the past we have been told by honourable senators on the Government side that we ought to have secret ballots for the election of trade union officials. We have been told that if we had secret ballots we would be able to get rid of the militants about whom Senator Walters always talks and that if we had properly supervised ballots then the rank and file would vote out the militants. I think one only has to look at the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia which has been referred to tonight by Senator Harradine. That Federation, I suggest, would have the fairest and most democratic electoral system for officials of any trade union in Australia. I think we all know the result of that and I sure that Senator Elstob would agree with me when I say that the rank and file members of that union do not elect supporters of this Government when there are secret ballots for the election of their officials. In the United Kingdom the Donovan Royal Commission in 1968 looked into trade unions and into employer organisations. That Commission rejected secret ballots. It said they would not work and of course they will not.

I think we have to look briefly at the facts in this dispute and at what caused this legislation to be before us now. Two unions were involved-the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the Australian Public Service Association. They are hardly the sort of hard line militant unions which Senator Walter's had described. They assumed-this was the mistake they made, of course-that the Public Service Board decisions would be adhered to by the Government. The unions involved acted in good faith. They thought that the Government could be trusted. In fact, they were urged by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) to take their case to the umpire, as Senator Button said this afternoon. In this case the umpire was the Public Service Arbitrator. The Arbitrator decided that the unions had a good case. He supported Determination No. 503. But we have the situation where the Government will not abide by the umpire's decision. The Government then turned around and gave the unions out. I think it is worth remembering what Senator Walters said this evening. She said that the last occasion that a government moved to disallow a determination of the Public Service Arbitrator was in September 1932. That was at the time of the Lyons Government. As Senator Button pointed out this afternoon, and as I reminded Senator Walters earlier in my speech it was a Liberal-Country Party Opposition not a government that moved in 1973 to disallow the determination on four weeks annual leave. Such leave, of course, is now enjoyed by practically all Australians. So it is 50 years since the Parliament has been asked to overthrow the convention that the umpire's decision, that is, the arbitrator under the Public Service Act, should not be interfered with.

I think we have to look at and ask ourselves what this Government is doing toward bringing about better industrial relations in Australia. What is it doing about, say, amalgamation of unions through which there are advantages? We all know that some of the most costly and irritating strikes in Australia today have to do with demarcation disputes; things that would not occur if there were a decent amalgamation of unions in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amalgamation on what basis?
—On an industry basis.
—What does that mean-on an industry basis?
—I know that Senator Harradine opposes the point of view that I have put before about this.
—No. What does 'industry basis' mean?

—Mr President, if Senator Harradine would stop interjecting I would get to the point. I know he opposes the Labor Party's views on amalgamation. But let me present some statistics about the number of unions in Australia today. There are 147 employee organisations registered under the Federal Act, 117 having branches in one or more of the four States which have a separate industrial registration system. Most of those unions have registered branches operating as unions under State Acts. In my own State of New South Wales alone 124 employee organisations are registered under the Trade Union Act, 113 are registered under the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act, and 50 function as branches of Federal organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: The large number of trade unions in this country does not assist in improving industrial relations, especially when the situation is compared with the contribution made by the 16 unions in the whole of West Germany. Prime Minister Fraser loves to quote statistics on West Germany. He is always lecturing us on the economic success of the Federal Republic. He is always talking about its great industrial record. What he does not say is that West Germany has one of the most sophisticated trade union movements in the world and that we in Australia have one of the most antiquated trade union movements in the world. For example, the Qantas management has to negotiate with 23 separate unions, Trans-Australia Airlines with 21 separate unions, the Australian National Railways Commission with 18 separate unions, and the Australian National Line with 12 separate unions. I had hoped that the Government would have learned a valuable lesson from the Qantas dispute about the benefits of amalgamating unions. I wonder how long that dispute would have dragged on if the management of Qantas had had to negotiate with one union instead of the 23 unions that are involved at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure as eggs, the planes would have been grounded.

—Senator Harradine had his full time. I do not intend to take full time, but I want to put on record that Senator Harradine's views on the amalgamation of unions are well known, just as the views of the Labor Party on amalgamation are well known.
—I just want democratic control; that is all.

—I refer Senator Harradine to the situation in West Germany about which I was just talking and ask him how many unions Lufthansa deals with when it comes time to negotiate over an industrial dispute or a wages matter. I suggest to him that Lufthansa does not have to negotiate with 23 unions, as Qantas does in Australia. No government in the Western world relies more on union bashing as a tactic than does this Government. It is interesting to note, though, that the Government spokesmen stress this when they are at home, not when they are abroad. A former senator, Sir Robert Cotton, became our Consul-General in New York, and quite often one sees reports of speeches he makes to businessmen in the United States in which he is at pains to point out that Australia's industrial relations are good, that they are not as bad as they are painted in the Australian media.
—Remember what Mr Anthony said.

—As Senator Bishop reminds me, recently Mr Anthony has been in the Middle East and in Japan. I think it was only this week, in Saudi Arabia in the Middle East, that he said Australia had a good industrial relations record, that it was not as bad as that of the United States and it was not as bad as the industrial disputes record in Britain. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Lynch, continually defends our Australian industrial record, but he does it when he is overseas talking to businessmen, not when he is in Australia. I stress that no government in the Western world uses union bashing tactics as this Government does. I use the words 'Western world' because I believe a free trade union movement is essential to any demoncracy. One of the first acts of any totalitarian government, whether it is a totalitarian government of the Left or of the Right, is to smash a free trade union movement. One has to look only at the events in Poland at the present time to prove that point. It is a wonder to me that the Central Committee of the Polish Communist Party has not called in Prime Minister Fraser in an attempt to put down the efforts of Solidarity in Poland.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be better for Australia if this Government concentrated on improving industrial relations instead of encouraging activities such as the recent anti-union marches. The marches were designed for one purpose-to pit Australians against Australians. This Government would do well to remember the fate of similar anti-union conservative governments in the past. In 1928 the Government of Stanley Melbourne Bruce introduced a Bill that increased Federal powers in the conciliation and arbitration system. Mr Scullin, the then Leader of the Australian Labor Party, had these thoughtful, and still pertinent, words to say in Parliament:
The assumption of the Party opposite is that when there is a dispute the workers are always wrong and every set of figures quoted is used as an indictment of organised labour.

I ask honourable senators: What has changed since Mr Scullin used those words? Of course, the Bruce Government lost the next election and Prime Minister Bruce lost his seat. Sir Earle Page when he was Prime Minister attempted to abolish the conciliation and arbitration system. I think everybody would agree that that was one of the things that led to the downfall of his Government. I am not one of those people who believe that the trade union movement is always right, and I give as an example the recent strike by sewerage workers in Sydney. I agree completely with the remarks made by the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, Mr Jack Ferguson, that it was a very selfish strike. Nevertheless, I ask: How can this Government justify spending $2m on an advertising campaign against the 35-hour week? We have to ask ourselves how many workers in this country now work less than 40 hours. It is a large proportion, and the numbers are increasing daily. One has to look only at the reports this morning of the decison relating to the Altona Chemical complex in Melbourne granting another 850 workers the 35-hour week. We all ought to ask ourselves now long it is since the 40-hour week legislation was brought in.

I wish to refer briefly to part of the present campaign being run by the Government against the trade union movement. It is a campaign against Bob Hawke, and we heard some of it this afternoon from Senator Scott. It is a campaign against Labor's spokesman on industrial relations. It is an attempt to denigrate not only his work as our spokesman on industrial relations but also his previous work as President of the Austraian Council of Trade Unions. I predict that that campaign will fail, and fail dismally. In the past the Australian public gave overwhelming support to Bob Hawke in his efforts to settle industrial disputes, and I am sure that they will continue to support him in the future. I am sure that they will continue to reject the industrial relations policy of this Government. The Opposition opposes this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not hold the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) responsible for the fact that he was unable to answer any of the matters that were raised in the debate at the second reading stage because the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill is totally indefensible and, therefore, he could have nothing to say about it. The Bill omits the existing section 24 (4) and inserts a new sub-section which precludes the making of any determination by an arbitrater or award of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of the redeployment or compulsory retirement of public servants. Does the Minister feel that the clauses of Determination No. 509 of 1977-which, as the Minister said, must be read in conjunction with this piece of legislation-are adequate to enable an employee or groups of employees faced with redeployment or compulsory retirement obtaining redress from a source which ultimately is not the Public Service Board?
—The situation has been clearly spelt out by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) in his second reading speech.
—What is the name of the Bill, Tony? Can you tell us that?

—Senator Harradine obviously is very interested in this matter, even if Senator Evans is not. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the point that there is a very significant appeals tribunal. It will be a very powerful body, I believe, in deciding these particular issues. That is the key question here. I think that is the answer which Senator Harradine is seeking. If he needs any further amplification on that matter I would be happy to arrange for discussions on the matter later.

-That is not good enough. On a number of occasions I have raised the need for the Minister responsible for a piece of legislation to be in charge of the legislation in the Senate. This brings us very close to a position of the Opposition asking that the Committee report progress until such time as the Minister who is responsible for the legislation is in the House. TALK.START.PARA: —I want some clarification on this matter. I have studied the Bill and can make neither head nor tail of it. Clause 3 (b) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: by omitting sub-section (4) and substituting the following sub-sections:
(a) a term of an award makes provision for or in relation to-

(i) the redeployment, or the termination of the employment of persons who are redundant, are physically or mentally incapable of performing their work, are inefficient in the performance of their work, do not have qualifications essential to the performance of their work or have had the operation of such qualifications suspended;

What do the words 'award makes provision' mean in relation to the words 'the operation of such qualifications suspended'? Who suspends the operation of such qualifications? What does that provision mean? Does it mean that the work that was normally done has been suspended? Who determines whether a person becomes inefficient? Can we get some clarification? Is this an example of the big boss standing over employees whom he wants to get rid of and saying: 'You are gone, and you and you' or is there some criteria by which we establish inefficiency? It could well be that in a person's mind a worker becomes inefficient but in fact he is possibly more efficient than the person who determines his inefficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the procedures in this matter will be discussed with the unions in the not too distant future and that those guidelines will become the guidelines for the decisions in respect of the matters to which Senator Cavanagh seeks answers.

—I do not think the answer is good enough. We are told that something will be decided with the unions after we have passed this legislation. The legislation will be passed and the unions will have to decide the matter I suppose with the relevant Minister within the guidelines we have determined. It is not satisfactory for a Parliament which does not know what the legislation means to make a law that permits another organisation to interpret it. We are getting back to the stage where the unions control the situation. All we have been told is that the responsible Minister and the unions will fix this matter up. But that will be done after we have passed the legislation. They cannot go too far when the decision is made by us. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Senate a problem which I had. As I read the legislation, it provides almost a code in respect of certain matters which become the responsibility of the Government, as distinct from the Public Service Board, and the responsibility of this legislation, as distinct from Determination 509, which the Government says it intends to retain. I wish to pursue a line of questioning which Senator Harradine started. I think that I can best do this by referring the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) to clause 4 of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill and asking him: What happens when the employment of a person is terminated after being told by his employer, for example, that he is physically or mentally incapable of performing his work, that he is inefficient in the performance of his work, or that he does not have the necessary qualifications? Is that the end of the road for that employee? What redress does he have from that decision? It is an important question. There has always been provision in the Public Service Act for redress from a termination of employment-indeed, redress in terms of a hearing before an inquiry of some kind.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the answer is completely clear but it is not completely clear in the legislation or in the second reading speech which purports to explain the legislation. The fundamental question in this whole concept is the termination of employment issue. We can all have different views and views of different intensity about the capacity and right of the Government to move employees much more readily than it has been able to do in the past. That is a matter of quite legitimate discussion in which rights are not involved to the same extent. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — My questions relate to the nub of the Bill. The nub of the Bill lies in proposed new sub-section (4) of section 24, which precludes the making of any determination or award as defined in proposed new sub-section (7) in respect of the redeployment on compulsory retirement of public servants. Determination No. 503 has now been disallowed, this Bill must be read in conjunction with Determination No. 509 of 1977. The fundamental aspects of redeployment and retirement of public servants will be governed by a code of procedures outlined in the amended Bill plus the code of procedures encompassed in Determiantion No. 509. Furthermore, that code cannot be removed by arbitration; it can be removed only by an Act of Parliament. Therefore, I ask: Does the combination of this Bill and Determination No. 509 provide to a public servant who is to be compulsorily retired on the decision of the Public Service Board redress ultimatley to any authority other than the Public Service Board? Section 16 of Determination No. 509 provides a right of appeal procedure. It sets up a committee which is the right of appeal committee. Sub-section (3) of section 16 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee shall report its findings to the Public Service Board with a recommendation for action appropriate to the case.

They are recommendations. Under what obligation is the Public Service Board to accept those recommendations? That is the first point I wish to make. The second point is probably even more important and may not have been envisaged by the Government when it introduced this legislation. It involves the issue of automation and technological change. Of course, the issue of automation and technological change, whether it is in the Public Service or in private industry, raises the fear of redeployment and compulsory retirement. As I said in the second reading debate, the Government is on record-there are ample examples of statements by Government Ministers-as to what should occur in respect of automation and technological change in private industry. In essence, it says that there should be notification, consultation, and, failing agreement, arbitration. I ask: Is the Government, by virtue of this legislation, blocking off the final step to its own employees?

The third and fourth questions do not necessarily relate to the provisions of the Bill but I think the Government ought to answer them. TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the agreement and believes that it should be renegotiated. I do not believe that the agreement between Australia and the United States Government on the staging of B52 aircraft through Australia should be looked at in isolation. It should be seen as an integral part of the new US Administration's foreign policy strategy, a policy which, unfortunately, is becoming more aggressive and confrontationist every day. I believe that history will judge the Carter Administration on foreign policy much more kindly than did the American voters. I think that, in regard to Australia's foreign policies and interests, the Carter Administration will probably be remembered as the best administration since that of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

SPEECH.PARA: I think President Carter is to be commended in a number of areas. Firstly, he is to be commended in the area of human rights, particularly in regard to Central and South America. People might think it strange that I should say that but I have in mind the immense pressures that President Carter must have been placed under in Nicaragua. When one looks at what is happening in El Salvador today one sees that it is to his credit that he resisted these policies and pressures. His co-operation with the Socialist International about conflicts in Central and South America meant much closer contact with social democratic leaders like Schmidt, Brandt, Palme and Kreisky. This meant that there was constant European advice which was listened to and acted upon, unlike the present situation where already Canada, France and West Germany have warned the United States on its policies towards El Salvador.

We had the spectacle of the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) rushing off to America a few weeks ago and appearing to endorse US Policy. We were one of the first countries in the Western world to support the American policy on El Salvador. In our own area of the world, in South Korea and in the Philippines, I think the Carter Administration did not ignore human rights issues. One has only to look at America's actions in the case of Kim Dae Jung to realise that. I think it is interesting to note that the President of South Korea was the first official head of state to visit President Reagan after he was sworn in.

The United States policy in southern Africa paralleled that of the Australian Government. I think that was a creditable policy especially in relation to countries like Zimbabwe and Mozambique. I think that the role of the former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, Andrew Young, has to be taken into account. His contacts with Robert Mugabe and his wing of the Patriotic Front have proved to be successful. I think anyone who now sees the amount of Soviet support that was given to Joshua Nkomo would realise that in this instance the Americans were right. I think it was Andrew Young who recognised that the President of Mozambique, Samora Machel, was not a Marxist but in fact was an African nationalist, despite the rhetoric that he might have been credited with.

What disturbs me at the moment is that it looks as if the United States will reverse its policy in southern Africa by giving aid to the rebels in Angola and trying to destabilise the present regime in Mozambique just when I believe that the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Malcolm Fraser, was about to recognise the regime in Mozambique and to extend diplomatic recognition to it from Salisbury. He was certainly about to re-establish an aid program to Mozambique that was last in existence under the Whitlam Government as a small aid program. I wonder where we will stand on that point. Will we follow Reagan's example blindly? Will we give the United States a positive example of Australia's stance towards Mozambique? Will we be prepared to say that we have a different policy and we will not blindly follow the United States? The fact that five of South Africa's most senior military officers were recently able to spend a week in the United States before they were asked to leave is an indication of an improving relationship between these two countries.

The relationship between South Africa and the Reagan Administration seems to be improving. Forces led by Jonas Savimbi of UNITA, or the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, received assistance from the South Africans in the war in Angola. Mr Savimbi is about to visit the United States next week. It is certain that he will be seeking arms. I hope, not because I do not support UNITA or not because I support the present regime in Angola, that he does not get them. I believe that if the supply of arms is continued to the people who are opposing the present regime in Angola the conflict will spill over into Namibia and will not do Australia or any of the Western world any good at all. Rumours in the newspapers this morning indicated that the Reagan Administration intends to invite the South African Prime Minister, Mr Botha, to visit Washington. While these rumours have been vigorously denied, the very fact that they have been printed in the newspapers should concern us. I think Australia's stance must be different from that of the United States in southern Africa. It was recently said here by a spokesman from Nigeria that to be an Australian in present-day Africa is virtually a passport of safe conduct through the continent. We must not allow this standing to be eroded by blindly following United States policies in the area.

I think another area where the policies of the United States and Australia are bound to differ is in the Middle East. There is no doubt in my mind that events in Iran doomed the Carter Administration. The hostage crisis in November 1979 made the election results of November 1980 entirely predictable. In the US the mood of the people changed dramatically. They felt that the United States had been humiliated by the so-called Government of Iran especially so when the rescue attempt of the hostages was such a dismal failure. I believe that the US voters especially turned to Reagan because he promised to re-establish United States foreign policy as paramount in the eyes of the world. I think it is worthwhile noting that there was one of the lowest turnouts of voters in the presidential election since the 1930s.

I turn to the Middle East. We know that the Australian Prime Minister received an award last year in the United States. We have seen him trying to strut the world stage. But the first time he was asked for assistance by the United States, the first time he was asked to take part in strategic naval exercises in the Indian Ocean, he refused. I think we should ask ourselves why. Was it because of National Country Party pressure? Was it because important wheat sales to Iran were being negotiated when the strategic naval exercises were being carried out? Could it be that those naval exercises were being aimed at Iran and at the Gulf? This is something we have to ask ourselves. Again we have been asked recently to take part in a peace keeping force in the Sinai. At the moment the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) is in Saudi Arabia and in the Gulf States on an important trade mission. There is no way he will make a commitment one way or the other about a peace keeping force in the Sinai when he is in countries such as Saudi Arabia.

I also raise the question of Israel and Palestine. I was very disturbed to see a cutting from this morning's Australian Financial Review. I am glad that Senator Martin from the Government side asked a question on this matter this morning. Peter Robinson, the Financial Review's correspondent in Riyadh, had this to say in part of his article:
. . . Saudi Arabia was looking for Australian support-particularly in 'voting patterns in the United Nations'.
Australia's Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, in an answer that was not in his prepared text, said: 'I believe there is growing awareness and an even-handed policy being applied by Australia'.
'I look forward to discussions-particularly private ones-in an attempt to do what we can to solve this painful problem.'

I just hope that Mr Anthony was not signalling a change in our attitude on the question of Israel and Palestine purely because of trade. I just wonder: Is this the way that we go about getting respect from our United States allies because, if it is, it is no wonder that they deny us information about their activities at the bases in Australia. Also on the Middle East question, I believe the United States is in danger of making the same mistakes in Saudi Arabia that it made in Iran. Giving a country the most sophisticated military equipment does not necessarily guarantee the stability of the regime in that country. If the regime does not have the support of the people, no amount of military equipment, no matter how sophisticated, will keep that loyalty. We should have learnt a lesson from the situation in Iran, and the United States should have learnt a lesson from Iran. It did not matter whether the Shah had F14s, F16s, or F18s, or how sophisticated the equipment was; he did not have the support of the people and the regime toppled. I believe that there is a great danger today that the regime in Saudi Arabia might change. I believe that there is a very strong chance of that happening. We will then have to ask ourselves who will use that equipment, because outside the superpowers at the moment I think Saudi Arabia is moving to a situation where it will certainly have the most sophisticated air force in the world. What will happen then? Will we have another Iran-Iraq type of conflict in the Middle East? I think it is in Australia's interest to be more sympathetic towards Iraq. Here is a country that is moving gradually away from the Soviet Union. It is attaining a leadership role in the non-aligned movement. It is making a natural progression towards the West, expecially as far as new technology-equipment and computers-is concerned. But it is also a country which has no diplomatic relations at the moment with the United States. It is certainly in Australia's interest that we improve our relations with that important country.

I view with concern the statement of the United States Secretary of State Haig that the Reagan Administration is attempting to develop a strategic consensus to counter the Soviet Union. He went on to say that the United States was looking at a belt of countries that extended from Pakistan to Egypt and that included such divergent states as Turkey, Israel and Saudi Arabia. I think that proposal is farcical. I think it runs counter to all modern political and global strategies and, again, I hope that Australia is able to put to the United States our belief that that strategy will fail.

I turn now to the Camp David agreement. It would seem to me that the cautious approach that was used by the Carter Administration is now to be replaced by a harder line stance and that the problems of Israel and Palestine will be much harder to solve than they would have been under the Carter Administration. Another area where I think it would pay us to have a much different foreign policy from that of the United States is Vietnam. Recently, as a member of a Senate committee I heard representatives of the Australian Indo-China Refugee Association, certainly no supporters of the present regime in Vietnam, recommend to the committee most strongly that Australia begin a massive aid program to that country. They pointed out to our committee that agriculture in Vietnam at the moment was in such a mess that there was likely to be a massive exodus of refugees in the very near future. While, of course, they hoped that a lot of those refugees would come to Australia, they realised the sort of predicament Australia was facing with unemployment and the economic circumstances in Australia at present. But they did not hesitate to suggest that Australia should give aid to Vietnam.

I think all of us should realise that the United States policy towards Vietnam, no matter how justified people might think it was because of the conflict that took place, has resulted in forcing Vietnam closer and closer to the Soviet Union. If people are concerned at the present build up of forces in Cam Ranh Bay they have only to look back at the reason why there has been this build up. To whom will Vietnam turn if it does not get aid from the West? Certainly it will turn to the Soviet Union. I do not believe that we can rely unswervingly on the Administration of President Reagan and Secretary of State Haig. I do not think we can expect them always to do the right thing by Australia. I do not believe that the United States will respect a government that agrees with everything that it does. The Labor Party believes that the relationship between Australia and the United States should be based on mutual respect. We believe that an ally should tell a friend when it is wrong. After all, it was the Australian Labor Party that formed the Australian-American alliance. Yet at the moment, if we criticise the United States we get members of the Government jumping up straight away and claiming that we are being pro-Soviet.

I turn now to the issue of the B52s. I have here a copy of Hearings before the Committee on Armed Services, United States Senate, where evidence was given by General Richard H. Ellis, Commander in Chief, Strategic Air Command, and Director, Strategic Target Planning, Joint Chiefs of Staff. In his evidence there is an expression-SIOP-which stands for Single Integrated Operating Plan which, if one cuts out all the jargon, I believe means all-out nuclear attack. I showed a copy of this document to the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, earlier this evening and I now seek leave to have the two pages incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE ROLE OF CONVENTIONAL FORCES

Recent Soviet activity in Africa and South Asia can be traced, not to a change in our overall conventional force capabilities, but rather to a shift in the strategic balance. The Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact have enjoyed a conventional advantage over the U.S. and our NATO allies since World II. Through the years, we have maintained a moderate size force with investment keyed to modernization in an effort to keep the historical conventional balance static, as opposed to closing the gap. Today, we find the Soviets using their increased strategic capabilities as a ''nuclear umbrella'' in the pursuit of global activities we were able to deter when we had the undisputed nuclear shield. Because of this, deterrence can no longer be neatly divided into subgroups such as conventional and nuclear. It must be viewed as an interrelated, single entity.

In response, SAC is developing new options which provide the National Command Authorities (NCA) with additional flexibility to respond to future crises and conflicts in a timely and controlled manner. In addition to nuclear adjustments, we are exploring a range of non-SIOP (contingency) options for SAC forces.

Participation in these evolving contingency options is not intended to diminish the SIOP mission but to assure the most effective use of SAC resources. Strategic forces are uniquely capable of supporting general purpose force missions. The ability to execute contingency plans and procedures using SAC assets-particularly the manned bomber-markedly improves U.S. war fighting capability. SAC aircraft can provide rapid, long-range force projection in the conventional and theater nuclear areas while retaining their contribution to the SIOP, if so tasked.

SAC's contingency capability spans a wide range of conventional operations-from rapid force projection to psychological warfare. Let me briefly discuss one small portion of SAC's contingency operations-B-52 rapid force projection-so that you can better understand the extent of this national asset.

No other weapon system can match the B-52 in delivering concentrated conventional firepower on the battlefield. In the opening hours of hostilities, B-52's, with 30 tons of explosives, can provide timely and effective assistance in disrupting enemy actions.

The projected conventional battle scenario is one characterized by minimum warning time followed by a massive attack from highly mobile forces aimed at a rapid breakthrough of defensive lines. In this situation, employment timing is critical. Ground forces need all available firepower in the first 48 hours, preferably applied directly on attacking and supporting forces.

The most timely way to meet a commander's request for B-52 support is to operate from forward area bases which have been upgraded for B-52 operations and have prepositioned war reserve materials. Last December we tested the ability of our B-52's, aircrews and maintenance teams to support such a concentrated effort in a conventional scenario. A B-52H squadron of 14 aircraft from Ellsworth AFB, South South Dakota, was tasked to deploy to Andersen AFB, Guam, as an extension of its Operational Readiness Inspection (ORI). The unit was provided ten hours notice prior to the first aircraft launch. The KC-135 was the only organic support airlift authorized. Fourteen B-52H's (reconfigured from a SIOP mission capability to a conventional weapons configuration) and five KC-135s launched from Ellsworth for Andersen. All deployed aircraft, support equipment and personnel were in place within [deleted] hours. Four hours later, the first B-52H had launched on a sea surveillance, mine, laying, and conventional weapons delivery training mission. During the next five training days, 30 conventional warfare training missions were flown. A similar deployment to Guam was initiated three weeks ago as part of an ORI at Grand Forks AFB, North Dakota, with equally outstanding results.

With regard to the current world situation, combat missions could be launched from Andersen to the Middle East, if the need arises, although the distances involved are incredibly long. This points to the critical near-term need for operating bases closer to the Persian Gulf area to support both tactical and bomber forces. Standby operating bases in Northeastern Africa, Sinai, Turkey, or Saudi Arabia could be developed to accept U.S. combat aircraft. Air operations from these bases could also support the rapid deployment ground forces program now being developed. These forward bases are essential if the United States is to effectively insert a military presence in the Middle East or Persian Gulf area.
CONCLUSION

I hope the preceding statement has covered an urgent and convincing message-our current and near term strategic forces, while capable and ready, are, unable to achieve the relative balance possessed just two years ago. The delay in ratification of SALT II promises to further aggravate the balance and I would like to expand on this thought.

For the past several years, the Soviets have had, and still have, three ICBM's a supersonic bomber with intercontinental capabilities and a nuclear submarine with long range missiles in hot production. They have a new generation of ICBM's and a Trident size submarine in advanced development. [Deleted.] Less well understood, but just as certain, is the development of a new strategic bomber. All of this points to a near and mid-term continuing build-up of Soviet strategic forces. SALT II restraints would have placed a quantitative lid on these on-going programs-even though qualitative improvements would have continued. With no SALT II, the Soviets have the option of pursuing both. Of equal concern is the probable loss of certain intelligence and other data that would have been made available by the verification clauses of the treaty.

From a military and strategic balance point of view, the U.S. needed SALT II more than the Soviets and now our country must be prepared to meet the consequences of delayed or no ratification. If the Soviet strategic buildup continues as it has for the past ten years, we could be faced with an even more critical situation than that portrayed in this statement.
Thank you.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the current world situation, combat missions could be launched from Andersen--

to the Middle East, if the need arises, although the distances involved are incredibly long. I would think that probably Darwin would be seen as being part of the places that he mentioned.

I want to spell out in detail the Labor Party's reservations about the B52 agreement. The Government alleges that the B52 agreement is comprised of, firstly, an exchange of diplomatic notes and, secondly, a statement made by the Prime Minister in the House on 11 March 1981. The Prime Minister's statement does not form part of the agreement either from an international, legal or a commonsense point of view. The additional document to which the Foreign Minister referred and which he produced from the Embassy in Washington is no more than a set of speaking notes, the purpose of which was to produce an agreed formula for Fraser's public statement, which would protect the long-standing United States policy of not disclosing whether its nuclear strike force planes and ships were carrying nuclear weapons. The agreement, as constituted by the exchange of diplomatic notes, is inadequate and does not in any of its eight clauses contain an unequivocal assurance that the United States will inform the Australian Government whether any of the B52 flights to stage through and over Australia are carrying nuclear weapons. Sub-paragraph 1 of the agreement says that the B52 flights shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean and for navigational training purposes. The fundamental point, however, is that the B52 is a long range strategic nuclear bomber which has been designed specifically for carrying and dropping nuclear weapons. It is not a training aeroplane or a surveillance aeroplane and it would be naive to think that any other power would regard it as such.

The statement made by the Prime Minister on 11 March purports to be in accordance with the exchange of diplomatic notes-it is the latter which constitute a binding international treaty obligation on Australia-but it is not. The fact is that late last year the Americans were prepared to agree that we should receive notification whether nuclear weapons were on board these planes, but they subsequently refused to do so. A careful reading of the diplomatic notes makes this quite clear. When the agreement was introduced in the House of Representatives, Mr Bowen, the Labor Party spokesman on foreign affairs, moved an amendment. The Government exposed the worthlessness of the Prime Minister's statement to the House when it voted against the amendment. The amendment simply would have ensured that such flights would not be armed with nuclear weapons.

The Government has expressed the wish that it be possible to have a bipartisan policy on these issues. I believe that that is nonsense. When this agreement was presented to the Parliament, the diplomatic notes had already been exchanged which means that we had already entered into an international, binding agreement. Therefore, we were presented with a fait accompli. There was no attempt by the Government to discuss the question with the Opposition leaders prior to the tabling of the notes in the Parliament. For those reasons, the Opposition opposes the agreement. We believe that it should be completely renegotiated.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967.
