DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF B52s THROUGH AUSTRALIA FOR SEA SURVEILLANCE IN THE INDIAN OCEAN AND FOR NAVIGATION TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although it would not have been apparent from much of what Senator Sibraa said, we are in fact discussing a ministerial statement on the staging of B52 aircraft through Australia for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean and for navigational training. At the outset, I would like to correct one remark Senator Sibraa made, that this was an initiative of the Reagan Administration. In fact, it was an initiative of the Carter Administration which came to fruition in the time of its successor.

SPEECH.PARA: In discussions on this subject, the remarks of the Opposition seem to cast doubt on whether it realises that we are an ally of the United States of America. We have a military alliance with the United States and it is one of the few countries with which we have such an alliance. Of course, that alliance is in the form of the ANZUS treaty. This treaty-a very important one though it is- is not, in fact, most important because of the assurance of support it gives in the event of an emergency. The United States will come to our assistance in an emergency if it thinks it is in its interests to do so. That is what happened in 1942. There was no military alliance then. That is not the real importance of the ANZUS treaty. The real importance of the ANZUS treaty is the deterrent it provides to the outbreak of hostilities in our area.

It has a secondary importance in that the mechanism and the existence of the ANZUS treaty provides very valuable world-wide intelligence for Australia. The treaty provides facilities for joint training by our armed forces and it provides for us a vehicle, a mechanism, for the provision of a great deal of technical information that otherwise would not be available to us. These are all enormous benefits that flow from the existence of our treaty relationship with the United States. Any treaty has both benefits and obligations. One of the obligations we have under the ANZUS treaty is set out in Article II of that treaty which reads:

In order more effectively to achieve the objectives of this Treaty the Parties separately and jointly by means of continuous and effective self-help and mutual aid will maintain and develop their individual and collective capacity to resist armed attack.

This staging of B52 flights through Darwin falls squarely under Article II of the ANZUS treaty. The purposes of these B52 staging flights are, firstly, sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean, an area in which surveillance is grossly inadequate. Despite the remarks of Senator Sibraa, the B52s have a very considerable surveillance capability. The second objective--

TALK.START.PARA: —They were designed as such?
—They were not designed as such but by the equipment they have for their primary role, they have a very substantial sea surveillance capability.
—Just because they have long range tanks. Is that what you are saying?

—It has nothing to do with their long range tanks. It is primarily their radar which gives them this capability. Their very long endurance and their radar capability make them excellent sea surveillance vehicles. The second role for which the staging is designed is for navigational training. This is an important role. The B52s are, as Senator Evans has just remarked, essentially long range bombers. That is their prime role and the crews need training in this role. The use of Darwin as a staging point will make it more possible for them to get effective training. This is a very important contribution to the deterrent. Turning firstly to the role of sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean, as I said, this is a key area in world affairs at the moment, particularly the north-west corner. The surveillance facilities in that area are very inadequate. Darwin is necessary as a staging point if surveillance is to be carried out in the Persian Gulf area. Surveillance cannot be done effectively from Guam. I wish to make quite clear one point that sometimes arises. The thought that the surveillance might be carried out by satellites is quite false. Satellites can provide the raw intelligence. The one thing that is essential is identification. Aircraft and satellites must work in conjunction if we are to have effective surveillance of an area.
—Where else in the world are B52s unarmed and used just for surveillance purposes?

—They are not used in any other areas as far as I know because in no other area are the very long distances involved which exist in the Indian Ocean. The B52s are the only American aircraft even operating from Darwin which would carry out surveillance missions in the north-west Indian Ocean.
—Not in the Pacific; not in the South Atlantic?

—No, the Americans have a very considerable array of bases that cover the Pacific very adequately. The second reason for the use of the Darwin staging facility is the navigational training of the B52 crews based in Guam. They are a very important contribution to the nuclear deterrent and their effective training is, of course, the key to their deterrent capability. When operating out of Darwin, we are assured they will not be armed. The assurance comes from the American Government in the person of Secretary of State Haig. The suggestion made by Senator Sibraa that this should be somehow written back into the treaty, presumably because the Opposition does not trust Secretary Haig, is nonsense. If one does not trust the Americans, the Americans do not become any more trustworthy because provisions are written into the treaty.
—Why have a treaty in the first place? Why write anything down? Why not do the whole thing on trust? Alice in Wonderland!

—What is needed is an agreement on how the aircraft are to operate. The type of attitude which is evidenced quite clearly by Senator Evans is not to trust our allies. The Opposition's policy-I think it is evidenced very well by Senator Evans-is that Australia should kick its friends in the teeth and grovel to its enemies. I saw a very good example not long ago in the Parliament when one prominent Labor member, talking about the invasion of Afghanistan, did not like to call it an invasion. What he preferred to call it was a Russian presence in Afghanistan. This is the approach of Labor members; they grovel to their potential enemies and take every opportunity--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That claim made by Senator Hamer was refuted by each member of the Labor Opposition in this chamber in answer to Senator Carrick at the time of the Russian invasion, which term was adopted by the Labor Opposition.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Hamer.

—The remark was made by the member for Hunter in the House of Representatives. It would be idle to pretend that the United States has a perfect government. No human institution is ever perfect. Of course that government makes mistakes. Also it is certain that our interests will not always be identical with those of the United States, but we must recognise where our friends lie and where our potential dangers come from. To adopt the words of Sir Winston Churchill, I refuse to be neutral between the fire brigade and the fire. That is the sort of attitude that many members of the Labor Opposition would like to see us take. Quite clearly, the broad thrust of the policy of the United States is correct. The broad thrust of the policy of the United States is in our interests. The instance that we are looking at, the staging of B52 aircraft in Darwin, is concerned with two matters of very considerable interest to us. One is stability in the Middle East and the other is the deterrence of nuclear war.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot do anything specific about the conduct of a nuclear war but we can assist and are assisting to deter the outbreak of such a war. That is clearly in our interests. We are doing that through providing facilities at North West Cape for communication with missile firing submarines. They are second-strike weapons designed because of their vulnerability to be able to inflict unacceptable damage in the event of a lightning attack on the United States. By their existence and by the existence of the communication stations, they make such an attack almost inconceivable. The monitoring stations in central Australia are designed to give warning of a surprise attack. Again, they contribute to the deterrent. Now in a more minor way, the staging facilities and the training for the B52 force also are contributing to deterrent. All these activities are in Australia's interests. It is in our interests to deter the outbreak of a nuclear war. It is not only in the interests of the United States but also it is in our interests. What we are seeking to do through this agreement is to increase the sea surveillance of the Indian Ocean. That is clearly in our interest. We are improving the effectiveness of a nuclear deterrent. That too is clearly in our interests. Finally, of course, we are continuing, as we should continue, co-operation with our tried allies, and that is also clearly in the interests of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that it has to be said, and said clearly, that the blame for any deficiencies in the agreement which we made on 11 March with the United States over the use of the B52 bombers in Australia cannot be laid at the door of the Government of the United States. I agree with many of the things which Senator Hamer has said. It is a realistic point of view that we have the ANZUS alliance with the United States; and I firmly believe that the majority of Australians support that view. That said, it is essential that the understanding between the two nations should be clear and unequivocal. The real objection of the Australian Democrats is to the fact-indeed it is a fact-that that agreement is not clear and unequivocal. We say it is the Government of our own country which is the culpable party here.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two questions which have to be asked. The first question is: What is the extent of its culpability to the Australian people? The second question is: How can the Government now remedy the unforgivable carelessness, laziness and slovenliness with which it has committed the Australian people to this very important agreement? It is an agreement which amounts to no less than the use in Australia of one of the United States most awesome weapons, the B52 nuclear bomber, which exists for the major purpose of delivering a massive nuclear strike against an enemy in the event of total atomic war.

It is our Government's responsibility to protect our national interests in a matter of this kind. It is our Government's job to see that the clearest and fairest agreement possible with other nations is finalised. It was our Government's job, I should have thought, if it was seeking consensus, to bring this matter forward for discussion by the Parliament before it concluded the agreement. I think it is of vital importance that the Government did not do that. It came to this Parliament with a fait accompli and said: 'Rubber stamp this'. I suggest to the Government through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it should not be surprised if those of us on this side of the House suggest changes to the agreement and that indeed many members of the community also are deeply concerned about this matter and also are suggesting changes to it.

In assessing what has happened, it is very important to separate the actual facts from the mass of rhetoric that has built up in recent days around this issue of the B52 bombers. Basically, I suggest, the rhetoric does not matter very much; it has consisted mostly of political statements, innuendo, mud slinging against individuals and then refutations and denials. That practice has been dangerous to the extent that it has tended to obscure what is really important, that is, the agreement itself, its actual terms and what it actually says. I suggest that we must look only at that agreement and be guided in our judgment by what it says and only by that. So we can look then, I suggest, at what is in it, not at what is in the speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and not at the explanations which have been made since. Sub-paragraph (I) states:

The B-52 staging operations shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training purposes. The agreement of the Government of Australia shall be obtained before the facilities are used in support of any other category of operations.
Thus far so good, but this apparently clear statement then becomes clouded and muddled by sub-paragraph (VII) of the agreement which states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B-52 staging operations through Australia.

The Australian Democrat view is that sub-paragraph (VII) should be strengthened so that there is no possible inference that consultation might be substituted for actual agreement. This could be very easily achieved simply by saying as much in that article of the agreement. Indeed, we believe it should originally have been in the agreement. We cannot understand why it was not there. The Government will keep on having trouble over this agreement until it has explained why it was not there. If it cannot come up with a satisfactory explanation, it must make sure that the agreement is renegotiated and that something is done about it. It is not too late to make changes now. There is nothing irrevocable about an agreement of this kind. If we are dealing with a friend and a friendly country, as indeed we are, it should be very pleased to permit an agreement finally to take form, which is something that the Australian people can agree with in consensus as a proper agreement between friends. It is important that treaties of this type state first the uncompromised integrity of Australian sovereignty as clearly as possible, and the present sub-paragraph (VII) does not do that.

I now turn to the most serious deficiency of all, to our mind, in the actual treaty. I think the Australian people now feel this very greatly because this is an issue which has emerged and already has become a major issue in this society. The fact is that nowhere in that treaty, from end to end, is the actual question of nuclear armaments, the carriage of nuclear armaments or the non-carriage of them mentioned. The agreement provides that, subject to the terms and conditions specified in the sub-paragraphs of the agreement, the Government of Australia agrees to United States Air Force use of RAAF Base Darwin for the staging operations of B52 aircraft and, of course, their associated KC135 tanker aircraft which refuel B52 aircraft in the air. It is necessary to reiterate that this agreement, in terms of that definition, is the only area of importance. The understandings of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) with United States Secretary of State Haig appear to have absolutely no force in law. I will be interested to hear an explanation from the Government perhaps later in this debate. Perhaps it can instruct me whether they have any force in law and how they have any force in law. I think the Australian people would be reassured by that.

I have no brief here for Mr Hayden, but I thought it not very intelligent of Mr Street to castigate Mr Hayden because he would not accept as adequate a casual, old boy agreement between Secretary of State Haig and Mr Street about nuclear weapons. Mr Street's response was to say that if Mr Hayden wished to impugn the integrity of the United States Government and of the member of Cabinet who represented it on that occasion, he should get up and say so. Senator Hamer has repeated those thoughts. I suggest that it is not worthy for a matter of this seriousness to be degenerated to this degree of politicking, because I think the Australian people see it as not worth while. It is not for me, of course, to define the attitudes of the Australian Labor Party, but certainly as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned there is no question of impugning the integrity of Secretary of State Haig or of anyone else.

The fact is that in politics and history there is a continuous change of personalities. Mr Haig may become ill, may die or may be replaced for a variety of reasons. That is why agreements between governments exist-mere verbal discussions between personalities can have no force over a period. That point was made earlier in interjections from this side of the chamber, notably by Senator Evans; and I think we agree with that. That is why Mr Street's protestations about vague and illegal agreements that the B52s will not carry nuclear weapons seem to us not to be worth the breath he expended in making them. I do not doubt his sincerity, but I doubt his competence to do his job in this regard.

The fact is that the matter should be clearly stipulated in the agreement; it should have been from the first. That agreement should say in so many words that no nuclear weapons will be carried on to Australian soil or serviced from facilities on Australian soil without the previous agreement of the Australian Government in writing. This does not seem to the Australian Democrats to be an unreasonable thing to ask for. I feel sure that the bulk of reasonable Australian people would not see it as unreasonable either. I urge the Government to commence the task of renegotiating this agreement as soon as possible and in good faith with the United States. There is no question of its being anything other than that.

If our Government does not do that, it will be guilty of consequences beyond its original laziness and carelessness in this matter. It will be guilty of perpetuating a divisive situation in this matter which will be, into the future, a permanent cloud over Australian-American relationships. That would be very damaging and we, as a political party, would see it as disastrous. We would see it as counter productive to the objectives the Government itself is trying to pursue and to those we would approve of. It is important that there be clear understanding between friends about their relationships.

I suggest that while the Government is renegotiating the matter it should look again at sub-paragraph (VII) with its reference to arrangements for consultations and should consider a new and tightly worded sub-paragraph (VII) that would make it plain that, whatever consultations are held, an expansion of the role of the B52s beyond reconnaissance and training must be subject to prior agreement of the Australian government of the day in writing.

The next point that worries the Australian Democrats is the selection of Darwin. In the United States, B52 bases are not located, quite deliberately, near major cities. Why should we have one right on the outskirts of our major northern city? Why Darwin? I was in Darwin last week and I discussed this matter with many people. It was very much a burning question in Darwin last week; everybody was talking about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it!
—Yes indeed, my friend.
—I was there with you.

—Senator MacGibbon did not talk to the right people. Perhaps he was not trying. Every one of the many people I discussed this with was asking that question. They have fears about the consequences. Are these reasonable fears? I would say that they are. I have done a good deal of reading of military texts on nuclear strategy. For a certain purpose, I once researched that subject for a full year.
—Spare us the details.

—I have a good mind to give Senator Evans all the details. Perhaps I will do that. No, I will not; I will spare him. I can only say that I was appalled at the mechanistic and cold-blooded way in which nuclear targeting, especially from submarine-based missiles, is organised. I implore Senator Evans not to approach this rather serious subject in a spirit of levity. I do not think it is one we should approach in a spirit of levity.

SPEECH.PARA: There is to my mind no doubt at all that the presence of a B52 base in Darwin will ensure that that city becomes a nuclear target of quite high priority in the event of war. I invite honourable senators to consider honestly what that means. It means that in the event of war Darwin would be obliterated in the first strike. It would be destroyed with all its men, women and children, its shops, its houses, its hospitals and it schools, because it is of a size that could be destroyed by a single submarine-launched warhead. What we are doing in this agreement is conniving very coldly in the possibility of death for a city housing 50,000 Australians.

I was shocked at the kind of rubbish some irresponsibles in the political field were talking in Darwin last week, especially the dishonest and cynical claim that somehow B52s would protect Darwin-provide a mantle of safety, I believe the words were. This is absolute and dangerous nonsense. The B52s are strategic bombers designed to drop nuclear weapons and are not likely to be adapted to Darwin's defence. I will be very pleased to hear a statement to the contrary from anybody on the other side of the chamber. If they cannot give me an undertaking, I would be pleased if they would send to Darwin a note instructing some of their people there to be a little more responsible in the statements they are making now to the citizens of that city.

It seems to the Australian Democrats that any decision to expose the people of Darwin to such a monstrous and hideous possibility as I have outlined is of tremendous consequence in this country. Even worse is that it appears to have been taken very coldly, very lightly and without good reasons. For instance, on the North West Shelf of Western Australia, far away from any major area of population, is the Royal Australian Air Force base at Learmonth. I understand that it has the runways to handle B52s. It would need more facilities certainly, but it seems not unreasonable to assume that the United States might be prepared to provide those facilities. I gather that there is a question of an extra runway having to be built at Darwin. Why Darwin? I bring up this point again and again. What about Learmonth?

Learmonth is much closer to the Indian Ocean than is Darwin. It would seem much more rational and reasonable to use it and to get any possible danger away from one of our cities than to use Darwin. Because it is closer to the Indian Ocean it should be much more suited for surveillance there and would be in fact a considerable economy in terms of crew time, fuel and everything else. To conclude, the Australian Democrats again ask: Why Darwin? It is a good question to ask the Government. We would like a reply to it. We will not stop asking that question until we get a reasonable reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this agreement between Australia and the United States on the use of facilities at Darwin by the B52s. It is one small but positive step to increase the security of Australia and of the Western democracies. The agreement provides that B52s and KC135s can use Darwin. Sub-paragraph (I) defines the purpose for which they will be tasked operationally. Sub-paragraph (II) gives the numbers of aircraft involved at any one time. Sub-paragraph (VII) details the consultations that the Government will be required to go through with the United States if there is any change in these defined operational requirements. Sub-paragraph (VIII) defines how those changed operations may come about. Despite what Senator Mason said, sub-paragraph (VIII) is necessary because the Australian Government has to go through fit and proper conditions to fulfil its treaty obligations. It is necessary to provide that we can fulfil the requirements of the ANZUS treaty if it is necessary in a time of emergency. That is the great importance of sub-paragraph (VIII). I would like to deal with sub-paragraphs (V) and (VI), which state:

SPEECH.PARA: (V) Irrespective of financial arrangements agreed between the two Governments, RAAF Base Darwin shall remain an Australian facility under Australian control.

(VI) No circumstances arising from this Agreement shall affect the title of the Government of Australia to the relevant land, or the pre-existing authority of the Government of Australia in the use of RAAF Base Darwin.

I think that is a particularly important point and I commend the Government for making it. I am behind this agreement in all ways because I believe we have to support the United States, but I do not believe that we should ask the United States to pay for the facilities it uses here. That is where I differ most strongly with Senator Mason.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Casual Senate Vacancies in Queensland-Tasmanian Timber Industry

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the adjournment debate tonight to mention two matters associated with the print media. I mention firstly a letter which I wrote to the editor of the Brisbane Courier-Mail. The topic of that letter was suggested to me when I saw a letter written by Senator Bjelke-Petersen to Wallace Brown, the Courier-Mail's representative in Canberra. In discussing casual Senate vacancies in that letter Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Joh asked for a panel of names when the Labor Party proposed Mal Colston, because the ALP had demanded the same thing previously.

The latter part of that assertion is quite false. I replied to that point by way of a letter to the editor of the Courier-Mail. Most of the letter was not published so I would like to read the whole reply so that the letter I wrote is on record. I mention that I have discussed the severe abbreviation of the letter with the editor of the Courier-Mail so I am not going behind his back in mentioning the matter in this chamber. I read from the letter which was printed in quite an abbreviated fashion in the Courier-Mail. The letter states:

In a letter to Wallace Brown, (C-M 14 March) Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to the nomination of three persons for the Senate vacancy caused by the resignation of Dr Glen Sheil. The nomination of a panel in the State Parliament last Thursday bordered on the Gilbertian because it was a fait accompli that Senator Bjelke-Petersen would be the successful candidate.

More important than that, however, is the incorrect information in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's letter to Wallace Brown. The Senator stated: 'Joh asked for a panel of names when the Labor Party proposed Mal Colston, because the ALP had demanded the same thing previously.' The latter part of that assertion is absolutely false.

These are some relevant facts: Prior to the introduction of proportional representation in 1949, there were three casual vacancies in Queensland. In none of these cases was there a call for a panel of candidates.

After the introduction of proportional representation, State Parliaments recognised that it was proper to replace a Senator who died or resigned with a person of the same political persuasion. Since 1949 and prior to last Thursday's proceedings, four casual vacancies have been filled by a sitting of the Queensland Parliament.

Two of these were Liberal vacancies, the first caused by the death of Senator Sherrington in 1966 and the second by the resignation of Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin in 1971. In both cases, the Liberal Party submitted one nominee only and those nominees, Senators Heatley and Bonner respectively, were duly appointed by the Queensland Parliament.

In 1962, Labor Senator Max Poulter died and the Labor Party nominated Mr Alf Arnell to fill the vacancy. The Country-Liberal Government, led by Mr Nicklin, refused to accept Mr Arnell because of his alleged left-wing philosophy. It insisted upon another nominee and the Party reluctantly (and against the wishes of many Party members) submitted the name of Mr George Whiteside who was subsequently appointed.

Upon the death of Senator Bert Milliner in 1975, the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, demanded that the Labor Party submit a panel of three nominees for the vacancy. This time the Labor Party would not accede to the Premier's demands and I was the only person nominated by the ALP.
The Premier seized the opportunity to stack the Senate and selected Albert Field.

I stress that the ALP has never demanded that a panel of names be submitted when it has been necessary to fill a casual vacancy. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen is going to rely on history to support her arguments, she should first make sure that her facts are correct.
Yours sincerely
MAL COLSTON Senator for Queensland
The other matter which I wish to raise is related to a motion of which I gave notice in the Senate yesterday. Today's Notice Paper outlines that I moved as follows:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make provision for the Senators for the State of Queensland to be chosen by the people of that State voting as one electorate.

I gave such notice as I was originally assured that I would, indeed, be able to bring my motion forward today. I have no quibble with the fact that it has been necessary to delay my Bill's introduction. I believe it will be brought on in the near future. Unfortunately, however, Press representatives misunderstood the purpose of my Bill. I would like to read from sections of two newspaper reports which refer to this. An article on page 8 of this morning's Australian stated among other things:

Senator Florence Isobel Bjelke-Petersen had barely taken her seat in the Senate yesterday when an Opposition senator gave notice of a private member's Bill which, if enacted, would prevent further political appointments to the Upper House.
The article went on to mention some other things including your reply, Mr President, to admit them. The last paragraph of the article stated:
Moments after the swearing-in, the Senator Mal Colston (Queensland) gave notice of his private member's Bill, which, if enacted, would stop political Senate appointments.
An article in the Courier-Mail, the newspaper from the capital city of my home State, outlined how Senator Bjelke-Petersen was sworn in. The article concluded:
Queensland Labor Senator Colston gave notice of a private member's Bill, which would prevent further political appointments to the Senate.

I do not want to traverse the content of my Bill at this stage. I stress it has nothing to do with political appointments or casual vacancies. Indeed, it had nothing to do with Senator Bjelke-Petersen except insofar as she is a senator for Queensland as are nine other people. When I present the Bill, the content will become available and will become known to all. If Press representatives had wanted to know what it was all about I would have been happy to inform them yesterday. I consider this would have been a far preferable course of action than to disregard the facts so that a good story was not spoiled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly on behalf of the Tasmanian Timber Association to bring a matter, which is of grave concern to the exporters of timber from Tasmania, to the attention of the Senate in the first instance and, of course, to seek action from the relevant Minister who in this case is the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). As honourable senators know, the timber industry in Tasmania is based on our dense and continuous forests with which we are blessed, unlike the mainly more arid regions of mainland Australia. Some 31 per cent of the State's area is in fact covered by what might be loosely termed commercial forest area. The industry is based on hardwoood holdings although softwood is being planted to supplement the hardwood natural timbers. Figures which I obtained tonight from the Parliamentary Library indicate that we exported some 245,000 cubic metres of sawn timbers at a value of some $29m in 1977-78. No doubt, when adjusted for inflation, those figures could be enhanced. However, this gives some idea of the scope and importance of this industry in Tasmania-the export of sawn timber.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it is very important that the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme operate in a fair manner not only in respect of producers of sawn timber in Tasmania but also in respect of the Australian taxpayer from each State and Territory who contributes moneys to the Federal revenue. In what I am about to say there is no intention on my part or, indeed, on the part of the Tasmanian Timber Association to impugn the attempts by the Department of Transport to reach a rate applicable for north-bound sawn timber from Tasmania which, as I say, is fair both to producers and to the taxpayers who are paying a subsidy related to the volume and weight of wood sent north to the mainland.

This saga began on 24 December 1979 when the Department of Transport made it known to the Tasmanian timber industry that assistance rates applicable to north-bound timber were to be varied and a new series of rates was to apply from 1 January 1980. In summary and without going into great technical detail, one tonne of timber that occupies 1.9 cubic metres of stowage or less-in other words, it is dense or perhaps green timber-was to have assistance paid at a lower rate than fully dried and seasoned timber of which one tonne could be stowed in 1.9 cubic metres or more. For example, the rate of assistance for transportation from northern Tasmania to Victoria of the dense, usually green timber would be $6 a tonne but on dry, less dense timber the rate would be $11 a tonne. I will not go into the technical details. I merely say that the variation between the two rates of assistance was then dependent on whether one tonne of timber occupied more or less than 1.9 cubic metres.

In practical terms, this meant that from that date, 1 January 1980, all green timber and about one-third of all dried timber bollards moving north from Tasmania received assistance at about half the previous rate. As honourable senators can imagine, this has had quite a severe impact on the industry. One may note in passing, as I have said, that the determination apparently was made on Christmas Eve 1979 and notified to the industry at a time when the industry was in its traditional recess. So, in fact, when businesses began their operations in the third or fourth week of January 1980, they were confronted with circulars and letters which one might say had a retrospective impact because contracts and undertakings entered into by the industry for the year commencing 1 January 1980 were, as I said, negotiated and undertaken without any idea that this new rating system would apply.

Be that as it may, its impact was estimated by the Tasmanian Timber Association at that time to be such that about $750,000 worth of assistance which might previously have been expected under the old formula would be lost by the application of the new formula. It may be that some new formula was and is required so that some exporters of timber are not overcompensated and some are not undercompensated. Some change might be required. As honourable senators can imagine, correspondence has been entered into and has been going backward and forward between the responsible Minister and the Tasmanian Timber Association for some 15 months since January 1980.

I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate by detailing the correspondence and the various conferences that have taken place. The Minister has received delegations. His officials have been made available both from his Department and the Bureau of Transport Economics. One can say that a situation was reached in the latter part of last year in which the Minister was prepared to say that there are alternatives. It may be that the break point should not be 1.9 cubic metres per tonne. Perhaps one could look at alternatives ranging from 1.3 cubic metres, or even a new flat rate. He pointed out the consequences of selecting new break points. That led to further consideration by the Tasmanian Timber Association, which eventually suggested that 1.6 cubic metres be the break point. That elicited further replies from the Minister which pointed out that this break point might have a detrimental effect on some exporters of timber. At the end of this 11 or 12 months of negotiation, in a letter dated 11 December 1980, the Tasmanian Timber Association concluded:

Under these circumstances we believe that, even at 1.6, the subsidy rates should not be reduced but, for the sake of cutting short to some degree the continued injustice of the present assistance rates, we acknowledge that you probably will reduce them.

This amounted-and I believe it was understood to amount-to a plea that the north-bound assistance rate for timber be set at a break point of 1.6, with such consequences to the industry as the Minister had outlined, and the industry was forced to accept that. The industry accepted it reluctantly, but considered that it was marginally better than the original proposal put forward on 1 January.

Further correspondence and telegrams have been entered into. Senator Messner looks a little bewildered, and I agree that I may seem to be speaking, in the substance of my remarks, about a technical area. My real concern is about the sequence of events. Over 15 months have elapsed since the matter was first presented to the Tasmanian Timber Association and the new rates were introduced, about which continuing negotiation has taken place. There has been no meaningful response from the Minister since the letter dated 11 December last year from the Tasmanian Timber Association to the Minister accepting the 1.6 break point. There have been just a series of acknowledgments and letters which, I may say, have put off the Tasmanian Timber Association.

I believe that this industry which, as I pointed out in my earlier remarks, is of great importance to the economy and to employment in Tasmania, has been treated in a shabby manner. It certainly has not been treated in an expeditious manner or in a way that reflects the urgency which is spoken of and experienced not only by the exporters themselves but also by their employees in the sawmilling industry in Tasmania. I believe that unless we get a response in the very near future the Federal Government will have to bear the ignominy of its attitude of putting off this industry's legitimate claims for full consultation and a response to the compromise which was reached over many months. I ask the Minister to take to the Minister for Transport the concern that I express, not only on my behalf but on behalf of the other Tasmanian Labor senators with whom I have consulted, and I consulted with them all before making these remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can include me.

—Senator Harradine asked that I include him. In fact I am fair-minded enough to say that I believe that any Tasmanian senator would be willing to support the plea that I make tonight for an expeditious and speedy reply to the complaint of the Tasmanian Timber Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two matters have been raised tonight. One related to Senator Colston, and I thought at one stage that we were going to have a speech on the Bill which he proposes to introduce. I, for one, would very much like to hear more about that at some future time. Nevertheless I-like the Press-probably have totally misunderstood what the Bill is about. However, the point was made, and we look forward to that discussion on some future occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Tate's matter, it is a complicated one, and he has outlined it very competently on behalf of Tasmanian senators. He makes the point quite clearly that expedition is what is required. I will undertake on his behalf and on behalf of all Tasmanian senators to obtain an early reply from the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) on this matter, and will ensure that the message is conveyed to him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
